In my experience I never thought that I would enjoy psychology much less want to minor in it. I thought that I only wanted to program and work with computers, but once I took the intro to Psychology class I found that I really enjoy other topics also.

fields.title: All in Good Company
fields.post:
Inside Higher Ed posted a great article today on the qualities associated with successful and productive researchers. Aside from individual motivation, the strongest indicators of success were associated with networking skills. For anyone who knows me, they should know I've been convinced of the importance of networking since I started Graduate school, but it's always nice to see my thoughts echoed by someone else.

The key to success, in my obviously qualified opinion, is rooted in the professional relationships that you build throughout your life. Whether you're an academic like me or a professional out in the industry, a diverse network of people who are devoted to personal development is one of the most important resources built during the formative years of your career. As it turns out, there's actually a name for this important group of people: it's called a Personal Learning Network (PLN), a buzzword that I discovered thanks to a comment on my blog from the Research Whisperer about a year ago. Now that I know the term, I see it everywhere!

Note that my two qualities of the people that make up a PLN didn't include anything about intelligence, notoriety, or quantity. The two traits that I think are key are diversity and devotion. When fully fleshed out, the people that you consider colleagues should consist of people who are passionate about the same things you are, but looking at them from a different perspective. As someone who is interested in technology education, my network contains both career academics and industry professionals... computer scientists and humanities scholars... people local to me and people located all over the world!

The most beautiful part about a personal learning network is that it is a symbiotic relationship. Having a PLN enriches you because it exposes you to different viewpoints and broadens your view of the world, getting out of sheltered disciplinary silos and building global thinking skills. But while it may not look like it at first, the people with whom you collaborate are getting the same value, but in a different package... they are getting the technical experience and expertise that comes with the training we receive in our discipline. This informal give-and-take of knowledge is learning in its purest form, and nothing is more reassuring than facing a problem with the support of a diverse network of colleagues behind you.

The best ideas I've come across didn't manifest themselves in a classroom or a lab, but instead over a beer among good company. Some of my most inspirational colleagues don't even have a bachelor's degree, but have more passion about education and technology than some of my peers in the Ph.D. program here at State. It's not about credentials or institutional affiliations, but about people with a positive attitude that brings out the best in you. It takes some effort to build these networks, as it requires keeping an eye out for opportunities that fall outside of the comfort zone of our discipline. It isn't easy, but it's well worth it.

fields.title: Since I Know What I Wish I Knew Back When I Wished I Was Where I Am Now...
fields.post:
I am human and I read somewhere being a human did not come with instructions, therefore I am prone to make mistakes in life. However from those mistakes comes wisdom. For example, as a child you touch an iron that is on, out of curiosity. What happens? Well, besides the twenty minutes of crying and yelling, HOT! HOT!, you learn that touching a hot surface will burn. In contrast, as you go through life you will make mistakes, some worse than others, but all will contribute to you becoming a better person if you learn from them. Faults help define who we are as people, they give uniqueness to each individual. I myself am a firm believer in learning from mistakes and turning those negatives into positives. Thus, failure is one of the keys to success...you may be asking yourself, what does he mean by that? When it comes to failure, giving up is what turns it into a problem but embracing it and growing gives you the upper hand in whatever situation. Another key to success is taking the initiative, don't always wait around expecting. Be like Nike and "Just Do It". There will always come a point in which you feel as if you are done, but you are not. There are so many opportunities out there in the world however people are no longer finding it necessary to go to them, they rather wait for one to approach them. There is so much I can say about the keys to success but I can't state all of them being that I am still in the midst of reaching success. I am a lot more knowledgeable now than I was then and there are so many things I wish I could do over, but then I think to myself, if I was to go back and change something, how would that affect me to this day? I have learned that I undergo various events in life because I am suppose to and that in the end, the struggle, the happiness, the greif, etc will all be worth it.

Some advice for those who are climbing their own ladder to success:
be humble,
be wise,
be thoughtful,
be kind,
be strong,
be different,
be careful,
and be efficient.

Don't let anyone tell you that you are not capable of completing whatever you set forth and with that said be YOU!

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post:
So better late than never. This year I will be working on the SPARCS @ CCMMS project, the CS Principles project, and leading the STARS program with Robinson. This is my 5th year on the SPARCS project and I'm excited for some of the new activities we'r rolling out, like Kodu and TouchDevelop. I'm also trying to coordinate lab tours for the students involved so they can come to campus and see the latest and greatest in cutting edge computer science research. While I spent my 1.5 years at Charlotte, lab tours happened almost once a week. I was able to plug my outreach kids into these tours, and they absolutely loved it. For some of those students it was their first time they or their parents have been on a college campus, which is incredible.

My other non-STARS projects this semester include designing a Lebanese immigration game for the museum of natural history, consulting high school students at Shaw University on making a CSI game, and continuing my hunt for a focused research topic.

As far as goals go, my big one is to figure out what I want to focus my research on. I've been assisting on a variety of research projects and have reached the point in my grad career where, I should be honing in on one thing. My other goals this semester include writing at least 1 conference paper, working out ~10 days a month, and leading a successful STARS team. Additionally, I want to avoid the need to pull an all-nighter, and still maintain my time management skills.

My expectations for the upcoming year are that I will inevitably commit to more projects than I can mange. I will therefore expect to "voluntell" more people for tasks they are currently unaware of, these people will consequently learn the meaning of "voluntell." I also expect that somehow I will be able to help someone in a seemingly arbitrary manner, but that it will have a large impact on them.

As far as milestones go, this spring I am scheduled to take my qualifying exam for graduate school. Next month will also be my first trip to the NSF building. Milestones that occurred recently were my first trip to the West Coast, and the first time I EVER made a sandwich containing meat on bread (& yes it was for someone else).

Something cool I did this summer, was teach 120+ people ages 11 to 87 how to make an application for the Windows 7 phone using touch develop (~40 minors, ~20 high school teachers, ~60 STARS Celebration attendees).

fields.title: Defining Success
fields.post: The key to my own success in computer science has been my ability to self evaluate my work.  There have been times when I've coded a project and although it received a good grade I knew it wasn't my best work.  On the other hand there have been times when I've built something very interesting or creative and although it  didn't necessarily get me the grade I had hoped for I knew that it was those projects that I want to strive for as a programmer.  The ability to recognize personal success and lack there of has been vital to learning computer science.  This is especially true in programing where "success" needs to be defined by both yourself and others not just a teacher or a testsuite.  Confidence in accessing my own work and achievements has helped me find my own version of success.

fields.title: The Road Not Taken
fields.post:
When asked about the keys to success, most people mention things like diligence, intelligence, and the ability to make connections with other people. There are hundreds upon hundreds of books and articles on the topic of becoming successful, with most of them saying things that everyone knows, but nobody wants to admit.

After reading the article "9 Beliefs of Remarkably Successful People" (http://www.inc.com/jeff-haden/9-beliefs-of-remarkably-successful-people.html?nav=pop), I'm trying to come up with good, solid life advice that I would pass on to future computer science students.

The results are as follows:
1) Get Out Of Bed - It's amazing how hard this one can be, especially after a few weeks of working on projects and grinding away at tests. It's tempting to sleep in for a few classes, and just put things off until later. Once that starts, though, everything starts snowballing into something that's a lot harder to handle.

2) Make Connections - "Networking" is a buzzword these days, but there's a reason for it. Go out there, make friends, and talk to people. Catching the eye of someone on a research group or in a business might be your ticket to getting your foot in the door.

3) Do Something Different - Nobody's a cookie-cutter copy of their neighbor. If something interests you, try it out. Don't let any stigmas get in your way. If you want to write a novel, or do a study abroad trip, or join the parkour club, go for it. You'll be a happier person for having tried it, and there will be other people (potentially job recruiters) who find your hobbies just as interesting as you do.

4) "It's Not A Bug; It's A Feature!" - You're going to mess up. It's a fact of life. Success is when failure is used as a tool, not a handicap. Put a positive spin on whatever happened (which can be hard, sometimes), and then move on with your life, doing whatever you can to learn from the experience.

So, yeah. There you go. Life advice from an undergrad. Maybe somebody will get some use out of it.

fields.title: Identify the "lock" before the "key" :)
fields.post:
As I started thinking about the topic of the blog, I realized that "key" is somewhat a misnomer. What use is a key without knowing the lock??? I guess my first "key" to success is finding the lock :) Analyze and analyze well to identify the correct problem/issue and then the creating the "key" becomes much more easier. 

Another thing that comes to mind is something that came out of the mouth of my absolute favorite sportsperson of all time - Rahul Dravid (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rahul_Dravid). He once spoke about how usually only natural stroke makers (in case of cricket) are considered talented. He felt that people who possessed the ability to work hard,  to persevere, to work with diligence etc should also be considered talented. This was one of those "Aha" moments for me. I have personally heard people commenting - XYZ is not really talented but he has the hard working capacity to make up for it. Why is hard work not considered a talent? Shouldn't it be an obvious talent :)  There goes my second key (keys) to success- hard work, perseverance and diligence. This is the piece of advice I would give any student in general. 

My third key would be to know how much to take on. Throwing in your hat for different things provides great opportunity to learn new things and I would do it every-chance I get but sometimes learning to say No is important. -This piece of advice I would give to every version of me - I'm still working on it :)

fields.title: How to get other departments involved
fields.post:
Hi All,
I am sure everyone is excited about their STARS projects this semester. During yesterday's meeting, I realized one way to reach out to more people would be to get people from other departments involved. These are the few ways that I was thinking about. 

1) We could help them with their technology use - we can begin with a survey and see what kind of technology they use and if they need help/tutoring etc. We could introduce something like R to statistics department students (I assume they would primarily use something like SAS) or LateX (like Veronica mentioned)- something along those lines

2) The other way would be to see if other departments are using some interesting technology (say textile design students or horticulture) and we could invite some grad students to give guest lectures (of sorts) (invite undergrads to attend ). If not anything, it would just mean getting exposed to some new (cool!!!) s/w.
3) Avoid guest lectures- record a presentation/video/audio and create a STARS page with all these "Tech-Talks" and pass on links university wide. (Collect usage info and publish paper :))
4) We could provide technology assistance for projects.Say, some biology class has a project where they need to collect and record some measurements and analyze it. If we link some of our undergrads with those grad or undergrad students - they could for starters maybe create a simple UI with back end database to collect and store results. They could also maybe help computationally analyze them.  This could be a great resume add on for undergrads.


This first step would to be to create a survey and see if other department students want to be involved and how it can be mutually beneficial.

Feel free to send me comments- kpadman@ncsu.edu (Anything from this idea won't work (or is not necessary) because...... or Gr8 idea and this is how it can be improved or Awesome and I want to be involved... :) ).

Thanks,
-Kanchana

fields.title: Success...a Journey
fields.post: I still remember the quote my father always reminded me of - "There is always room at the top when bottom is crowded." and I have realized from personal experiences, that the quote is very true and real in this practical world. I have heard this many times and truly believe that success is a journey and not a destination. I might sound as a Student writing a GRE essay - but the truth remains that success is not something that is "take it and go" but more like "achieve it and stick to it".  I have failed numerous times in my life till now in academics, competitions, social life etc. but it is the courage to hit back strongly next time, that has helped me in getting success which otherwise wouldn't have been possible if I did not try it that n+1 th time. It is the courage to go that extra mile that has helped in succeeding in things I like. Flexibility is another component that has helped me. I try to remain away from getting tangled into rigid rules and allow myself to remain flexible to try new things, to help people and to learn new things just for the sake of experience. I also believe that in order to be successful in a team, one should not form opinions on others too quickly. Give some time, and you will be amazed to discover positive qualities in a person which otherwise would have been shadowed if you formed a negative haste opinion. Lastly, from my experience as a student in Computer Science - I would say that the 4 years of undergraduate life is the Golden period of life. Don't take it too seriously and don't waste it too carelessly. Be passionate and confident about the things you want to learn and volunteer as much as possible because that is the key to successful networking..It is truly said that sometimes "it doesn't matter what you know, it matters who you know". Try to communicate with professors often by visiting their office hours and getting into a research project or something. I think research is really important in Computer Science and, I regret of having spent less time on it. So Good Luck and keep moving!

fields.title: 2012-2013 Action Plan
fields.post:
This (academic) year is going to become really intensive - I can say that for sure. My plan is to finish up work on my research and write up my dissertation in the coming 6-8 months. Then, if everything goes well, I hope to defend end of Spring or Summer 2013.

This semester I'm working on a journal paper focused on saliency detection in images, and a couple of Android projects - one of them is a touch/gesture library that we're planning to release open source. I've also signed up on a IEEE Ground Robotics team, and we are meeting regularly, preparing towards an event in 2013.

The weather's been really good, so I've been riding my bike a lot. Hope it stays this way for some more time.

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post:
I am working on developing a program for a local Durham charter school desiring a program to show a variety of technology to K-8 students. I am also in contact with high schools (still) concerning dissiminating information concerning STARs and computer science/engineering. Need help with information from STARs.

I am currently working on research but I am looking forward to new adventures with STARs. An important milestone for me is to complete my written exam.

I guess the cool thing for me this past summer was spending it with my daughter, who is now a junior in college.

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post: This is my second semester as a PhD student at St8 and is already turning out to be a pretty good one. Just before leaving for the past summer, I completed my Written Preliminary examination and I am happy that has come in a record time. This semester I am planning to focus my research on a new topic involving User Mobility Management and Optimization Strategy. My goal for this semester is to come up with my next research idea and make substantial progress in it. As for STARS, I am a tutor for undergraduate students for CSC116, Introductory Java.

fields.title: My first STARS blog!
fields.post:
Hello World!

This is Srinath. I'm currently a second year graduate student and am working as a research assistant working on application tracing in parallel computing environments. I'm super excited to work on some really awesome cluster environments. Makes me think that I can compute anything I want in no time! :)

This is my first semester as a STARS member. I'm hoping to mentor/teach undergraduates some programming. I hope to help someone out thereby augmenting my skills as a teacher as well. The summer was well spent at Riverbed technology, Sunnyvale. I was an intern in their kernel networking team. It was an enriching experience and I got to meet some really smart folks and learnt a lot.

My aims for this semester are to
- Do awesome progress in the research
- For fun, learn haskell, a functional programming language and implement a small machine learning library for it
- Learn android programming and implement a small VoIP client on it

fields.title: New Years Blog
fields.post:
It's the beginning of a new school year. As someone who's been here all summer, the beginning of the school year doesn't always hold a lot of meaning for me. There are more people, new students, new faces. More activity. But the day to day life of a graduate student ceases to change when the core classes are completed. 

That's not to say that everything's the same as it was last year, or even last month. This year holds an important milestone for my personal progress: My Oral Preliminary Exam. Of course, the name of the exam tells you very little about what it actually is. Basically, at least from what I've been told, this is my proposal for my dissertation. That means I've picked a topic, have had a little bit of time to get excited about it, and now I get to put it out into the aether and see what my committee thinks of it. With any luck, i'll be one step closer to graduation.

Of course, that doesn't keep me nearly busy enough. This year, I'm doing my reading challenge again. A little lighter than last year, I'm trying to read 100 books by the end of the calendar year. I'm a little behind, coming in at just over 50 books, but I've got a couple trips coming up that'll give me some time to plow through a couple titles. Last year, I made 125 by reading 3-4 books on new years eve, so there's still plenty of time to catch up.

My other personal challenge for this semester is NaNoWriMo. It's an unusual challenge for someone in the computing fields, though I know of a couple others (one of whom who's even in Stars... you know who you are) who've attempted it in the past. NaNoWriMo is short for National Novel Writing Month. The goal is to write a full length novel (50,000 words) within the thirty days of November. This will be my 5th attempt, and will finally break the tie for whether I win or lose more often. I've got a great premise, just have to find the story within it. If you're curious, check in with me in December to see how the whole thing turned out.

Lastly, we have Stars. This year, I'm making a last attempt at pushing my tutoring agenda. Discrete Math is a really important class, and is often considered one of the hardest classes here. The sparsity of volunteers for this gig probably speaks to that. So it should be an exciting semester. Looking forward to taking you all on the ride.

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post:
This semester I am working with Joseph Grafsgaard on developing unsupervised methods for facial feature clustering, currently working on AU4, brow lowering, identification.  I hope that in this upcoming year I will be able to write about my results and submit a paper to the AIED conference.  At the moment I am working on extracting facial expressions effectively regardless of tilt or rotation of the head so that my solution can be used to identify AU4 in non-posed footage (the goal being using it to identify AU4 in the JavaTutor video corpus).
This summer I went to NAACL in Montreal and had a great time.  It was a very interesting experience and I learned about the different work going on in machine translation, topic modeling and even some gaming that used verbal input.

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post: This year I look forward to the many things that are in store for me from academia to the endless opportunities to better myself as a student and as an engineer. I am excited to be apart of the STARS Alliance along with fellow students and take yet another challenging year head on. In order to do my best, my aim is to spend time managing my time if that makes sense. In the past, I have not been a good candidate for punctuality or great time management, but that is all behind me now. I plan to grow from this undergraduate experience as it will be my guideline for my future. With that being said, I am going to attend workshops/interest meetings, network with others and become a bit more involved with my major. Some planned projects that I am going to be apart of will be the USCRI refugee project that will introduce the computing environments to those who are not savvy from other countries. I am also going to be an Evaluation Assistant for the 2012-2013 academic year. So look out world, or to be more specific NC State, Gregory Daniels is on the move and will not let anything hold him back!

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post:
I am really excited about this school year since I now have a year of coordinating the SPARCS@DNS middle school outreach initiative under my belt. It's been a great ride so far as the program has really grown throughout the last several years. I am most excited about doing a possible workshop on Microsoft TouchDevelop since it allows students the ability to program on a physical device. There's nothing more rewarding then watching a kid gain confidence in his/her abilities after creatively solving a problem.

Outside of SPARCS@DNS, I plan on being an active member in the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE), Caribbean Student Association (CSA), and continuing my undergraduate research. I am apart of a team that is working on building an innovative and visually appealing health news website for college-aged African-American females. Now that we've launched (myhealthimpactnetwork.org), my spare time will be taken up writing a research paper and presenting my findings at various conferences. 

My expectations this year include excelling academically, being a great mentor and role model to younger students, and applying to Ph. D programs centered around Human Computer Interaction. It should be an interesting year to say the least but I am looking forward to it.

fields.title: New Year's Post
fields.post:
Happy New Year!

So this semester I will be doing several things. Mostly I'll be working with SPARCs DNS and CSC 116 (introduction to java) tutoring.

This year I am a senior at NC State university. I am working on my computer science undergraduate degree. I currently reside on the border of Cary and Raleigh. I work at RerverbNation in Durham. It's an awesome job and I do something that I love.

My expectations of this year are to work hard and really just to learn. I tend to learn the most when I'm busy and I plan on being this semester. I also plan to be a good tutor by being patient and thorough in my explanations. With SPARCs I have the expectation that I might not be the greatest kid person but I will definitely be a positive influence in computer science.

I don't really believe in milestones. I believe they do two things. They cap your potential or the stress you our when they aren't going to be met. This is how I plan on measuring success. If the 116 students, SPARCs students, and I learn and have fun then I will consider this a success.

The coolest thing I did this summer was see some friends get married. It was a pretty cool experience.

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post: This is my first semester as a STARS member (I volunteered previously) and I am looking forward to contributing to the three projects I have signed up for. From academic perspective, this semester is going to be really busy, working on a research paper now and hope to get it submitted soon. This summer I was working at Lawrence Berkeley National lab, my first time at a research lab environment. It was very exciting to be working with a group that owns some of the best technology & data in computational biology.

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post:
This semester will be my busiest to date. I have a lot on my plate on the academic, research, and extracurricular fronts. At a high level, I hope to use this semester to start setting my post-graduation goals. I only have two years left here at State and soon I will be applying to PhD programs. At a low level, I hope find enough time to excel in my commitments. For STARS, I will be working with SPARCS and the website team. This is my first semester in STARS and I'm really excited to start the SPARCS sessions.

I spent this summer up in Seattle working for Microsoft. I was an intern on the Internet Explorer web programming team. It was a great experience and I learned a lot about how an industry leader does software development the right way.

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post: Seems like a long semester already! Was the first Summer that I stayed back in Raleigh. This semester, I will continue to help with the USCRI refugee project. We hope to get more students than the last semester and make it useful to as many as possible. I will be attending the Grace Hopper Conference for the first time...so looking forward to that! Have lot of things lined up for the next few months, so will be a busy and exciting semester....now just need to breathe in, breathe out and take one day at a time :)

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post:
As my 3rd year at NCSU starts, I have a variety of activities to keep me busy.

On the research front, I am hoping to make significant progress on my written qualifier.  Currently I am looking at how to use scientific drawings to aid in student modeling for 4th grade science students.

On the STARS front I am teaching a 10 week LEGO Robotics course with Citizen Schools for the 4th time.  It is always fun to meet a new group of kids and see what kinds of projects they come up with.

fields.title: The Beginning of the End
fields.post:
Its that time of year again, where all the new and returning STARS projects are scrambling to get together. I am excited to be participating in SPARCS@CCMMS again for this new academic year as well as continuing to work on new features and bug fixes for the website with the rest of the website team. Some exciting changed might be coming about in the SPARCS curriculum if we can get our hands on some Windows Phones. I will also be tutoring CSC116 a couple times during the week. I enjoy getting to help other students with programming and showing them that yes, even though it can be hard, its just as equally rewarding, if not more, when you have a cool and working program.

This is my last semester at NC State and STARS. I will be graduating in December with another handful of students and be thrown into the real world. I am currently focusing a lot of my extra time on finding a web development job in the area. Unfortunately, it seems like those jobs are somewhat lacking. Besides finding a job, Im balancing my work with ITng, RiboLab, Senior Design, and my other classes. Im being kept busy, which is a great thing, and hope to finish out strong for my last semester here at State.

Its going to be an interesting semester!

fields.title: Impending ...
fields.post: Welcome to my ramblings about my upcoming year.  As the full year is too intimidating for me to think about in a single sitting, I will only be going over half of my year.  This semester, I am working on research with Dr Gu.  The topic of the research is improving distributed systems and optimizing fault tolerance.  For STARS, I am looking forward to helping out with the robotics in Durham.  Robotics has always been a personal interest of mine, so I look forward to being able to help kids and have fun at the same time.  My high level goals this semester are to get the most out of my classes and survive them.  My low level goals this semester are to do well in my computer networking class and get a summer position secured for next year.  Once I get through this semester, I can begin to think about next semester.

fields.title: Septemblog!
fields.post:
This is my first year in STARS, and I'm pretty excited to be a part of the program.
  
This year, I'll be working on tutoring outreach through the SPARCS program.  I'm getting to go out and play with Lego Mindstorms and Gamemaker, and also work with middle school students, trying to get them interested in computing.
  
As a high level goal for the year, I would like to get out a paper about the undergraduate research that I'm doing in knowledge-tracing techniques.
  
As a low-level goal, I'd like to figure out the interactions between the various parts of the program I'm working with to write that paper.  Things will work a lot better once I figure that out...
   
For the upcoming year, I'd like to get some research experience and find a co-op job.
  
This year should be fun, but it's trying to top last summer's month-long study abroad trip to Italy.  I look forward to seeing how the two compare.

fields.post: My goals for this semester consist of narrowing down my research which will pave the way for me to begin working on my first qualifier by the end of this semester. My plan is to finish my first qualifier by April  2013 and participate in a research internship on related research top the following summer. Throughout the year I will focus my time, on reading articles, applying to fellowships, and networking at events held on campus and in the surrounding area.

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post:
In this coming year I am really excited to be working on the SPARCS@CCMMS project again.  This year we will have two groups of students, one that meets on the weekdays and one that meets on Saturdays.  I am excited to see this program grow even more.  I am also doing an REU with the JavaTutor project.  I think that I will really enjoy this also and get to combine my two academic interests in Computer Science and Psychology.

This past summer I was able to have an internship at a small company in Charlotte called Swisher.  I worked on automating some database processes that my co-workers were doing manually.

fields.title: STARdate 201209.12
fields.post:
Despite being quite far removed from my first year at State, this is my first year as a member of STARS. Looks like I'll be making this first year count, though, as I'm heading up undergraduate tutoring for 116 and 216, helping out with SPARCS@DNS, mentoring a student, and occasionally helping out with the mentoring demonstration project. Outside of STARS this semester, I'll be working on my research in tutorial dialogue systems, writing conference and journal papers, working on my written prelim, taking a machine learning course, and keeping up with my duties as a research assistant and volunteer teaching assistant. So my main goal for this semester is just to keep my sanity. :)

Why would a person subject himself to such madness? Well, this leads me to the part about what I did over the summer. A major perk of being a grad student is going to conferences and meeting really cool people from all over the world and seeing the interesting stuff they're working on. This was my first major conference-going summer, and I traveled to Florida, Montreal, and Seoul, presenting my first talk and first poster to an academic audience. It's definitely a thrill to be able to explain your work to people who've been researching the same kinds of things as you for 30 years, or who have authored the definitive textbook in your field (especially if they're good enough to act interested). I'm looking forward to presenting some great results from the undergraduate tutoring project at next year's STARS celebration!

fields.title: New Year's Blog
fields.post:
This is my first year in STARS, and I am enjoying it so far. I am doing CSC 116 tutoring and USCRI for STARS, as well as a hobby project of mine. 

My high level goals would be, of course, to make good grades this semester and generally do well in school. I would also like to make friends in the computer science field. For next summer, I hope to land an internship that will hopefully lead to a full-time job in the future.

Although this probably isn't very cool, I did visit Carolina Beach during the summer, and I enjoyed it very much!

fields.title: Let's get rolling!
fields.post:
Yesterday when I was talking with a friend a mine about future plans, I realized that this semester is indeed very important for me. Not only am I graduating in December 2012, but also appearing for GRE in late September, applying for Fellowship in November, applying for Graduate School at NC State for Networking and also taking a Cool Senior Design Project with Cisco!! That's a lot of things for one person in one semester - Don't you think the same!! Well, if everything goes according to the planned schedule(which it rarely does!!) than it should be pretty smooth! I am really excited to graduate this semester and go to the next level of Education which is Graduate School, possibly into research field of Network Security! Some of my other goals this semester includes - updating my family website(originally built by my father), read CCNA text book and learn Ruby!
