I interned at Cisco this past summer and was working on a cool python based automation project. One of our group members was a Ruby expert and he showed me some cool stuff that can be done using Ruby. This inspired me to learn Ruby and do some cool stuff!!

fields.title: Oh my gosh it's full of STARS!
fields.post:
Hello STARS peoples! This is the first entry of my little corner of the STARS Student Leadership Corps here at NC State, and in order to kick things off, we were asked to write a short paragraph about who we were, what we were doing in STARS, and what we wanted to accomplish during our tenure here.

I suppose I should start off with the disclaimer that I actually keep a blog, and I refuse to accept the notion that a "short paragraph" can be considered a "blog entry". Others can if they like, but I have standards... specifically a 500 word minimum. So the first long term goal I have is to fill this blog with whimsical prose about my adventures here in the world of STARS, all the while raising the bar on "mandatory blogging". So why am I here?

So far, the project that it looks like I'll be working on is an effort to help train high school instructors to teach a new Advanced Placement course being offered called "AP Computer Science Principles". AP CS Principles is a pilot program for getting folks an early start on Computer Science, focusing less on Java syntax and much more on building a strong foundation to prepare students for Computer Science. This means rather than trying to give students a grammatical toolbox of boilerplate code snippets to use such as for loops and linked lists, we'll be fostering the development of a more cohesive foundation around basic themes in programming such as the concepts of logical thinking, abstraction, and problem reducibility. Cultivating the intuition to these high-level concepts is particularly key to helping students find their way through our discipline.

The tremendous benefit of this project goes far beyond training local instructors in how to teach this class. If we play our cards right and put enough care into our workshop materials, not only can we produce a cohort of teachers ready to lead the next generation of Computer Scientists, we can develop a workshop resource package that can be deployed by anyone, anywhere so that others can do the same! Given the state of STEM education in general, resources like these are desperately needed, and by making them publicly available, we can provide educators with a tried-and-true collection of resources so that they don't have to start from scratch. Furthermore, in the same spirit that drives the Open Source Way, as they try our package for themselves, they can address the shortcomings in our materials, fix them, and improve the resources for everyone else in the process.

This project is about service to the local community. However, the reason why I'm here... in STARS... in Grad School is to make education more accessible to people across the world. Computers and the Internet have made it possible to scale not just content, but human relationships to an unprecedented level. My research focus is in educational technology, which isn't about making computers that can teach people. It's about utilizing technology to connect people with the resources they need to learn, and part of that is making sure that teachers are well-prepared. Creating storehouses of Open Educational Resources and global networks of teachers and learners... this is what education looks like in the 21st century and beyond.

I want to be a part of that. That's why I'm here, and that can't be expressed in less than 500 words.

fields.title: Happy New Blog!
fields.post:
Hey everybody! How you doin'? This is my first STARS blog (be gentle).

     This is my second year in the Ph.D. program. So far, classes have been pretty straightforward, but research-related activities have increased exponentially. I am currently an RA for the Engage project, whose goal is to create a game to teach middle school students computer science using the CS Principles as a guide. The group has been working on designing the levels, and we're pretty close to start implementing the basic game mechanics, which should be fun! My personal interest is game-based learning, so I am also trying to get a study off the ground to observe how learning occurs naturally between two people working together on a game-based task. Hopefully, this would lead into my written qualifier adn get me one step closer to the ultimate goal of graduating.

     On the high priority list, I have my research study and the Engage project, which take up most (if not all) of my time. I am also looking forward to working on the SPARCS workshops. This is the first time we're offering them on weekdays as well as once a month on Saturdays at NC State. Aside from splitting the activities into smaller weekly chunks, I also hope to integrate some activities from Engage that will serve as pilot studies for the project itself. Smaller goals include getting through my classes in one piece and applying for fellowships (grad school ain't cheap!).

     Summer was a busy time for the Engage project, but also a good time for me to visit my friends and family in Puerto Rico. I flew back home frequently: I went for my mother and brother's birthdays, my friends' graduations, and my own birthday, which was possibly one of the best I've ever had. I really wish I could just take my friends and family with me wherever I go so I don't have to miss them :c

     Anyway, I should probably wrap this up. Hope you all have a good one!

fields.title: Current Projects
fields.post:
I'm currently working at the OSCAR lab where we are developing a analytic engine for data mining and analysis.  Something very interesting and new to me is the chemistry involved in the analysis of water.  I have been studying the Nernst Equation as well as other chemical dosing equations that are designed for using ORP and PH to create dynamic dosing of water.  
Away from school I spent time this summer in western NC cycling.  I had the chance to bike through Blowing Rock and around Boone as well as Asheville.  I also built a new bike that I am very excited about and have been riding for the last month.

fields.title: Online Presentation Tool
fields.post:
Presentation is somehow always associated with "Microsoft Power-point" and vice versa. Recently I saw this new tool used by a student in one of my classes for creating a "zooming" presentation. Its a great innovative tool allowing user to be as creative as he/she can. Its called "Prezi".  Here is the link to the website : http://prezi.com/
Also, registering with school email address gives FREE access to an  otherwise $59/year subscription which has more features than the free version. Go ahead and try out this new tool for your next presentation in class or at work.

fields.title: Online tools
fields.post:
There are quite a few online tools I use on an almost daily basis, a few of my favorites are:

Dropbox: Point dropbox at a folder, and it is instantly synced to the cloud and any other machine you have dropbox installed on. Just a fantastic product with tons of uses, especially for sharing documents and managing group projects.

Mendeley: Indispensable if you write research papers. Stores/syncs all your sources and allows for easy citing and bibliography generation.

Mint: Great for managing multiple bank accounts/credit cards/loans/investments/etc.

Hipmunk/Kayak: Great sites for finding cheap flights/cars/hotels

Zillow: Great tool for real estate searching

fields.title: Online Tools
fields.post: One collection of my favorite online tools is hosted at http://www.falstad.com/mathphysics.html. This site contains many, many, many Java applets to visualizing various physics and engineering concepts. My personal favorite is http://www.falstad.com/circuit/, which is an analog circuit simulator. This simulator has been used in the SPARCS@CCMMS digital logic session.

fields.title: Favorite Web Tools
fields.post:
I love web tools. There are so many great ones and I love having resources online rather than having to install something everytime I want to try something out.

For academic purposes, I have to say my favorite webtool is Google Forms. It is so easy to put together a little webform and get data in a nice, easy to use spreadsheet. I use it with CSC116 students all the time - to get feedback on my teaching, what's confusing, lecture topics they like, etc.

As far as personal tools just for fun. I love Houzz. Its a home decor/design site that lets you scroll through tons of photos of houses and designs and save your favorites to idea books. It recommends photos based on what you've saved. It also has a tagging feature where you can tag where different items are purchased, or what color/brand paint is on the walls. So much fun!

fields.title: Wordles and sketches
fields.post:
Here's a neat little tool I came across today: Wordle. You can create your own word-clouds by simply pasting a bunch of text into a box, or even better, giving it a URL that has a feed associated with it. A wordle of recent STARS blog entries, neat and styled:

Other online resources that I've found very useful (and fun) include an image editor that can do animated GIFs, sketching tools like this, a function plotter, etc. Have you come across any such interesting tools on the internet? What would be your dream tool, and what do you think it would take to create it?

fields.title: Patent Wars
fields.post: I believe that in today's digital age, a sense of entitlement is needed to protect your ideas and inventions. However, the recent trend to sue competitors over claims that they stole intellectual property has halted innovation. As it relates to software, tech companies should focus on selling the rights to use their software systems to competitors if it is an open standard. By bottle-necking certain solutions, you are creating a closed system that otherwise cannot naturally evolve. Companies have to remember that being first does not necessarily mean that your the best and if your in the business for the right reason then opening your portfolio will only create better products and services for customers. On the other hand, I will say that the intersection between software and hardware is crucial to great product experience and anything out of that realm could destroy the true essence of the original idea. In these instances, a collection of patents is necessary to stop competitors from potentially misusing or misinterpreting ideas.

fields.title: The confusion that is the patent system
fields.post: So I believe that very few people would agree that the current patent system is working and good for development. The few that might are the big corporations who currently hold a lot of patents and the money to "defend" them. While I personally believe that open source is the way to go, I understand that from a commercial standpoint, it isn't terribly attractive. I understand that the person that created/designed/invented the new technology deserves the credit for it. However, our patent system is a mess. The patent system that is currently in place was originally created for physical IRL inventions and ideas. That is where the confusion arises when the same patents are applied to virtual inventions and ideas; it just doesn't work well. The entire patent system could use an overhaul to address the issues being exploited and to attempt to join the modern era. If not the entire system, at least the patents with regard to code and other virtual inventions should be redone to account for the changing times, patent trolls and absurd patents. Only when the research front is liberated, will technology be able to move forward uninhibited.

fields.title: Invention as a Money-Making Venture
fields.post: I essentially agree with what a few others have already said thus far about patents and infringement of those rights affecting the nature (or prevalence) of innovation. The purported concern by some investors in novel technology is that people with new ideas will hesitate when attempting to launch their products due to these difficulties. The underlying assumption is, however, that those innovators only produce their inventions when it is economically viable to do so. What of the great people who discover and create without regard to monetary profit? Certainly I would agree with the stated concerns: when monetary benefit remains a motivator for some would-be inventors, patents are essential to protecting their investments. However, in the long run, I don't think patents nor the lack thereof will prove significant in the way forward for technology. Open-source, other countries, a myriad of options exist for those who enjoy tinkering with new things.

fields.title: Patents, copyrights, innovation and open-source: What is the way forward for technology?
fields.post:
Patents are a tricky subject right now and I do not think there is one clear cut answer. There needs to be a middle ground between patents and open-source, because there is a need for both. Patents are important in keeping businesses interested in spending money on research. Big businesses are not going to spend the money needed to make the latest and greatest if they are not going to get any profit off of it. At the same time though there is a place for open source code. Open source is great so that everyone can keep improving the technology that we have now.

Since there is a need for patents and open source code we need to find some middle ground between the two. I am not sure what this would look like, I just know that we cannot have everything patented or everything open source.

fields.title: Patents, copyrights, innovation and open-source: What is the way forward for technology?
fields.post:
The path forward for technology, specifically software is unfortunately very complicated. The patent system in its current form is obviously broken (as detailed many places including here: http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/441/when-patents-...), and is wasting billions of dollars. Large corporations are hording patents as a defense mechanism, and must waste resources defending themselves from lawsuits and acquiring patents they have no intention of developing. Startups are attacked by frivilous claims that can often be fatal to a young company.

However, there have been some recent changes that are promising for software developers. The various app stores on mobile devices have finally provided a marketplace for small applications to be distributed to millions of customers. By removing the hurdles of distribution(packaging, shipping, etc.), innovative software can now be sold for lower prices, greatly reducing perhaps the biggest barrier of entry in the past and hopefully encouraging innovation.

fields.title: Patents
fields.post:
Patents are a manifestation of society's attempt to curb unethical behavior. As originally conceived, patents were intended to prevent others from stealing an inventor's idea and consequently stifling innovation. As demonstrated in the recent news, patents can interfere with technological progress, however, which negatively impacts society as a whole to the benefit of the innovator.

I think that the free and open-source software (FOSS) movement has developed an effective paradigm for advancing technology. FOSS is not developed for direct monetary gain, which renders patents regarding FOSS completely unnecessary. Licenses such as the GPL protect FOSS against theft of source code (and therefore ideas to some extent) and can be leveraged to support further development when theft does occur. The idea of free and open-source technology has spread from software to electronics and other fields and may revolutionize much of the technology industry.

fields.title: Patents, copyrights, innovation and open-source: What is the way forward for technology?
fields.post:
I'd say that patents and copyrights are a motivator for companies to invest in research and innovation because the patents and copyrights guarantee earnings for that company for a period of time. However, patents and copyrights prevent other companies to take advantage of those innovations, and to take the technology further.

In my opinion, patents and copyrights can help companies to invest more in research that will deliver something good for technology, but the patent should not last for a long period of time so that other companies can take advantage of that innovation. Of course, having everything on open-source will facilitate other companies to take advantage of the innovation, but it could prevent companies to invest on developing them. There should be a balance between the number of years that a company can have a patent or a copyright, so they can get a return on the investment, but not affect other users with having a monopoly of the product or the technology being developed.

fields.title: Say yes to patents ??
fields.post:
It is kind of a tough question, as we are all seeing the number of lawsuits that are being filed these days over patents.In last 2-4 months Samsung and Apple (2 big giants of mobile industry), are like waging a war over these patent issues.

Apple has maintained its lead in mobile industry for last few years,Android mobiles are becoming famous in the recent times,Apple is using patent as a weapon to sue its rivals.Hence it is an interesting point to think what to keep as open source and what to be patented.By seeing the recent times,it appears that patents are being a hindrance in the development of any technology.But i feel patents are necessary,but one should not misuse them.

fields.title: Individual or Collective?
fields.post:
"Patents, copyrights, innovation and open-source: What is the way forward for technology?"

Wow, what a tricky question. I know this is an issue that a lot of people have very strong opinions about (in every camp) but its one I just can't seem to make up my mind on. In many ways the future is pushing towards a shared knowledge - where an individual contribution is not so important but what matters is the outcome of the collective. However, our (Western) society is still based on individual accomplishments and contributions. It seems like the issue arises when these two meet.

In the US we reward people for their individual success (or the success of their ideas). Under this scheme we have to protect individuals and their contributions, so it seems we definitely need patents and copyrights. I hate getting to far into politics here, but it seems like if we were further towards the socialist end of things and beyond that individual contributions ought not matter so much and that we could get rid of things like patents and copyrights in favor of encouraging collaboration and intellectual curiosity.

I have no idea what the solution is to this - I only see the problem. And I imagine it could continue to get worse as time goes on and collaboration and openness become even more the way of life.

fields.title: Patents or No Patents?
fields.post:
The recent examples of repeated and ugly patent wars have kept us wondering - are patents a good thing or are they a waste of everybody's time and a hindrance to innovation itself? To draw an exaggerated analogy to the patent wars, let me present a scenario. I decide to patent 'breathing' one fine day. After about six months of running back and forth, the patent miraculously goes through. What would the rest of the human population now do? Do they stop breathing, or do I start suing them for it?

Although this is an exaggeration, it isn't far from the truth. If you look at simple things like the scroll bar in iPhones - there are patents behind those. And guess what, smart phones from other manufacturers (Samsung, Motorola to name a few) can't use it, because it is 'protected'. I definitely think that this is wasteful. If someone (anyone) spent time, energy and money developing a technology, why would the rest of the world not be able to use it? After all, don't we want to build the best products in the world? How can we do that unless we join hands to share each little technology that we develop?

In my opinion, we do need patents to protect intellectual property. However, there needs to be rules on what can be patented. There should be some sort of standards association (like the IEEE) that pre-decides what can be patented. For example, one should not be allowed to patent 'breathing'. How can such an organization pre-decide what can be patented? Well, I'm not the expert here! I'm sure there's lots of people out there who know better, and can make it work!

fields.title: What would be your primary form of interaction with the digital world 5 years from now?
fields.post: The digital world is continually evolving; however, I don't see any terribly dramatic changes within the next five years in the way we interact with the digital world. I believe that we will see dramatic increases in brain computer interfaces (BCIs), but once again, I don't think they will be mainstream within 5 years sadly. My primary interaction with the digital world in 5 years will probably be an improved form of motion detection coupled with a projector with most of your traditional computer out of sight. Already fighter pilots are able to lock onto targets using only their eyes; I believe this is sufficient to control most of my day to day functions in the digital world. Worst case if something is not able to convert to a purely motion based interaction, a touchscreen can be used. This is definitely a developing field and will continue to develop rapidly within the upcoming years. I can not wait until we reach the point of full immersion into the digital world.

fields.title: Primary Form of Communication
fields.post: I believe that my primary form of communication in 5 years will still be my iPhone as I have fallen madly in love with it :). I don't necessarily think it will be the same iPhone I currently have but I know that Apple probably has many more tricks up its sleeves and it is going to continue to be the future of our technology needs. It's crazy to me how only a few years ago everyone was pretty much like Apple who? but now all of a sudden everywhere I go I see iPhones, iPods, iPads, and iMacs. Siri, the new tool Apple just introduced, is only the beginning for Apple I believe the next step I think will be a personal assistant that your are able to have full blown conversations with that will help its customers get through day to day (kind of like the Watson idea that IBM has come up with). The possibilities of new technology is endless and I can honestly say within the next 5 years I will be keeping informed and updated with the newest forms of communication.

fields.title: Living in a DIGITAL world
fields.post: The rate at which technology changes makes it extremely difficult to predict the future these days. I remember only 5 years ago when having a touchscreen device was rare and in some cases even strange. Back then, you were cool if you had a smartphone and even cooler if you had a Blackberry Curve. Since then, technology has changed drastically as the majority of my peers and family has at least one touchscreen device (i.e iPhone, Droid, etc.) My guess is that 5 years from now, the trend will be gesture and voice activated devices that rival Siri on the iPhone 4S as well as consumer natural language commands on the IBM Watson. The world is really pushing for multiple inputs as seen in the gaming industry and that will only lead to super duper smartphones where your hand is the actual device. While that may be 10-15 years away, technology will continue to innovate faster than humans can adapt.

fields.title: After Five Years..
fields.post:
Recently I I came across a very interesting article in Bloomberg Magazine which was about John Rogers(winner of MacArthur Genius Award) - person who came out with a great invention of stretchable and bendable micro-processors which are so thin that they look like electronic skin. I thought that when this innovation will be combined with technology advancements in computers .... we will have some surprising products. For e.g, five years from now, this bendable micro-processors might be used to create a small device which can create a computer image almost anywhere you want. It will use the surface(e.g wall, table) as its screen and also create a key board along with it. So, whenever you want to access your computer/laptop just take this small device from your pocket and use a nearby surface to bring the image on it.
Following link contains a picture of Pranav Mistry (a PhD student at MIT) working on a similar project.
http://www.w3.org/blog/MWITeam/category-63

fields.title: Interacting with the digital world
fields.post:
I think 5 years from now, we'll be communicating with the digital world through... voice & gestures. Sorry if that was a let-down. Yes, we already have pretty good speech recognizers as well as text-to-speech. With Siri on iPhone4, we even have a voice activated 'personal assistant'. But I still think that the primary form of interaction would be voice in five years. With Siri, and other similar software, we're just starting to explore commercial voice activated software on a large scale. Sure, there's been research in this area for many years now, but latest smart phones are the first commercial products to make these features available to everyone.

In spite of that, there's lots of scope for improvement and making these 'agents' even more intelligent and addressing accessibility issues. And I suspect, that that's going to take the next 5 years. So we'll probably have very sophisticated agents that function very well with voice and maybe even gestures (like the Kinect)? Maybe we'll see an integrated software that can understand voice, gestures, touch etc. I also hope we see some usage of 'smell', to give us the 4D effect!

Of course if you asked me how I'd communicate with the digital world in about 35 years, I'd say with my 'mind'! We probably won't even have to say or use gestures then, just think of it and your device would know it :) While we're at it, I hope that we have a common database of human knowledge then - just like Issac Asimov's people from Gaya. That would eliminate the need for classes - simply access the information from the comprehensive database!

fields.title: Five years from now - devices that understand the 'when' and 'where' of 'what' we need
fields.post:
I see myself relying on devices with smaller and smaller screens, and more multimedia content as opposed to plain text. The limit seems to be something with no screen at all, and perhaps a lot of smart ways of communicating - gestures, voice commands, etc. But the most important change I see coming about is that of devices becoming more context-aware. Morning news, calendar and appointments, store coupons, etc. - all these scenarios/applications present opportunities in which the knowledge of the 'when' and 'where' can be exploited effectively to determine 'what' we need.

Physically, I see the smart phone as a survivor among devices. Something that can fit in the palm of your hand, or your pocket, can keep track of where you are and serve content accordingly, is perhaps the best bet for people during the work day. At home, a more centralized system is what I envision - unified as well as modular solutions providing entertainment, gaming, full access to the internet and seamless integration with other devices such as smart phones. There are still some barriers towards making all this a reality (things are still more segregated than they should be, in my opinion), but it should become a norm soon.

Five years from now, I would want to spend a lot more time 'doing' things, and less time instructing my device(s) to get my point across. In fact, I see systems that will be one step ahead, that can figure out what I will need next from my current context and observing my past behavior. For instance, if I'm at the theater, tapping the phone (even while in my pocket) should execute the most likely action - make it silent. When I'm sitting on a bus, it might be easier to read news as text articles, and while in the kitchen, audio and video clips would be more suitable. Routine activities, such as taking a bus to campus every morning can be enhanced, by say, automatically pulling up the schedule and/or live map just in time so I can make it.

Flexible screens are one technology I'm looking forward to, and more of Kinect-style hands-free interaction. An integrated and augmented experience of reality is also gradually building up. We could start interacting with real objects and places in all new and virtual ways. It's just that we'll need to be careful not to let ourselves get carried away. Talking to people in person, pen-on-paper scribbles, physical activity - all this should remain a natural part of our lives.

fields.title: In Five Years
fields.post:
I find it hard to believe that my primary computer interface device will be anything other than a keyboard and mouse. Although natural interaction or natural language for human-computer interfaces present the possibility of high-throughput communication, I believe that precision is lost in the computer's interpretation of the "natural" symbol that the user supplies. The keyboard and mouse are unambiguous; when the user presses a key, there is no ambiguity as to the nature of the input. Systems that extrapolate from language or gestures must utilize some tremendous inferences to understand the user's input or restrict the space of inputs to those easily understood at the loss of flexibility. Such reasoning is bound to introduce errors.

I can envision new input methods for specific applications, however. For data visualization, hand and eye tracking or augmented reality systems could revolutionize how three-dimensional data is explored. Some researchers have already started using the Kinect to implement such techniques for browsing medical data. Instead of passwords for authentication, I can envision the use of nuanced gestures that allow the use to rely upon their motor memory skills rather than recalling a (hopefully) random sequence of characters. But for programming and low-level configuration, the very tasks required to implement the aforementioned technologies, the keyboard and mouse will prevail as unambiguous and efficient input devices... at least for the time being.

fields.title: "What would be your primary form of interaction with the digital world 5 years from now?"
fields.post:
Technology changes all the time. As I was thinking about what the technology will be like 5 years from now I started by thinking about the changes in technology in the past 5 years. 5 years ago I was a freshman in high school where I did not have a cell phone and shared a desktop with everyone else in my family. I wanted a laptop of my own but at that time laptops were still very expensive. Now I have a laptop and a smart phone of my own. Many people have tablets also for when they do not feel like carrying around a laptop. Everything has changed so much and because of that I honestly have no clue what the digital world will look like 5 years from now.

My best guess of what technology will be like in 5 years is more portable. I think smart phones will keep becoming more useful and better for day to day usage. In 5 years I do not see my interaction with the digital world changing too much. I think I will still use it for school or work but also for fun and staying in touch with my friends. I think in 5 years it will be easier to communicate with others 24/7 and everything will become even smaller and faster than it is now.

fields.title: Physical and Visual Interfaces
fields.post: I believe our society adopts and pushes for new technology to a great extent based on what is already made popular by the culture. Part of the drive behind great innovation is the passion to accomplish what has so far been seen in our imaginations (or Hollywood, more realistically). Thus it makes sense to me that our primary form of digital interaction will evolve to 2D/3D manipulative interfaces in the next 5 years. Already touchscreens are growing in popularity, as evidenced by the rise of smartphones and tablet PCs, and now companies like Microsoft are even designing mechanisms to turn any flat surface into a touchscreen computer. This, coupled with rising holographic technologies, could easily rise into digital walls as seen on the Minority Report and even 3D breakdowns of physical systems as seen on Iron Man. Personally, I would love for this to be the case. I can just imagine writing code for the next control system in my physics lab to be much more interactive and intuitive. Plus then I can have a computer on my wall instead of sitting heavily on my lap or dealing with a keyboard awkwardly in front of me on a desk.

fields.title: "What would be your primary form of interaction with the digital world 5 years from now?"
fields.post:
A very interesting question, and one that I can almost guarantee I will get wrong but here goes nothing.

First lets start with some things I think will still be the same. I think my primary uses for the computer will stay basically the same; a combination of work (writing/coding) and leisure (video games/surfing the web). I also think that the physical interactions will remain mostly the same, i.e. touch screens and mouse/keyboard. While technologies like the Kinect/3D displays/etc. are promising, I just can't see them becoming overly useful in the next 5 years.

In the next 5 years I do expect the interactions to consolidate more and more in the cloud and on mobile platforms. It is not hard to imagine being able to control your lights/appliances/heating and cooling/tv all from a smart phone or tablet. It is also interesting to think of the many things we will be able to accomplish with this 24/7 connectivity.

And as general and vague as many of these claims are, I also predict I can look back on this in 5 years on my motion controlled 3D headset and laugh about how wrong I was.

fields.title: "What would be your primary form of interaction with the digital world 5 years from now?"
fields.post:
In the present day, there are a lot many devices with which we can interact and access the digital world, but its kind of hard what would be the primary form.In the present day, the most advanced technology is iPhone 4S Siri, an artificial intelligence model and Samsung galaxy S2 are some of the prominent ones, which are providing a set of brand new features that mobile industry has never seen.Its like that these mobile devices are your virtual friends, you can talk to them and they will get things done for you.(pretty cool huh!!)

I mentioned that it is kind of hard to guess what will be the primary form of interaction in 5 years because, technology is getting updated twice a year, in a few months Samsung is releasing S3 and iphone5 is also coming out. You can imagine the pace at which technology is progressing.Some of the other forms available now a days are tablets(ipads and samsung galaxy tabs) which offer certain neat features too.

I feel that in 5 yearrs there would come a single device with which we can do everything.All in one kind of thing.

fields.title: The digital world 5 years from now?
fields.post:
It's hard to imagine how the digital world would be 5 years from now. My guess is that computers and tablets will replace TVs, and that our cellphones will be so powerful that people will be doing many tasks on them, like creating documents or doing homework.

I'd say that our cellphones will project an image on any surface, and we will able to perform any task on that surface using our fingers. In that way, if we need to use a bigger screen than our cellphones, it would be easier for us to do it.

I also think that computer desktops will also disappear completely, and they will be replaced by laptops.

That's my guess!

fields.title: Five years from now...
fields.post:
Hmm....I do not own an iPhone or an iPad...for that matter not even an iPod. But when I look back, the biggest and most positive change in the last 5 years has been social networking sites and the fact that these new iGadgets can be used to instantly upload photos, videos, and even your emotions :P It is amazing to see how iPhones have replaced baby toys. I recently visited a family friend and her 1 year old was given an iPhone to grab his attention while she fed him lunch. On a more serious note, the new gadgets are getting more and more intuitive to operate...my 2 year old niece can figure out how to get to the games on her dad's iPhone much faster than my mom took to figure out how to connect to the internet!

Perhaps in the next 5 years, we will see more multi-purpose and affordable gadgets replacing the good-at-one-task gadgets like cameras and GPS. We will probably also have add-on apps available to mimic Siri on laptops? So if all systems at your home like the washing machine / dish washer could "talk" to you.....you could probably instruct them remotely over a call :P Well....that would add more "contacts" on your list..lol. Then, I guess very soon we will need voice authentication...since these machines should only listen to their owners? :P Am also interested to see how far we go with the Spoken Web that IBM research is working on.

fields.title: Future of Computing
fields.post:
"What would be your primary form of interaction with the digital world 5 years from now?"

Wow, what a tricky question. I guess I should start by reflecting on how my interaction with the digital work has changed over the last five years. I would say that the biggest change over the past five years for myself is that my computer use has transitioned from being primarily for school and work and started to be much more a part of my everyday life. This has a lot to do with the mobile revolution. I have an iPhone so I've gotten used to having the internet everywhere. I'm used to never being lost, never having questions that can't be answered, etc.

So how can this change over the next five years? I guess I see it becoming more and more pervasive. And the types of questions being more and more personal. For instance, I recently saw work at a conference where you can monitor your brain waves with a device attached to your cell phone. And another where you can monitor your heart rate and galvanic skin response with a little bracelet. They've been using this technology to help people realize the types of things that stress them out or have a calming response. It's mostly been used for people with particular deficiencies in this area but its not unreasonable to foresee the general population taking advantage of it. I think I see the future of tech as making us more and more self-aware and better able to manage our lives.

fields.title: First Computer Memories
fields.post:
My first interactions with computers were probably text based games that were available on my Mom's Rainbow terminal she had in the house as a kid. As I grew older, most of interactions on the computer were various types of games of various qualities and types, and eventually writing papers for class in high school. Even in college the majority of my computer usage was mainly school work oriented (programming, circuit design, etc.) and gaming.

In the 5 years or so since I graduated, it is amazing how much more computers have ingrained themselves into my everyday life. While email/instant messaging are relatively old technologies, it is amazing how vital they are to many of my friends from college and former co-workers. On top of that, everyday tasks like directions, finding recipes, calendars, remembering birthdays, etc are now integrally tied to computers and web services.

It is amazing to think of the changes that have occurred in my brief lifetime, and also interesting to wonder what life will be like 20+ years from now.

fields.title: My First Computer
fields.post:
My first memory of a computer is when my father (randomly, as it seemed to me) asked me to come into his home office one morning. He introduced me to an Apple Power Macintosh which he had configured with the learning games and puzzles that I now fondly remember. I recall solving word and math puzzles, escaping mazes, and primitive virtual landscapes filled with villains poised to attack with riddles. Computers were essentially learning and teaching devices. I eventually inherited these early computer after time. Curiously, I still have the complete set of 3.5" floppy disks to install a Power Macintosh-compatible version of Microsoft Office.

Eventually I came across computer programming, probably again influenced by my father. I quickly devoured all the programming books at my school's library. I started primarily with Excel macros, moving on to Visual Basic 6 applications and TI-83+ calculator programs in middle school. The TI-83 plus became my primary platform for TI-BASIC in middle school and z80 assembly in high school until my TI-83+ suffered an untimely death. Computers, including my calculator, became tools. I quickly realized the potential of TI-83+ programs to expedite my homework and using software to automate mundane tasks.

Nowadays, computers are integral aspects of my education and work. My interests lie in robotics, and without computers and tiny microcontrollers, robotics is reduced to relying upon the massive ladder-logic relay boxes that predated microcomputers.

fields.title: Expensive Home Computing
fields.post:
About two years ago, my parents were cleaning out some old boxes full of papers and records from our move back home after spending some time abroad in France. My dad found his receipt for the home computer he bought for our time there, and thought if sufficiently amusing to show me. This terrible old piece of hardware (running Windows 95! Oh yeah) that is worth absolutely nothing now, was bought for $2K only a decade or so ago. It is certainly evidence of the quick-natured way of things springing up in many areas of the world today.
In France, that computer was our link back to family and friends in the States. I didn't really use it at all, besides the odd educational computer game or two, but to my mother it was great comfort to be able to still communicate fairly easily with home while we were strangers in another land. My first real use of it came after the move back home, when I was about 10 years old, and that mainly for the Internet. School projects were indeed much easier with the easier access to information, the pursuit of which became my new goal when confronted with the annoying parental filters on the web. It was great fun to figure out how to remove the controls without the program alerting my parents, and when I did succeed I could finally write that paper on Babe Ruth ("babe" being a term of concern, apparently). This precipitated my involvement with investigation of the security holes inherent in any system, particularly the new electronic/computing ones.

fields.title: Window into a whole other world
fields.post:
The first time I saw computers was probably in some bank branches during my elementary school years. Back then I could only see the back side of white CRT monitors, slightly soiled by dust and grime, and wondered what the clerks were looking at so intently. It still amuses me to look at people staring into a computer screen - their eyes focused on this small window into a whole other world, their faces often lacking any expression or enthusiasm. I probably look the same most of my waking hours!

I got the chance to start using computers in late elementary school, and began to realize why this other world was so fascinating. Even in the 80 columns by 25 rows plain-text displays in use at that time, you had infinite possibilities (think ASCII art). Being able to type my own name and see it in the bold white print-like typeface was quite amusing. Sending messages over the local network during class was priceless! We had only heard of something called email back then, which offices apparently used to exchange memos and reports. Meh.

Computers used to be very predictable and reliable machines. Over the years, I've noticed how computers have become more complex in functionality and how they've lost some of that predictability. I've always thought of computers to have a personality, things that they like people to do with them and things they don't (like reading floppies). Early computers were still fairly docile; now they seem to have a mind of their own. In many different ways, computers have now become more closely intertwined with reality, and the "whole other world" that seemed so mysterious before, now seems to be like the real world itself seen through a kaleidoscope. Fascinating, nonetheless.

fields.title: My Beige Box
fields.post:
I remember seeing beige boxes all around my elementary school library in Kindergarden. I never knew what they did or how to use them because they sat idle for the majority of the day. That all changed, however, when I went to the local Rooms-To-Go Furniture Store and the attendant was typing away at a black screen with green font. I immediately became intrigued and begged my mother to go back to the furniture store every week. The instant feedback on the monitor from hitting hitting a key and seeing your result was so cool. A few years later I was introduced to the original iMac with its assortment of colors. I would always swing by the computer lab with my hall pass to see if any of the computers were available and work on my type writing skills. It's fair to say that I thought computers were just a tool to learn how to type, in case you had crappy penmanship.

After years of mastering my typing skills, browsing the web, playing computer games, and now programming, I now view computers as the single most innovative device known to man. It has evolved into a lifestyle that some can't live without as well as a means to communicate over long distances in times of war. Computers are continuing to get smaller, faster, as the latest movement belongs to mobile computing. I am excited about where computing is going because aside from completing complex calculations, computers has the ability to change the way we interact with them i.e iPhone 4S Siri and IBM Watson.

fields.title: Where in the World are Computers?
fields.post:
I cannot fully remember the first time I that I was introduced to a computer, however my first memories of a computer involved use of one at my elementary school. My first fond memories of using a computer were playing Where in the World are Carmen Sandiago and JumpStart. I remember in some of my classes I could just sit on the computer and play those two games ALL DAY. Those were the highlights of my years in elementary school especially when I knew that I was close to beating both of the games. Not only were these games fun to conquer, but little did I know they were very influential in my development of knowledge and education. To me these games were just something fun to do in order to avoid homework as well as boring lectures from my teachers. I remember begging my parents to by me the extensions to these games the older that I got for birthdays and Christmas. Right then and there I should of known that I had a knack for using computers and it was something that I was going to enjoy for the rest of my life. Who would of known that I was going to end up studying Computer Engineering?

Back then I thought of computers as a really cool toy that got me away from the boring life of school work. I use to think computers were so smart, but never really considered that more might be in store for this technology over time. I did not really find myself analyzing technology at such a young age however now that I have grown up I cannot even fathom the possibilities for the future of computers especially when my children begin using them. As a computer engineer I have been exposed to the ancient and "prehistoric" concepts of how a computer is built and the history of computers. I have learned how something that was once so huge has now been compacted into smaller and smaller designs that not only work more efficiently but also have a more aesthetic like qualities that appeal to the eyes of the customers. Honestly now I have no idea where the technology of computers will go from here and it actually scares me to know that the evolvement of this technology is really far from over. Although the evolution of computers does worry me I also am very excited to experience and see what is in store for our us in the world of computers!

fields.title: What is Oregon Trail?
fields.post:
I dont exactly remember the first time I used a computer, but I do remember the old Apple computers in my 4th grade classroom. Programs were started from 5 inch floppies. The entire class shared two computers. One day, our teacher gave us two floppy disks with Oregon Trail on them. We had no idea what Oregon Trail was, but we popped them in, started up the program, and played our first computer game. It was one of the most fun experiences at that time.

I was also exposed to computers at home. My dad loved tinkering with computers and I would constantly pester him with questions (What is the C: for? What is a hard drive? What is memory?). To me, computers were like big, expensive, complicated, confusing, calculators. Over time, though, as I kept up interest, I realized that they were not so confusing and they were not just calculators (but they were still expensive).

Looking back, I realize how silly I was, but also how much of an impact that computers had on me. It would be very different if I grew up in this decade, where computer technology is so pervasive in society. Even though Ive gotten used to the technology we have, Im still surprised and amazed by new and emerging technologies. I cant wait to see what computers will be able to do 5-10 years from now.

fields.title: From Logo to Linkedin
fields.post:
The first time I used a computer was way back when I was in second grade. They used to teach us 'Logo' back then. Logo is a programming language which is an adaptation of Lisp - we used to draw figures with it by moving the 'turtle' around the screen. It used to be so much fun! Of course we used to operate from the DOS prompt - there was no GUI yet! The first actual programming language that I learned, where you could do more than drawing figures, was 'BASIC'. If you haven't heard of BASIC and Logo, you were probably born in the 90s (Gosh! That makes me feel old!). The first graphical OS that I used was Windows 3.1. Home PCs weren't readily available in India back then. My dad got one from the US and it used to be a thing of wonder! I remember that they had something called a 'Kid's Space' in Windows 3.1, and that used to be my secret corner in the computer!

So anyway, when I got introduced to BASIC, I slowly realized the power of programming. I remember that I would feel awed at being able to make the computer print stuff with a set of commands. I started using programming to solve puzzles, do math etc. Around that time, I also got my first email address (which I still use actually!), and started emailing people. Suddenly being able to communicate with people around the world became the coolest thing ever. Who knew that communication would reach its current level with facebook, twitter and linkedin!

The computer industry has changed drastically in the past couple of decades - and it changed right in front of my eyes. Today computers are a way of life. If an earthquake happens, people will probably post a facebook update before leaving the house! Back when I started using computers, they were 'box-like' things which you used to send emails or write programs in. Over the years, computers have changed both in their shape & size, as well as their usage, not to mention that they are way faster and cheaper than they were before.

The cool thing is that 'computers' are still changing everyday. Even five years back we didn't have smart phones and tablets. I feel grateful to be part of this community that innovates and brings new things to the world literally everyday! I also feel very proud to be part of a generation that saw innovators like Steve Jobs and Dennis Ritchie. As a networking researcher, I feel excited at the prospect of being able to contribute to improve the Internet so we have even better connectivity in the coming years. Here's to hoping that we work hard, innovate and take the computer industry to the next level whatever that may be!

fields.title: Computers and Childhood
fields.post:
"When was the first time you used a computer? What did you think of computers then, and how has your outlook evolved over time?"

I really can't remember the first time I used a computer. I do remember the types of things I did on them though. First I used them for schoolwork, but I wasn't a very good typer. I would write my essays on paper and have my mom type them for me because she was so much faster. Then around 3rd grade in school we started using the software that I think defines a lot of our childhood computer uses - Mavis Beacon! My typing quickly improved and I started using the computer to put out the neighborhood newsletter that my friends and I thought was so clever. I remember reporting on the release of the first Lion King in theaters :)

Soon I stopped using them just for schoolwork and started playing games. My favorite games were Lemmings and Jill of the Jungle. I could never remember how to start the games and would have to go ask my dad. Eventually he gave me a post-it with the instructions. I thought it was so weird.... "cd c:\random\stuff\i\dont\remember..." It made no sense at the time, but makes me laugh in retrospect.

I guess that kind of defines my childhood perception of computers. They were these cool, almost magic boxes that had a lot of power that I didn't know how to access. My parents were the computer gurus, both being computer scientists themselves. I remember finding my first programming class in high school so exciting. The first time I ran hello world, I felt like I suddenly had access to the magic! Almost like I imagine Harry Potter would feel on his first day at Hogwarts. Now I take this power for granted, but I am continuously amazed by the new things computers are able to do and how technology just keeps pushing forward.

fields.title: Wow..I can send messages using this machine!
fields.post: It was year 2000 and I was preparing for my first USA trip. I was in 5 th grade in India and it was at this time I was amazed to see my dad sending out short messages(email) and chatting (using yahoo id) to my relatives in USA informing them about our trip. This was the time I got my first email address which I am still using. Soon I discovered amazing things possible with a yahoo id like voice and text chatting. I spent lot of time discovering answers to my own questions like - "How can my relatives receive messages so fast though we are separated by 8301 miles?" . My basic interest in computers and later in programming grew from this incident and I enjoyed discovering more and more information about evolution of computers and internet.

fields.title: First time using a computer
fields.post:
I do not remember at time when I did not use a computer, since I learned to use a computer before I learned to read. My father is also has a degree in computer science and works with computers so I always had a personal computer around me. According to my parents I was two years old when my dad taught me how to use a computer since I had been begging him for a while. I learned how to use a computer before my sister, who is three years older than me, since she did not have any interest in learning how to use the mouse.
Back when I was little computers were just something fun to play games on, I did not have any idea about programming. It was not until I took a java class in high school that I started to enjoy programming. Now I see computers as something that I love to learn more about. I enjoy learning as much as I possibly can about computers so that I can understand more about computers.

fields.title: When was the first time you used a computer? What did you think of computers then, and how has your outlook evolved over time?
fields.post: Hmm...I guess I was in my 1st grade, studying at Mangalore, India. At that time, my parents worked at a bank and did most of their clerical work using type-writers. Only the managers and specially trained staff had access to computers. Around 1989-1990 is when my dad bought a new computer (desktop of course) and of all his friends, we were the only ones who owned a computer. Often, his friends would come to use it and get printouts (yes, we even got a printer!). They would also get floppy disks with new games :) , which they showed me how to play (eventually I had to know how to work on DOS). My parents also joined me to a summer camp computer course and the main thing I remember there is playing with MS-paint. Soon after that, computers were introduced in schools and we learnt BASIC as part of curriculum. It did not seem all that hard and it was easy transition from there to C, C++ and eventually Java. Over the years, the importance of using a computer has changed from just designing a program or debugging it....now it has become a way of life....connecting with friends and family back in India, literature survey for my research, and many other things that I had never imagined :)

fields.title: "When was the first time you used a computer? What did you think of computers then, and how has your outlook evolved over time?"
fields.post:
when was the first time i used a computer, hmm lets see its some where in 1999-2000.I was studying class VII,we had some basic DOS programming class at school.I used to attend those classes because we get to play games present in the computer after the class.:P Later when I was studying class XI and my brother was doing undergraduate in computer science,so my parents bought a new computer for him.I was very excited by seeing it and was very eager to use it.I had an email account by that time though never really used it.

My brother used to be very possessive or now i can say he was being careful,he never let me near the computer not more than 30 min.In that little time i used to open my email account,do some chatting play some games.But i was never satisfied,i wanted to do more with computer.Google was the most fascinating thing for me at that time,i could find anything from it.

This strong inclination towards computers led me to choose Information Technology in my undergraduate level.I got a new laptop in my first year of undergrad and there is no looking back.Now i spend nearly 14 hours in front of it.Everything related to me is also related to computer.My outlook has evolved, on the variety of things we can do with computer, we can build websites, learn many important things,be up to date with what's happening etc.There is a fun side too, computer games :)

fields.title: My First Computer
fields.post:
"When was the first time you used a computer? What did you think of computers then, and how has your outlook evolved over time?"

I received my first computer for christmas (1981). It was a Texas Instruments TI-99/4A and came pre-installed with Basic and tennis, which is the equivalent of pong for that little guy. I was able to buy cartridges to expand the usage of my computer to play wandering games, not too much unlike pac man. The fabulous black and white 9-inch TV that I hooked my computer to kept me entranced for hours :).

What kid would not love this state-of-the-art technology at home (so tongue-n-cheek). Seriously, I fell in love with programming playing around with the Basic language available to me. Imagine my excitement when my TV screen blinked "Hello Tonya"! I am not sure if my mom or my grandparents knew what they were creating when they bought me this wonderful device, but from Basic, I set off to find anything "computer-related". This curiosity led me to Clemson in the summers for 3 years, where I learned SAS, FORTRAN, and more Basic. My last summer was spent at NCSU in the Site program, which solidified my interest in computer science (not a part of engineering at that time) and sparked a new interest in electrical engineering.
For a piece of history: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_Instruments_TI-99/4A

I've enjoyed the ride! And I plan to keep riding. I thought computers THEN were wonderful and exciting. I cannot even express my awe of today's technology. I see nothing more than limitless opportunities.

fields.title: Teaching how to use a computer... for the first time.
fields.post:
Hello everyone!

I'm part of the USCRI and the Nursing Outreach.

On Saturday, we had our first session at the Nursing Home in Raleigh. We had 4 STARS volunteers, and 5 persons from the nursing home attending our session. The majority of the persons who attended our session, were not familiar with computers, so we had to teach them how to turn on/off a computer, how to use the mouse, and how to do click and double click.

This experience made me think about how difficult is for a person to use a computer for the first time. Kids, nowadays, are born using them, but people of advanced-age, are not familiar (and sometimes afraid) of computers. During the session on Saturday, I made sure to repeat each step several times, write down step-by-step instructions so they can practice by themselves during the week, and make sure they are not afraid of using a computer.

The first time I used a computer was in elementary school. But the experience I most remember was discovering Power Point! I remember that I was very excited with the sounds, and animations you could do to any word. The competition between classmates after that, was who would make the Power Point presentation with more animations and sounds than anyone else!

I'm very excited to be part of STARS again this semester!

-Andrea

How is your STARS project progressing?

I have begun meeting with Alok Baikadi and affirmed my duties for the remaining part of the research. I am now focusing on using language parsing to pull out dialogue from a user-created story for use with our animation scene. I am have read some material and learned the basics of what I need to accomplish while beginning to pull out dialogue from a sample .xml file containing already parsed tokens of a story.

Has STARS mentoring been helpful lately?

I discuss with Alok what's going on in my academic career during each weekly meeting. This communication allows us to keep up to date on each other. I have not had too many things requiring much mentoring but I still seek to take advantage of this opportunity.

Did you experience any memorable events recently?

I have recently been hired to work at SAS Institute. It is a paid Technical Student position which will last for a full year. I worked full time over spring break and am very impressed with the company so far. Besides this, I have been too caught up in school work to entertain myself in anything particularly memorable.

is there anything you're looking forward to in the immediate future?

I am looking forward to finishing up my part on Alok's project as well as getting to know my new coworkers at SAS. Also, I am beginning a team project in software engineering which will mimic a senior design project but on a slightly smaller scale. I am looking forward to this opportunity to succeeding in this large project as well as benefiting from all the extra credit which will be associated with it.

How do you feel about NC State and your department right now?

I feel connected to the department as I have been attending many events such as guest speakers and meeting with my professors in their office hours.

How do you feel about STARS right now?

I am very grateful for all the opportunities STARS has provided me so far in my junior year. I look forward to representing this organization in the Engineering Open House this weekend.

How is your STARS project progressing?

My STARS project is SPARCS @ CCMS. We have done two sessions so far this semester teaching the students about circuits (using an awesome java tool developed by one of our group members) and also allowing them to program in the lego mindstorms NXT software. The kids LOVED the robots, and everyone is looking forward to our next session where we are going to do some more complex activities with the robots.

In other news, we just finished up a research study at Four Oaks middle school that was really successful and I'm looking forward to examining the data from that study soon.

fields.title: STARS Reflection February 2011
fields.post:

Classes are picking up with midterms and material, but my academic goals have still been progressing well.

How is your STARS project progressing?

SPARCS is still going very well. We did our first session of Lego Mindstorms last week and the students absolutely loved it. They enjoyed learning how the robots work and were attentive throughout the learning process. Towards the end of the session, after we taught them how to use the robots and the software, the students started building their own robots. I cant wait to see what they come up with for our next session.

Has STARS mentoring been helpful lately?

I should be starting my mentoring soon.

Did you experience any memorable events recently?

Nothing recently since the last blog.

is there anything you're looking forward to in the immediate future?

How do you feel about NC State and your department right now?

I feel great about NC State and the CSC department. Both the school and department are keeping me busy with all they have to offer.

How do you feel about STARS right now?

I feel great about STARS. It has been a good semester in the program so far and I cant wait to see how it progresses for the rest of the semester and into the upcoming fall semester.

fields.title: STARS Reflection February 2011
fields.post:
How are your current academic goals developing?

Hopefully going in the right direction

How is your STARS project progressing?

We had the first USCRI session on 19th February 2011. It was a really nice start to this year since the turn-up was quite high: 16. We had varied audience and even people from Iraq, this time. And all of them expressed their willingness to come back for the next session on 26th February.

Has STARS mentoring been helpful lately?

Not Applicable

Did you experience any memorable events recently?

We were supposed to reach a bus stop to assist USCRI students with bus drive for the first day. We reached there around 9:45 AM and they were already waiting for us since half an hour and missed one bus scheduled at 9:30 AM because we were late. The next bus was scheduled for 10:30 AM and we spent those 45 minutes feeling miserable about making them wait so long. Yet those people were all smiles trying to make us feel as if nothing went wrong.

is there anything you're looking forward to in the immediate future?

The next USCRI session on 26th Feb and spring break when I am planning to visit San Diego

How do you feel about NC State and your department right now?

My department ...same as the first blog

How do you feel about STARS right now?

Same as before

I'm learning a lot about the process of developing software not only from what I'm doing, but also by observing the developers around me. It's great to be exposed to industry.

fields.title: STARS Reflection February 2011
fields.post:
How are your current academic goals developing?

My academic goals are going alright. I'm still working on my written preliminary exam. The models I've been developing have been a bit less successful than I'd hoped but I plan to keep tweaking them in hopes that I get some good results soon.

How is your STARS project progressing?

The SPARCS @ CCMMS project is going great. I'm really happy that so far this year we haven't seen the dramatic decrease in numbers as the year progresses. We've lost maybe 4 students since the first session which is not bad at all. We've got our second session tomorrow and since its LEGO Mindstorms, I bet we'll have good turn out :)

Has STARS mentoring been helpful lately?

I think mentoring has been going well. Anne and I have discussed different possible paths for graduate school based on how different schools structure their degree programs.

Did you experience any memorable events recently?

This past week I helped judge the science fair at CCMMS. I was really impressed by some of the students' creativity and projects. It was also nice to see some of our SPARCS students there. The projects were all anonymous so I can't say for certain which projects they did - but I can guess :)

is there anything you're looking forward to in the immediate future?

Today is my dad's 50th birthday so we'll be celebrating that this weekend :) Otherwise I'm just really looking forward to getting my written prelim done!

How do you feel about NC State and your department right now?

I have always loved NCSU and the CSC department. I feel well supported.

How do you feel about STARS right now?

I feel good about STARS. I think this new blogging format is going to help out a lot. It's much easier for me to put a link to this survey in my task list than try to remember when a new blog entry is due.

fields.title: STARS Reflection February 2011
fields.post:
How are your current academic goals developing?

I am making decent progress in my graduate studies. From the initial days in grad school when my focus was mostly on keeping up with course work, my current goal is to build a solid foundation for research. I received a Masters degree last spring, and I'm now looking forward to writing my PhD proposal soon.

How is your STARS project progressing?

I have mostly been involved with STARS Evaluation, which has become a regular task for me. In addition, I am also looking at promotion using video features. This semester we are planning to film several sessions, and perhaps make several short clips. Besides this, I am also tutoring for the Discrete Math course this semester.

Has STARS mentoring been helpful lately?

I have always enjoyed mentoring, but since my initial mentees graduated with flying colors, I've had no one to mentor!

Did you experience any memorable events recently?

I saw an air show in Atlanta a couple of months back - if that counts as recent. It was quite awesome.

is there anything you're looking forward to in the immediate future?

A research publication would be great! Also looking forward to Campus Movie Fest.

How do you feel about NC State and your department right now?

I am quite impressed by the diversity of courses, students and events at NC State. Our department is very research-oriented and has always been supportive of different student activities. The atmosphere on campus encourages us to explore our academic and personal interests.

How do you feel about STARS right now?

The NCSU STARS SLC has been growing phenomenally for the past few semesters, and it feels great to be a part of this. I expect to see a lot of good work coming out of STARS this semester. And I'm quite excited about us hosting the celebration in summer!

fields.title: STARS Reflection January 2011
fields.post:
How are your current academic goals developing?

My academic goals are proceeding according to plan. I am graduating this semester and will attend the NCSU graduate school for another year as part of the ABM program. I anticipate that as the end of the semester approaches, I will become increasingly embroiled in senior design and other projects.

How is your STARS project progressing?

My STARS projects are progressing well. I helped present a brand new SPARCS session on digital circuitry and logic with Anne. I think the material was well received by the students. The website team is still getting things set up for this semester.

Has STARS mentoring been helpful lately?

My STARS mentor meetings haven't started back up for this semester, so I don't have much to comment about. My mentor meetings take place during website meetings, so once the website team gets going my mentor meetings with resume.

Did you experience any memorable events recently?

I had an enjoyable time skiing over winter break in Utah. There was a fresh powder snow the day before I arrived so the skiing was quite good.

is there anything you're looking forward to in the immediate future?

I am looking forward to the start of my senior design project. My project is working with a software radio testbed to analyze potential techniques for adhoc wireless networks on vehicles. The project promises some interesting work with radio hardware and signal processing.

How do you feel about NC State and your department right now?

I feel that NCSU and my department are cooperating with my academic plans. I am quite satisfied with my adviser as well.

How do you feel about STARS right now?

I think my most valuable interaction through STARS is my SPARCS project. I think exposing CCMMS students to computer science and robotics will benefit them greatly in the future.

fields.title: STARS Reflection January 2011

Has STARS mentoring been helpful lately?

Have not participated

Visit to San Diego, Los Angeles and Santa Monica.

is there anything you're looking forward to in the immediate future?

Visit to my home country, India in the summer

How do you feel about NC State and your department right now?

NC State is a nice school to be in. ECE department is equally nice to be a part of.

How do you feel about STARS right now?

STARS is a program that let me do I like to do the most : Social Outreach. So I feel totally glad to be a part of it :)

fields.title: A Change of Routine
fields.post: So I managed to finish last semester unscathed which was a pleasant surprise. I finished the research project that Joe and I had been working on and I think it turned out well. We shall see what shall become of the research. Well, this semester, I am working as a co-op at Tekelec. I think I will thoroughly enjoy this because of the security aspect of it. Already, I have learned some of the perl that I need to know but still have a ways to go. The biggest difference, this semester, is going to work from 9 to 5 and having all the rest of the time free. I look forward to continuing the work we do in STARS especially considering it gives me something to do in my off hours. BTW Tekelec has some great coffee. That is pretty much it for now. I really appreciate the change in environment, so we will see how the rest of the semester turns out. Bye.

fields.title: STARS Reflection January 2011
fields.post:
How are your current academic goals developing?

My current academic goals are developing according to plan. I wanted to publish a few papers on my research. I also wanted to write and defend my dissertation. I intend to start writing on Feb 1st and defend my first wee of May.

How is your STARS project progressing?

We made many changes in the website last semester as part of the website team. We updated the profile pages for new and current members. We also created a Point of Contact profile for many NCSU students. This will be up in the main STARS webpage. We also added some analytics to the NCSU STARS website to monitor activity.

Has STARS mentoring been helpful lately?

I haven't had a chance to mentor anyone but the website team members so far.

Did you experience any memorable events recently?

I saw a new application called Qwiki. It is like the wolfram Alpha engine, but it actually creates a video about the topics we search.

is there anything you're looking forward to in the immediate future?

I am looking forward to graduate soon and find a research position.

How do you feel about NC State and your department right now?

How do you feel about STARS right now?

fields.title: STARS Reflection January 2011
fields.post:
How are your current academic goals developing?

My biggest academic goal this semester is to finish my written preliminary exam. I've taken steps towards this goal by making a timeline for myself and I will try to stick to it as closely as possible. For example, this week my goal is to transform the data from raw log files into a format that's appropriate for data processing. I need to figure out what kind of attributes I'd like to use and the best format for them.

How is your STARS project progressing?

My STARS project is the SPARCS outreach at CCMMS. We had our first session of the semester this past weekend. It went really well! It was our first time doing a circuitry/digital logic session and the students responded really well. A few students in particular were enthralled. It was amazing to see their faces brighten when they realized how complex circuits worked. I think this is definitely a session we'll continue to use.

Has STARS mentoring been helpful lately?

My mentee and I will be resuming our sessions this week. We have some particular goals we're looking to achieve so I think they will be helpful.

Did you experience any memorable events recently?

Not particularly.

is there anything you're looking forward to in the immediate future?

Finishing my written prelim!

How do you feel about NC State and your department right now?

I have always loved NC State and the CSC department, so much so that I can't seem to leave :). I think the department is especially doing a really good job right now of using social media to get the word out about cool things that are going on in the department. From youtube to facebook, there are lots of interesting news stories related to the department that make me proud.

How do you feel about STARS right now?

I think that STARS is still going strong. I here of good things going on with other groups, but there is a bit of disconnect, I think. Sometimes I feel like the groups are kind of divided and I don't even know some of the other people in the STARS group and what they're doing. This is probably just because STARS has grown so much this year and I'm used to the small groups of STARS past.

fields.title: End of Fall Semester Blog
fields.post:
Some reflections on the Fall CSC 116 tutoring:
- People were very grateful for the help. It was validating to know that my effort was not being wasted.
- On Fridays when a project was not due, it was hardly worth coming, since essentially no students showed up. They only ever seemed to come the day the project was due.
- Distressingly, I had the same kinds of questions at the end of the semester as at the beginning of the semester. Does this mean that the students were not learning anything?

fields.title: CSC 116 Tutoring - Fall 2010
fields.post:
I am happy to report that the Fall 2010 CSC 116 tutoring project will be wrapping up another successful semester tomorrow afternoon as we help the 116 students with their final project for the class.

This year we had fewer tutors (5) and served fewer students (93), but there were also fewer students to serve and not as many sections of the class. Despite these changes, we worked about the same number of hours (64) this semester.

The requests for help the we received were, again, from predominantly white male students, which was expected since the makeup of the class is predominantly white male. We more than doubled the number of requests from African American students this year and also increased the number of requests from Asian students. We received fewer requests from Hispanic and other race students.
