Based on feedback from last semester, we scheduled nearly all our hours for Friday afternoons. As expected, no one showed up unless a project was due that day. On project days, we were totally swamped and there was standing room only in the lab. I still have not devised a good method to encourage students to seek help earlier on large projects.

All in all, this semester went very well. Many thanks to my fellow tutors for all of their hard work!

fields.title: Website Team
fields.post: I have agreed to coordinate the website effort this year. This year the website team includes, Mark, Jayaram, and Arpan. We have decided to continue doing our regular activities of updating new members and projects on the website. We also have a few new things we wanted to change in the website, namely a blurb on the top of the page with the a sentence or two about a project that will be randomly selected to show up. We have also decide to move to a database backend for the website. We have also updated our youtube channel (NCStateSTARS). We intend to add google analytics to our website to see how it is being used. We hope to have a very productive year!

fields.title: Midterm updates
fields.post:
This is my first blog post of the year, and really ever. So far, STARS has been a great experience. As a new member, I feel very welcome. It's a great experience that give you a break from the monotony of classes. I decided to join the SPARCS @ CCMMS outreach program and it has been a blast. We've held two sessions: one on the field of computer science and another on game design, taught with Game Maker.

The session on computer science covered basic areas, such as what programs are, how computers interpret instructions, binary, and sorting. Many students understood the small lessons and I feel like they left with a better understanding of computer science. The second session on game design was great. The students could really connect with what they were taught, since they all play video games in some shape or form. David and Veronica did a good job on teaching them some basics of object oriented design, game design, as well as the Game Maker tool.

The next session for SPARCS is going to be focused on web design. Veronica and I will be leading the topic and will be teaching the students HTML and some basic CSS. Im excited to be one of the ones leading a session and can't wait to see what websites the students can come up with.

fields.title: Midterm Update - Getting my feet wet with research
fields.post:
My semester's project is predicting students' mistakes and misconceptions in a game-based learning environment. Research is a fascinating career track and this is my first semester being exposed to it to this degree.

First I had to decide on the project. This was difficult because how do you pick a problem to attempt to solve without exposure to the field? So, I set up a meeting with Dr. Lester and Dr. Mott where we discussed research, and they, along with my graduate mentor Jonanthan Rowe, gave me suggestions of papers to read over the summer, in order to expose myself to the field.

After skimming through papers, Jon helped me narrow down my interest and we came up with the predicting student mistakes and misconceptions topic. The next part would prove to be the most time consuming. I had to prepare a 22 page annotated bibliography on relevant papers.

I completely underestimated the 'relevant' part first time around. Reading and comprehending research papers was something I wasn't fully accustomed to. I chose many papers that were slightly relevant, but interesting. I also only had the minimum amount of papers. After a well-needed meeting with my mentor, I found over 80 relevant titles, greatly increased my reading proficiency, and was able to complete the task.

Now I have a new deadline approaching, the actual research project. I will be using the Weka toolkit to apply data-mining algorithms to data found in the student log files as well as pre and post-test responses, in attempt to solve my research problem. I will conclude my project with a research paper summarizing the results, as well as a poster.

fields.title: Project and STARS Experiences
fields.post: Up until now, my semester has been quite hectic. As far as my STARS projects are concerned, I am interning at SAS, conducting software engineering research under Dr. Xie, and am a member of Lucy's SPARCS project. My experience at SAS has been great and challenging. The work has become more intense and I'm creating applications that could greatly help my division. My research is the same as last year, iTutor. I am still amidst my project's most difficult task, which is to integrate jCUTE (Java Concolic Unit Testing Engine) into my iTutor project in Eclipse. Once this integration is complete, the program will be available for alpha testing. In SPARCS, we have conducted two sessions, both of which have gone greatly. Our most recent session dealt with cryptography and I was amazed as to how enthusiastic and smart some of the kids were. I look forward to our future sessions.

fields.title: The Start of the Beginning
fields.post:
This is my first blog ever so this should be an interesting experience. Here goes...

The semester started out just like my freshman year with normal classes and not much else. That is when I decided that I needed to get involved with something or the tedious repetition of classes was going to get to me. STARS gave me just the opportunity that I needed. I joined the undergraduate research with Joe Grafsgaard and Kristy Boyer. The research was very fast pace in the beginning and I managed to get the training and certification done in a weekend. After I was certified, Joe and I had to establish inter-rater reliability. Once Joe was satisfied, we got to the actual coding. I thoroughly enjoyed the facial action coding because it was interesting to see the universal expressions and because it gave me something to focus on besides just classes. Then when class work began to pick up, the coding was finished. So far this has been a very interesting semester. I have enjoyed the variety between classes and work. Now I just need to finish my poster for the research and I will be done.

Well thanks for reading. Thats all for now.

fields.title: SPARCS @ DNS: Reflections from the beginning of year 2
fields.post: SPARCS @ DNS is now in its second year of existence! After a successful first year, the administration and students at DNS were enthusiastic about starting up again this year. We have another great group of 15 young men this year. Our first session went well and the boys were extremely receptive to the material and excited about getting things going. They seem most excited about game development, webpages, and, of course, robotics. Our most recent session was security and encryption. SPARCS leader, KaMar Galloway, graciously stepped up to lead the session and did a wonderful job! Thanks KaMar! Next week we will be doing webpages, so stay tuned to see how their pages turn out!

fields.title: Midterm Update- SPARCS: Durham Nativity School
fields.post: STARS this year so far has been a positive experience and I have enjoyed meeting the boys and participating. This year the students seem to be very knowledgeable about computing and it is refreshing to know that they are extremely interested in what we have to teach them on Saturday afternoons. SPARCS-DNS is a program where we mentor middle school male students and introduce them to the wonderful world of Computer Science. We have exposed the boys to CS Unplugged and Security so far. I haven't lead a Saturday yet but I hope to be able to very soon. I am really excited about the rest of the sessions and hope to build even stronger relationships and friendships with the DNS students.

fields.title: Citizens School Apprenticeship: Hello world - STUDENTS LOVE WEB DESIGN!
fields.post:
This semester I am working with Citizens School at Lowe's Grove Middle school to teach an apprenticeship in web design and information discovery on the internet.

The students love web design, creating personal web pages, and learning about computers. The experience is very rewarding as it affords the opportunity to directly work with students on material that is interesting and fun! Students will also create web pages that discuss their career interests. This has provided a perfect opportunity to discuss careers in the field of computing.

Many students are interesting in video game development and so I have had one on one conversations discussing some video game career opportunities in the Raleigh area as well as some of the skill video games developers might have. It is uplifting to see students eager to learn about computers as well as see individual life goals set by middle school students that are directly impacted by the field of computing.

fields.title: USCRI : How STARS helped me to reach out..
fields.post:
All of us have our petty ways to connect to life and no marks for guessing that I have my own too. That being,"To be able to give back to the society". As I changed continents in the beginning of 2010 [er..joined NC State], I was on a constant look-out for opportunities that would let me connect again. The search ended with STARS. I joined STARS in Fall 2010 [into my second semester of Grad School], solely because I read about its outreach programs, only to realize later that STARS is way more than just that :)
I work with the USCRI outreach program. My first session was an eye-opener. I saw my team doing a great job with the task of : "Learning to interact with students who do not understand your language and yet ensuring they interpret the lectures well". Every session, I get to learn more from my team [Andrea, Katie, Lakshmi, Ling, Padmashree, Rachel and Rajesh]and from the students whose enthusiasm amazes me. Its overwhelming to see the way they ask questions about things we assume are granted. The other day a student asked me "So, if I can insert a picture in MS Word, can I move pictures from my cellphone to the computer and send it to my friends?" Well, I am sure the day isn't far... :)

fields.title: Midterm blog
fields.post:
I've had a great experience with STARS so far. CSC116 Tutoring is currently my main project, and I'm very happy with it. It's rewarding and fun to tutor introductory programming concepts, so I enjoy it. I've also helped in my secondary project, Feed Your Brain.
Hosting the social hour in Skype is always cool~ I'm sure participation will increase~
One of the most tangible outcomes that I've had with the organization is an internship position I just recently got. I'm very excited and happy with STARS.

fields.title: Midsemester Update - USCRI and Hispanic Outreach
fields.post:
This is my first year in STARS, and I'm part of the USCRI outreach program, and the Hispanic Student Outreach.

I really like the USCRI outreach program because I feel that the people who attend classes are interested in learning about computers and they find the information provided quite useful. Last session was held on Saturday, and one person brought an introductory book to Windows with explanations in english and his native language. This shows that the person really wants to understand computers, and that we are helping him, and others.

We have had really good ideas related to the Hispanic Student Outreach, but unfortunately we haven't had any luck with the schools we have reached to. We will be sending more emails to get in touch with people that might be interested in the outreach.

Looking forward for the next USCRI sessions, and to continue working in the Hispanic Student Outreach.

fields.title: November Wireless, SPARCS, and FYB Updates
fields.post:
It seems with each new year in STARS I've added a new project to my list of things to tackle. I began investigating starting the Wireless Raleigh project, then last year added working with SPARCS at CCMMS. This fall, I was so intrigued (as were many others) by the Feed Your Brain idea (and the results!) portrayed at the conference in August that I joined the start-up team to bring FYB to NC State as well.
The Wireless Raleigh project so far has been pretty stop and go. After a great conversation in August with the head of the IT department for the city, I was unfortunately asked to coordinate further efforts with another person in the department who has been a bit less speedy with responses. Essentially, I've been analyzing some traffic data as well as host information with the aim toward examining the common trends identifying the user base as well as security and privacy aspects.
SPARCS so far has just held one session, but we're doing our second and third ones in the next two weekends so that's something to look forward to! Additionally, we're beginning some new topics with the replacement of Alice programming with GameMaker, which should be exciting. The enrollment seems much higher this year than last, and we have two sets of girl twins in attendance as well as a good mixture (compared to, say, my computer science classes) of race and gender.
Feed Your Brain, in essence, is just a quick and dirty tutorial session amongst peers or a hands-on session led by an experienced person in the field. The topics really are intended to cover what students what to know that they are never really taught from the curriculum. This can extend not only to computer science students but also to other technical or even non-technical audiences -- since the aim of STARS is to broaden participation in computing, FYB in my opinion has a really great potential for doing so in many areas at that university level. We've done our first session this week on Eclipse, and I at least had a good time teaching and having discussions with the people who showed up. If anyone has some suggestions for more topics for later FYB session, please let me know (or comment below).

fields.title: Project and STARS Experiences
fields.post:
SPARCS

SPARCS has completed one session at Centennial Campus middle school thus far in the semester. This first session taught students computer science concepts without the use of a computer. We covered topics including sorting algorithms, how computers (blindly) interpret instructions, the Turing test, and binary numbers. Tasks appealed to students differently based upon the instruction method. For example, demonstrating how cluelessly computers interpret instructions involved pairs of students attempting to reproduce pencil drawings. That activity engaged students differently than did the more mathematical activities, such as binary, octal, and hexadecimal numbers.

The bulk of the SPARCS sessions for this semester still coming. Check back for another update after this week's SPARCS session!

Website

The website team is slowly getting the website updated for the current academic year. All membership and project information has been updated with the exception of some new or revised projects. We're also working towards hosting some promotional videos on our NCSU STARS SLC YouTube page and incorporating Google Analytics into the site.

Evaluation

The evaluation team is prepared to conduct the fall interview this Friday. More details to follow!

fields.title: Midsemester Updates
fields.post:
Wow, its so hard to believe its November already. The semester's going to draw to a close before we know it. This semester has held a lot of exciting projects!

SPARCS at CCMMS is in its fourth year and is doing even better than ever before. For the first time ever we've got a wait list of students who are interested, but we just don't have the space. I've also gotten several parents asking for a Raleigh-wide or other spin-offs of SPARCS. This year we're also trying two new sessions - GameMaker and Circuitry. I think these will be a great addition to the rest of our lineup and I'm excited to see how the students respond to them. We've got great mentors this year - never before have I had a crew so well organized and motivated! I know I say this every year, but this is going to be the best SPARCS ever!

We've also been working on some cool projects for a Crystal Island affect study this December. Veronica, an REU student with STARS and the Intellimedia group, has done a lot of interesting work in helping to prepare for this study. This includes playing with pressure sensors to build a seat which can measure student posture and fidgeting. She's also worked on the code for logging and interpreting data from the seat and is in the process of getting accustomed to the Crystal Island development process so she can incorporate some fun affect reports with a hint of a social media aspect to the game.

There's a lot that needs to be done on these fronts before the end of the semester, but its an exciting time :)

fields.title: STARS Midterm Evaluation
fields.post: This is my second year in STARS and I have really enjoyed it thus far. This semester I am mentoring under-represented middle school students and teaching them about the many disciplines in Computer Science. So far we have only had two sessions, the first being CS Unplugged and the latter being Security. I took on the challenge of leading the Security workshop and was surprised at how much I learned while preparing the material. We discussed the differences between viruses, worms, and Trojan horses, in addition to safety protocols as it relates to choosing strong passwords. I am really looking forward to the remaining sessions and assisting in each of the student's personal growth.

fields.title: Mid Semester With STARS - Fall 2010
fields.post:
My involvement with STARS this semester has been the SPARCS outreach at Centennial Campus Magnet Middle School (CCMMS). We've held one session so far, and have three more sessions planned this semester with the next session being this Saturday (11/13).

Our first session was a lot of fun. We had several kids, many of whom were vary interested and engaged in the topic--"CS Unplugged", which focused on teaching the kids the core concepts behind computer science, such as: What a program is, how computers interpret instructions, and the basics of binary. Overall, the topic was well received. I felt like the exception were a few of the kids who were more interested in playing flash games and not listening to us teach. At one point, we went into teaching them how to add binary numbers and how to understand hexadecimal--I think this topic was definitely too in depth and didn't reap real benefits to the kids.

Our next session with the kids is going to introduce them to the topic of developing video games. I am co-leading this topic with Veronica Catete. Using a tool called GameMaker (http://www.yoyogames.com/gamemaker/), we will actually demonstrate to the kids the basic concepts of OO programming and then let them work on a game themselves. We'll cover how OO design works, then show them some examples as well has how to make a game in GameMaker, then let them design their own game--conceptualizing the objects they'll need, and implementing their design. I'm excited about our upcoming sessions and can't wait to see how the kids receive it!

fields.title: Tutoring, Feed Your Brain, and Research: Oh My!
fields.post:
This is my first semester in STARS, so I suppose I should start with a brief introduction. My name is Alok Baikadi, I'm a 4th year Ph.D student in computer science. I was very involved in my undergraduate ACM chapter, and joined STARS for many of the same reasons. I've gotten involved in three major projects this semester, and will touch briefly on each of them.

Tutoring
Historically, STARS has provided tutoring for CSC 116 - Introduction to Java. While this is undoubtably useful, it's always been my experience that students tend to be more surprised, and struggle more, with the discrete math, and more proof-oriented courses (automata theory, algorithms, etc.). I made it a point this semester to start up a second branch of tutoring to meet with these needs. After some discussions with the instructors for the two sections of CSC 226 - Discrete Math, we were able to find several volunteers and assign ourselves a room. However, we've had some issue with advertising: The students don't seem to know that the tutoring is being offered. This has, unofrtunately, negated any sort of impact such a toturing may have provided. I do plan on continuing the project, and we'll see if we can get more people involved.

Feed Your Brain
Anne and I heard a little about this project at the STARS Celebration. We came into this project with, I think, very different ideas of what to expect. This project got off to a slower start, with some confusion in scheduling and myself getting overwhelmed by a few things. We've settled on a couple topics for quick tutorials, and we'll see about bringing in some other speakers to do similar tutorials. We're still working on the advertising and scope of these talks, but it's looking promising.

Research
For my last project, I'm mentoring Kevin in research. I'm sure he'll have his own thoughts on how that's been going, but I've been pleased with his progress. It's been a new experience for me to try and simplify and specify the problem in strict enough terms that I can pass it off and monitor someone's progress. I can't say I've always succeeded, but I hope it's been getting better as things have progressed and become more defined.

So that's been the semester so far, and some first thoguhts on each of the projects. Check back soon for more updates and final thoughts on the whole semester.

fields.title: STARS Update - Fall 2010
fields.post:
I am a new student with STARS, and I'm loving being part of this group! My induction to STARS was over summer, at the STARS Celebrations in Orlando, Florida. I think the celebration is a great idea, especially for new students. I got to know a lot more about STARS that I did before. It was great to meet so many people from all the different universities, knowing that we shared a common goal. I feel that meeting all these people left me more motivated to work in the STARS projects. I was also able to attend really good workshops at the conference, which provided useful tools to carry out research, mentoring and teaching.

This semester I'm a part of the CSC 116 tutoring project. The tutoring is going great so far. We've been having 2-4 students regularly. The week before last, we had about 30 students (they had a project due that day, of course!). It feels good to help the students. The general trend that we have seen is that if a project or a homework is due, lots of students turn up for tutoring hours. The assignments are usually due on Fridays, and most students come the day their assignment is due. So, by having almost all the tutors hold office hours on Fridays, we are able to help more people.

fields.title: STARS Evaluation and New Tutoring this Fall
fields.post:
Evaluation work is going as usual. With about a month left in the semester, a lot of reporting and summarizing tasks are coming up. Our SLC's increasing number of projects should give us a pretty good dataset for analysis, and I'm looking forward to the end-of-semester report. We are also contemplating putting up statistics and aggregated demographics for our projects on the NCSU STARS website, making it as accessible and meaningful as we can. For this purpose, and some other small tasks, I have been working with the website team - meeting at the library is a really good idea, especially with the touch table and creamery around!

Discrete Math Tutoring is the other project I'm doing, and I'm glad to be part of the first edition. But it has been pretty dry till now, with not many students showing up. I guess we'll see a better turnout in future semesters as this time we started off a little late. Or maybe this time the classes are exceptionally brilliant, and wouldn't mind teaching us a thing or two about math. I could actually use a refresher course like that; somebody told me 42 may not always be the right answer :O

fields.title: Alok's Research Project
fields.post: My part in helping with Alok's project is coming along smoothly. I have been meeting with him every week to discuss what I've accomplished as so far as well as plan what the goals for the next week will be. As of yet, I have developed a system for placing characters and objects around the scene according to various protocols such as nearest object or with targeted locations while also adding a unique offset distance. The next major step will be to read in key words and map that information to tagged objects so that the characters I am placing in the scene will make sense according to where they end up. There hasn't been too many setbacks so far, aside from a few instances where my code caused the game engine to crash and I had to restart the whole scene. This project is gearing up to be pretty neat and it will be even more exciting when it nears completion.

fields.title: STARS Update
fields.post: I am a part of the USCRI outreach program and I have an undergraduate research position with Dr. Young. The USCRI program is a little chaotic, because we don’t have a very regular attendance, but when people do show up, they pick things up quickly and are interested in learning more. We are planning to show them how to get to the Cameron Village Library so that they can use the computers there, since they don’t have their own, but because people don’t always show up for the classes, it is hard to find a time to take them there. My research position is interesting, but even though I only have 10 hours a week, it is a little hard to meet them because all of my classes are on main campus, and I can only make it to Centennial in the evening or at night. The graduate students I am working with are helpful though, and it’s a good experience.

fields.title: Project and STARS experience
fields.post: I am part of CSC 116 tutoring, web site design and Feed your brain. All the three projects have been going good till now. I was just able to help one guy for the CSC 116 tutoring. He had a problem with the syntax but it feels good to help atleast one person. For the website design, I redesigned the youtube page by changing the colors and the themes. We are going to have our First session of "Feed your brain" this Tuesday. The practical workshop is on "Eclipse". Hope it goes well. Overall its a very good experience to be with STARS and make some new friends.

fields.title: STARS Mid Semester Update
fields.post:
This semester my STARS activities include Research and SPARCS.

I am doing research with the Intellimedia lab on Crystal Island stuff. My current project is implementing logging for a new pressure sensor chair that will be used in upcoming test studies on ~250 8th graders. Together with Jen Sabourin we developed a sensor filled cushion that detects how a person is seated. It detects if they are leaning forward, leaning back, to the left or to the right. It has 6 different force sensors and 2 IR sensors. We had a logistics meeting with others involved in running the test study last week, and think we might need ~ 30 of these seats sewn together. After piggy backing my log script to the current CI log system, I will hook up the new social network to be implemented in CI. The players will be able to update their status with an emoticon that corresponds to a core emotion, as well as a text update. These emoticons are in efforts to replace annoying self-reports.

My second project is SPARCS @ CCMMS. This year we are adding 2 new sessions game design and circuits. I will be in charge of running the game design session with David in 2 weeks. We will also talk about the presidential video game challenge for middle schoolers. It offers huge prizes to middle school students who develop a game using scratch or game maker. GameMaker is the tool we will be using to make games with. It has an intuitive GUI based programming area where students can customize their own creations and save them to take home with them to play later. The week following I will be teaching web-design with Omar. Ideally we will be switching from html, to more modern css.

I have also been frequently tapped to be a computer science ambassador, where I go and talk with new students about opportunities in computer science involving research and other activities. Overall, my final semester as a NC State STARS member has been good. Plus we have two sets of twin girls in SPARCS this year which is super awesome ^o^

fields.title: Matthew Fendt Fall Blog Entry
fields.post:
I have been working on the CSC 116 tutoring this semester. The student attendance has been hit or miss so far. There have been several weeks when no students show up. That is frustrating because I have to travel all the way to main campus for nothing. However, there has been one or two weeks where students have shown up. I think that I did a good job helping the students then. One example was a student had a different block of code for each different possible logical branch in his code. I explained why this is not desirable and he asked to be shown how to fix it.

I also just got an undergraduate mentee, so we will see how that goes as well.

fields.title: Welcome to NC State STARS Blogging!
fields.post:
How to Blog:

1) Go to: http://research.csc.ncsu.edu/stars/wiki/

2) Use your WRAP Login

3) Go to “Create Content”, then “Blog entry”

4) You should create your blog entry in a word processor ahead of time.

5) Create a descriptive title and paste in your blog entry into the "Body".

6) Click "Preview" if you'd like to see your content.

7) Click "Save" to bequeath your experience to the world.

Enjoy!

fields.title: Spring Break
fields.post: The tutoring project will be taking a week off for Spring Break this week. Check back next week!

fields.title: CSC 116 Tutoring Project Update - Week 4
fields.post:
I'm noticing a trend in the tutoring program. Most of the week, no one shows up. Then, on Fridays before an assignment is due, so many people show up that we eventually turn people away.

I'm wondering what's the best way to fix this. One solution is to just move all our tutors to Friday evening. Matt Fendt is moving to Friday to help with the load. But there's got to be a better way. Any ideas?

fields.title: Taxonomy test 2-26-2010
fields.post: Testing taxonomy

fields.title: CSC 116 Tutoring Project Update - Week 3
fields.post:
Our intro class tutoring project is proceeding nicely.

Attendance by the students seems to be concentrated into certain sessions, mostly Fridays before assignments are due.

I'm seeing a lot of diversity in the students I tutor: men, women, white, african american, hispanic, etc. They all seem to be having similar problems, which I think speaks in favor of the overall project of increasing diversity in Computer Science.

More updates to come!

fields.title: Second Week of Tutoring
fields.post:
The second week of STARS tutoring went much like the first, with similar problem, though students do seem to be grasping some of the more difficult concepts.

We're happy to announce the addition of two new tutors to our ranks: Matt Fendt and Robert Hudson! Welcome to the group, guys. Looking at the CSC 116 TA / Tutor schedule is now a very satisfying experience because we have so many time slots filled. Students needing help in 116 won't have to look far!

fields.title: CSC 116 Tutoring Update
fields.post:
Our first week of tutoring was a slow one, but we've had a chance to introduce the program to all of the 116 classes, and people seemed enthusiastic.

Of all the tutors, I think I was the only one who had students show up... probably because I was working late on the day before a project was due. The students had pretty standard intro questions. They tend to get confused about integer/double mathematical operations, and the fact that (i = 1) is not the same as (i = i + 1).

At one point six students all wanted help on the same thing, so I got them to sit down in a group and work out the problem collaboratively with just a couple of hints. It was a rewarding experience to see that "Ah-ha! I get it now" look on their faces when we were done.

fields.title: Hello world!
fields.post:
Greetings fellow STARS watchers!

My name is Stephen, and I am new this semester. I got involved with STARS at the suggestion of several friends in the department, and am really looking forward to working with all of you.

I am a PhD student working with Dr. Young in the Digital Games Research Center. I get to research interesting new technologies for video games (and other purposes), teach, and work in a University setting. This is my dream job, and I hope I can pass on my enthusiasm to those I work with in STARS.

After seeing my undergraduate university (Loyola New Orleans) cut its Computer Science Department in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, and after teaching CSC 216 this summer, I've gotten very excited about raising awareness about CS to others. I get excited about my field, and I like to get others excited about it. I also want to increase the public's understanding of how essential our work is the the advancement of man kind.

Given my past teaching experience along with two previous TA appointments, Joe suggested that I head up the CSC 116 tutoring project this semester, and I agreed. We'll be providing help to struggling students in our intro course. Intro courses are essential. If we scare people away in 116, we can never hope to graduate the quantity and quality of technology professionals that we so badly need.

I suppose I should also include some information about me. My research is on incorporating conflict into computer-generated stories. I'm also interested in philosophy of mind and literature. Actually, it was my interest in literary theory that got me involved with my current research. I also enjoy cooking, fencing, table top games, and various recreational sports.

Here's to a great semester!
-- Stephen

fields.title: Project Summary
fields.post:
Internship

Overview: Student internships provide opportunities for students to gain experience in their field, determine if they have an interest in a particular career, create a network of contacts, or gain school credit. Internships provide the employers with cheap or free labor for (typically) low-level tasks, and also the prospect of interns returning to the company after completing their education and requiring little or no training (Courtesy: Wikipedia)

Impact: Gain real life work experience while still being enrolled full time student at an University.

Conclusion: The proximity of the Triangle area to North Carolina State University is ideal and the technical skills gained are invaluable. Students should look out for possible part time internships posting on the Computer Science listserv, to take advantage of the opportunities that pop up there.

Web Development

Overview: Updating and adding new feature to STARS website.

Impact: Gives future members and the public a means of viewing what we (STARS) are working on.

Method: PHP based template for the web site.

Conclusion: As STARS grow we hope add more features to the website, such as a being able to view blog entries on the actual STARS people page.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intern

fields.title: Project Summary
fields.post:
Evaluation Team:

Overview: The goals of the evaluation team is to try to understand the impact that the STARS Alliance has. We try to understand how effective the current projects are at achieving the overall goals of the Alliance.

Impact: The impact o the evaluation team is that how evaluations provide insight to how the Alliances projects and strategies are working toward our goal. Through the evaluation teams the Alliance can make changes to their plans in order to better reach their goals.

Method: We used interviews and project reporting for our findings. The interactions because us and our target audience is either in informal meetings or through emails.

Conclusion: Our project turned out well compared to the intended results. Having the reporting document earlier would have allowed for better reporting among the groups early on.

SPARCS @ CCMS

Overview: SPACS is an outreach aimed at middle schoolers to broad the participation in computer science. There are sessions held on Saturday that introduce the students to different concepts in Computer Science.

Impact: The impact of SPARCS is that it shows computer science to middle schooler. Some of the middle schoolers might only think of computer science as games or the internet and not think about the people behind those ideas. By showing them some of the concepts of computer science we hope to get more people interested in the field of computing.

Method: We have meeting on Saturday at CCMS were we introduce the students to a different aspect of computer science. We make use of computers, games, and non computer activities to get the students involved in computing and critical thinking.

Conclusion: Our first sessions have gone good. I believe that the students are learning and are interested in what they are being presented with. I think it would be nice if it was possible to meet with the students more often and have things for them to do during the time we're not meeting would be something that could be improved upon.

fields.title: Project Summaries
fields.post:
This was my first semester of STARS and I've enjoyed working on my projects. I was involved in both the Durham Nativity School Outreach as well as tutoring for CSC116 students.

The Durham Nativity School Outreach (SPARCS) involved working with about 12 middle school students from the said school every other Saturday for an average of three hours. The goal is to introduce the students to the basic concepts and also the breadth of computer science to encourage them to explore and perhaps pursue a career in computer science. The kids did not know much about computer science so I'm sure we've shown them a lot that they can take back. The cool thing was that they were very enthused about all our activities. Sessions we did include: 1) CSC unplugged, where we introduce the basic ideas and concepts without using computers. 2) ALICE programming, where they learned basic OOP ideas and used it to control and create scenarios in the ALICE interface. 3) HTML, where we went over the basic of creating web pages through code. 4) Lego Mindstorms is actually two sessions where the students build Lego robots with sensors then program them to do specific tasks. The sessions typically consists of pre and post surveys to gauge what the students learned, lunch, an instructions/introduction period, and then an activities period. I think overall, the way the project is structured is very good as and that our goal was accomplished. The kids seem to really enjoy doing some of the things, although the attentions of energetic middle-schoolers tend to wane after a longer session. However, I am sure we've taught these kids a lot of things they've never seen before through fun activities, so I think this project has been very successful.

Tutoring CSC116 students was a bit less exciting, but it was good to work with a different demographics as well. This was sort of my sub-project so I only tutored for one hour or so a week. There were some weeks where students needed help that I stayed longer, but I was also unable to make it to some week. Our goal of tutoring was to help students in the introductory Java class with their assignments and help them to better see and solve programming problems. For the time that I was there, I think I've helped a good number of students by either working one-on-one with them or perhaps talking to several students with the same problem at once. The difficult thing about this was realizing what they know and don't know since we did not know what's been covered in class. But overall, it was fun to help intro students solve their programming problems and mistakes that I used to make.

fields.title: Project Summary...
fields.post:
Working with the Durham Nativity School with SPARCS has been nothing but a great experience for me that I get excited about each Saturday when I participate. The boys are awesome and surprisingly love to learn about Computer Science on a Saturday morning. I feed off of their energy and am so glad that I decided to be part of this particular outreach. They all have a lot going for them and I am eager to see how bright their futures will be. For the first DNS SPARCS session I was in charge of facilitating the activities for that day called CSC Unplugged. Seeing as though I am not a Computer Science major I thought that this would probably be the best day for me to be in charge of. The boys were well enthused about the activities and actively participated in each one equally. I enjoyed facilitating CSC Unplugged and learned a little more about Computer Science myself. I also was in charge of picking up the pizza for the boys that day! :)

- Goals of my project: 1. Inform the DNS boys more about Computer Science
2. Encourage the DNS boys to pursue Computer Science
3. Build a mentoring relationship with the DNS boys
4. Get to know each DNS boy on a deeper level other than just academic wise

-Impact: This project would greatly benefit my community by giving youth positive role models in their community as well as providing opportunities for youth to better themselves, meet new people, and stay on the right track towards success through school. I feel like the DNS SPARCS outreach program is awesome and will and can touch several youth's lives. Not only can this outreach benefit those youth involved in the program but also those looking in by setting an example for others that can encourage them to do the same type of outreach as well.

Method: The tools that I used were my fellow STARS members. We worked well together with the DNS boys through activities and keeping everything organized. Lucy has done a super job getting the majority of the sessions together and making sure that every session is enjoyable for the boys. The interactions between me and the DNS boys seems to be pretty good. It is easy for me to connect with them because I have a younger brother who is around their age so I kind of have an upper hand in that aspect.

Conclusion: I felt liked SPARCS with DNS has been very successful and will only grow bigger and better within the upcoming semesters and I am excited about being a part of that. I hope that we can become more active in their extracurricular life as well and get to do things with them outside of Saturday sessions!

fields.title: Project Summaries - Fall 09
fields.post:
This was my first semester with STARS, and went really well. Both in terms of the quantity of work I was able to put in and the sense of fulfillment it gave me. My primary responsibility was being an Evaluation Assistant. With the new web-based reporting tool in place, STARS activity reporting went quite well. The coordinators have done a great job of keeping track of all the data and entering it into the online form, although I wish we were able to include more reports from the upcoming sessions in the overall Fall 09 report. The other part of Evaluation work was interviewing an SLC student about their thoughts and experiences about computing, which was quite interesting. Transcribing the interview took a lot longer than I expected (even though I and Jimmy split that task), but it was all good.

  • Impact: Evaluation has always been an integral part of any research project. For STARS, this means judging how well the different activities and programs are performing. It helps steer effort in the right direction and improve the overall effectiveness of the alliance. The impact is cross-cutting and will be visible in the progress we are able to make over the years.
  • Method: We used a lot of Google Docs this semester to collect data. Communication with activity coordinators was mainly through email, and a little bit over meetings. The interview was taped on a digital recorder provided by STARS. For all this work, we were given sufficient training and guidelines during the STARS celebration.
  • Conclusion: I believe the reports we're sending in for this semester are well representative of the efforts put in by SLC members and the impact we've had. Again, I would really like to report all the activities for a semester together (after the semester is over), instead of doing it with a month left - which leaves out several sessions to be reported in the following semester (e.g. reports are due end of Nov for Fall). I do appreciate the new web-based reporting form - hope it'll be improved upon further.

My secondary project was being a tutor for the CSC-116 (Introductory Java) class. In my opinion, the idea worked very well. Most students I helped out had trivial mistakes in their programs, like trying to compare strings with '==' when they should be using '.equals()'. Such nuisances can bog people down pretty badly, especially those who are new to programming. The students had an excellent grasp of the overall concepts of programming, and required very little or no assistance in coming up with the logic they needed for their programs. The syntactical peculiarities of computer languages are difficult to understand from textbooks, however, and can sometimes be quite frustrating. I'm sure that having a tutor around, who has gone through these same moments of despair, is quite helpful.

Mentoring has been my third activity this semester, just like everyone else. Interesting to get to know what courses other students take and how they manage them with other activities. The meetings were mostly informal chats about weekly activities, so this was probably the most relaxing part of the STARS experience!

fields.title: Fall project summary
fields.post:
The end of Fall 2009 is nearing! It's a good time to look back at what's gone on. I'll start with the STARS project I'm working with that I haven't mentioned yet: SPARCS. My one and only session for the fall takes place on Saturday, and I'm looking forward to it! With that out of the way, let's talk about where I've been spending the rest of my STARS time...

Now, on to the CSC116 tutoring. This started with the goal of providing an additional resource for students needing help grasping the concepts of programming. Hopefully, these students will be more successful in their class, and be more inclined to further pursue Computer Science. We held 9 tutoring hours per week between the 5 tutors (myself included), during which we'd provide one-on-one tutoring to students needing it. We were able to stay apprised of the homework and class schedule through collaboration with the outstanding 116 instructional staff. For instance, we knew to stack our hours towards the end of the week, as assignments were due on Fridays, though students did take advantage of non-Friday hours as well. Our service had dozens of visits over the last 3 months, and while I can't speak for the other tutors, I think I was able to provide them help (without crossing academic integrity lines). Given enough tutor resources, I'd like to expand this to include CSC216 (the next course) at some point! It's been a rewarding semester, and I look forward to the next one!

fields.title: Project Update
fields.post:
So far we have had two SPARCS sessions and our third is on this coming Saturday. So far the sessions have been going well. One of the big changes and focuses of work for me this year has been the new SPARCS webpage and this has had mixed results. While it is great to have digitized data right away, the school system doesn't seem to like the page very much and seems to be interfering with submissions. Hopefully we'll get these kinks worked out.

The overall goals of SPARCS are to increase interest in CS among middle school students. The impact of this on the community is obviously to broaden participation in computing. We have used many freely available tools such as Alice and CSUnplugged to offer acticities to students. Our interactions are structured as Saturday sessions and so far appear to be successful. So far everything is going as intended, as mentioned above the website is slightly less awesome than expected, but still helpful and improving.

fields.title: Project Update
fields.post:
The work on the STARS website has been moving slowly but surely. As of now, almost all member profiles and project descriptions have been updated. We pioneered the use of Google Forms in collection member and project information this year but were met with mixed results. On the plus side, information collection was centralized and did not involve the usual shuffling about of emails with updated information. Member profiles were then easily generated running the form data through a script. Project descriptions required manual work for correct formatting, however. On the down side, there was the human factor. People in general forget about surveys if they aren't constantly reminded.

  • Impact: The website is correct for the current academic year which consequently facilitates its usefulness.
  • Method: Google Forms, Python scripting, and markup
  • Conclusion: Progress is slow but sure.

SPARCS @ CCMS has had two meetings now with the third scheduled for this Saturday. (Hint: Today is November 19) The first session had large turnout, including a good number of girls. This session explored computer science concepts such as writing instructions and sorting. The second session introduced programming using the Alice environment developed at Carnegie Mellon University. Curiously (but not unexpectedly), the number of girls dropped to one. One (alleged) improvement that SPARCS has unveiled this year is electronic before and after surveys. This surveys are handy, but during the second session, we experienced technical difficulty using the www.stars.ncsu.edu/sparcs address instead of the research.csc.ncsu.edu/stars/sparcs. Unfortunately, the former is easier for students to spell.

  • Impact: Middle school students are preparing for the future by learning computer science concepts.
  • Method: Saturday sessions at CCMS, SPARCS site for parents and students
  • Conclusion: Surveys suggest students are learning.

fields.title: Project
fields.post: I am part of the Stars outreach project. We have been attending Lowe's Grove Middle and we are accomplishing a tremendous amount of our goals. Which are enlightening the children on what being a computer scientist is, what part they can play in the process, show them how everyday technology is used in the world and the many careers that are available. I feel like we are making a great impact on the community because we are taking the next generations and preparing them for the world of technology. Often times we found it hard to keep their attention but lets face it when you are trying to engage students nothing works better than the hands on method. We gave them alot of hands on participation which for this career is the best thing that will help them learn. I think our project has turned out great. As we go along we make the necessary changes and we are always open to new ideas.

fields.title: §Pâ|2(s  & fá©$
fields.post:
So one of my projects is SPARCS Classic, where we go to CCMS and work with the kids there. I think many of the children really enjoy learning about CSC. I've been told that half our girls & about a third of our minorities dropped out since the first session we had. But I am not sure if this is just a fluke or something that will remain. The goal of our project is to reach out to young children to help promote CSC. Ideally we would be reaching more minorities, women. However, we do have a couple kids with disabilities in our group so that's good. This project is ongoing, and we have another session this upcoming Saturday. We are looking at a turnout between 12 and 18 kids, and will be doing the second Alice session which, in the past, has caused issues, but hopefully will not occur this time.

My other project is research, but first I am getting FACS certified. FACS stands for the Facial Action Coding System, and we use it in conjunction with Crystal Island and identifying how emotions come into play when learning through the game. Working with Jen, I have gone through and reviewed all of the upper lower and miscellaneous facial actions, and just have to take the final examination, which I will do at the beginning of December. Word is that the exam is difficult, but we get really good feedback with our test results so that is nice. I am not quite solid on what research I will be doing with this next semester, but the outlook is good.

fields.title: SPARCS
fields.post: Being a part of the Durham Nativity School Outreach Program has been a great experience for me thus far. I have always wanted to give back to my community through my passion for technology and STARS has allowed me to do so. The goals of my project was to gather a group of boys from financially challenged (low income) families and engage them in Computer Science related activities. Over the past month or so, they have learned so much from what programming is, how programmers think, and that anyone can be successful in this field. More importantly, they were able to see how Computer Science relates to commercials, forensics, sport's casting, etc. We developed our lesson plan each Saturday to revolve around what kids find interesting such as upcoming video games clippings, touch-sensitive devices, and animation. The DNS kids really exceeded my expectations by discussing upcoming operating systems and "hacking" cell phones on the very first day. Our sessions were well organized and the boys really grasped each concept relatively quickly. My only suggestion for future STARS Outreach Programs would be to make sure that the participants are able to practice in between each session for retainment of the material. All in all, I hope that through our outreach that we were able to convey with them the wonderful things that CS can accomplish.

fields.title: SPARCS work
fields.post:
The Wireless Raleigh project has been stalled and spinning for the past two weeks or so, as the group downtown at the city government building is preoccupied with other pressing matters. My last update was on the qualitative (S/N ratio in various regions over the city) and quantitative (swapping over to new radios, distances, connectivity) tests being done.
However, I have been working on SPARCS for a while now, and am very glad to have joined up with this program and CCMS this semester. Our first session was two weeks ago on Saturday, and I was happily surprised at how much the kids seemed willing to learn, and how well they picked up the binary calculations, search trees, and cool games we played with them. Mark and I this past week worked on the lesson for next Saturday. Our upcoming session deals with the first Alice programming workshop, and so I got to play around with this world and style of learning for the first time. I made a demo for the lesson involving a very adorable cat, a big lion and a little squeaky mouse. Of course, along with the fun part Mark made a ppt to explain the basics of how to use Alice and create objects and the like inside its structure. It should be a good time for all next Saturday, I'm looking forward to it :)

fields.title: "Broadening Participation in Computing:
fields.post: I think it means to get more people involved into computing. There should always be a wide range of ages and ethic groups in computing bridging any gaps together. My STARS project reaches out to middle school children who share that same passion for computing and want to pursue some kind of career in computing. I think my early years would have gotten me a little further in the computer world, knowledge wise. Most of my passion of computing started at a very young age, receiving lots of electronics and computers as a child. But I had to learn alot on my own. I think it would help the future generations and build a stronger foundation on technology.

fields.title: Broaden participation in Computing
fields.post:
What do we mean and how are we achieving this at Citizen's school project?
- We want students to understand that computing is fun
- We want to break the stereotype image of computer scientists and the computer world
- We want to introduce them to "cool things" in Computer Science - Joe shows them a 5 minute "cool" video every session
- We want them to understand the concepts involved in computing and be able to appreciate them
- We want girls to know that computers are not a "guy's thing" and computer != JUST video games!!!! (I have come to understand that this is a challenge since we have just 1 girl in the batch this time!)

:)

fields.title: Broadening pariticipation in computing
fields.post:
Broadening participation in computing first and foremost means reaching out to potential students and getting them to consider going into computer as a field of study. This in turn involves breaking down stereotypes as well as exposing the students and their families to more facts about computing. Much like the article discusses, there is a need for a diverse group of computer scientists and engineers in order to get a diverse perspective on problems. However, many people do not enter the field thinking it's geeky, not cool, or that there's not much potential after the .com bubble burst and outsourcing. Parents decline "to send their young daughter to summer computer camp because they can’t imagine her developing a career in which she will be interacting with a computer the rest of her life." People need to realize that this is not true and that technical fields nowadays is very team and social oriented.

Kids these days are very technically savvy, but most do not think about studying computer as a field or even think about how computers came to be. They just expect it as a part of their lives. Therefore, it's important to reach out to young children, as the article stated. As a part of this, I'm involved in the Durham Nativity School Outreach, where we introduce middle school-ers to computer science. From the sessions so far, the kids really enjoy learning about computers and have not been involved with anything like it before. I believe that this is very critical to get young children involved.

fields.title: Broadening Participation in Computing
fields.post:
I really liked the article on BPC especially the considerations of top-down or bottom-up approaches. It all boils down to the conceptions people have of computing - that it is male-driven, nerdy, etc. In large part, this is true for now, but it need not be. In the bottom-up approach, we work on getting more students into computing and hope that the attitudes around computing change as demographics and involvement change. In the other we approach the attitudes and ideas first and hope that enrollment will follow. Both have their draws. The bottom-up approach is straight-forward. We can come up with steps to take to accomplish this, but without the attitudes in place it seems unlikely that we'll be too successful. The top-down approach is nice because it attacks the main source of the problem and hopes that people will start to act in accordance with these attitudes. But how can we change people's attitudes without the numbers and data to back it up. It seems like we need to approach it from both ends simultaneously and meet in the middle.

I hope that this sort of approach is what I'm accomplishing with the SPARCS outreach project. If our mentees get excited and pursue computer science, then we will be changing the demographic and we'll have started along the bottom-up road. But even if no one changes career paths, hopefully we'll instill infections excitement in the students. They will have us as role models and their friends will have them as role models to portray computer science as fun and exciting and available to everyone. All in all, a big win!

fields.title: What motivates me
fields.post:
The Blog Topic for 9/1/2009 is "What motivates you?":

Wow, what a tough question. I suppose a big thing that motivates me is my own ridiculous standards. I hate the idea of not living up to my potential. I know that I have what it takes to accomplish things and succeed and so not doing so seems like I would only be disappointing myself. I know that I set higher standards for myself than others set for me, so I'm not as worried about disappointing others (but I do hate that idea as well)

I think perhaps that is what brought me to STARS. The mission of STARS is something that I feel passionate about and I really feel like I can accomplish something here. I am motivated to help my mentees in their undergraduate careers and hopefully provide them with excellent guidance as my mentors did for me. I also hope to help the middle school students in SPARCS. I really just want them to have fun with computer science and enjoy it. The more students do that, even if it isn't their career choice, the more the attitudes surrounding the field will change.

Work and play are an interesting dynamic for me. To me play is what I do to keep me sane enough to continue with my work. I need enough play to keep myself happy and enjoying life, otherwise, why bother with the work. I guess this can be a conflicting goal at times. Because sometimes there's too much work to take Jen-time to regain sanity. Ah well, such is the work-life balance dilemma that plagues us all :)

fields.title: Broaden participation in computing
fields.post: By talking to people at an early age, I believe we can edge out any possible bias that may occur against majoring in Computer Science. STARS has several projects steered to doing this: SPARCS - Middle School Outreach which from my understanding is branching out to other schools. The project I am participating in is the Web Development mainly consists of Developing our STARS Website, I believe a key element necessary to spreading our message. Between the site and word of mouth, this explains how our group has expand this far in its 4-5 years of age.

fields.title: Broadening Participation in Computing
fields.post:
Influence is the key hurdle to increase minority representation within the computer science field. In comparison, there are already few women, hispanics, and blacks within the field. This means that for the next generation of minorities, there are few role-models, or positive influences to pursue a career in the computing industry.

How do we break out of this loop?
The minority sector of the computing world must work harder to influence the future generations.
It is not rare to see a military family. The grandfather is army. The father is army. The son and daughter are army. Or even a family business. The trade is passed down; each generation influences the next. This needs to be done in computer science. But, not only in the family. Take your community under your wing. If an individual's mentor or role-model is a computer scientist, computer science is now an option, and may even be a strong one at that.

fields.title: Broadening Participation in Computing
fields.post: Broadening participation in computing, to me, means getting more diverse groups interested in computing fields. The field is currently dominated by certain races, although this is not necessarily a bad thing. The questions remain, why are these races and only these races dominating computing fields? And why are underrepresented races doing all but pursue a computing field? There are numerous answers to these questions, but these questions would be mere statements if participation in computing is broad. Through my STARS projects, I hope to get more students, regardless of race, interested in pursuing a computing field.

fields.title: More computing for everybody: broadening participation in computing
fields.post: The article makes very interesting point on the need for diversity in the computer science field. If few groups are actively innovating the computing field, the resulting products may not be applicable to wide range of social groups, countries, etc. By reaching out to Hispanic students, Benjamin and I will hopefully garner some interest in the field that, due to lack of resources or other reasons, may not have been introduced. If we gain some more Hispanic computer science applicants in the coming years, awesome. If not, perhaps we can at least break some of the stereotypes that come along with computing.

fields.title: Broadening Participation in Computing
fields.post:
STARS exists to broaden participation in computing. To me, an important part of this is not only to attract, but to retain as many people as possible. Over the years, I’ve seen time and again that some percentage of students would give up on a computing major after only taking an introductory course. Some may perceive it as “too hard,” or perhaps there was something they found particularly difficult or hard to understand. A number of these people may have been more inclined to stick with it if given appropriate tutoring support from a peer. I’ve seen people who, given that support, succeeded in their studies, and continued with computing.

This was a primary motivation for my STARS project being the initiation of a tutoring service for introductory programming. I wanted to maximize the opportunity for computing students to have that sort of support.

After 2 weeks off for midterms and fall break, we’re back into tutoring once more, and I’m excited by the upturn in traffic in the past 2 days I’ve been in the lab! Just yesterday, I had the chance to help 4 students to understand their projects. Only time will tell how successful the project will be in terms of helping these students to succeed, and motivating them to continue with computing, but this is encouraging!

fields.title: Broadening Participation in Computing
fields.post:
-What does it mean to "broaden participation in computing"?

We need to understand the problem first in order to solve it. I think BPC means to get more people of the next generation interested in computer science. Computer applications are used in almost every engineering field and many non engineering fields too. But what we need is for the kids to get interested in creating computer applications and softwares.

-How does your STARS project produce an impact?

The SPARCS-2 (Durham Nativity School) project is essentially doing that. We are trying to get 12-14 kids interested in creating computer applications and not just get hem interested in using computers.

-What do you think of the issues and challenges surrounding the BPC initiative?
--Specifically, what do you think of particular points detailed in the
article (such as popular perceptions of computing, academic social
climate in the discipline, etc.)?

The perception sure is not in favor of BPC. We can try to change the perception, but the entire community should take a collective effort towards it. We can definitely make a change in the perspective of a few minds. But the chain effect that it would have is slow. The entire computing community should work towards it. The advantages of working in this field must be highlighted. The perception of "geeky" jobs must be changed to "cool" jobs. The perception of "computing is difficult" must be changed to "computing has the most scope for innovation". The other advantages like job prospects, good pay, etc must be spread to more kids.

-How do you think your life would have been different if you were
exposed to a BPC outreach in your K-12 education?

Actually I did have computer science from primary school. I guess this is what would happen if you are exposed to BPC in K-12: "You would go on to grad school :)".

-To what extent do you think BPC is an ideology or philosophy, versus
a set of concrete steps to improving participation in the field?

BPC I think is a concrete set of steps being applied to small sets of people. The ideology and philosophy behind it must be developed to both support the concrete steps as well as impact a larger audience.

fields.title: Broadening Participation in Computing
fields.post:
To me, broadening participation in computing means to get more people interested and involved in the computing fields. I think that there has been a serious lack in promotions for computer science and other related fields. It is a great idea to get outreach to younger students and get them exposed to computing and the "cool/fun" things it can do.

I think the SPARCS Outreach definitely does this by going to the middle school and getting the children interested in different ideas of computing. We have a diverse group of children who come to the sessions, and they usually have a friends there with them. So I think that having these sessions spread computing to kids who might not know about it otherwise. We try to keep the activities fun and interesting so the students stay intrigued by it.

If I were exposed to BPC outreach in k12 I'm not quite sure how I would have changed. With absolutely no exposure, and actually disincentives to do computer science, I still did it. My whole computer science career decision was based off of my laziness in geometry and one online computer class. I already had other extra curricular activities that kept me busy, so I probably wouldn't have joined the club. Younger students on the other hand would benefit from the program I believe, because they haven't had the opportunity to get involved/ interested in other options that seem 'cooler'. I have to agree that a big opponent to BPC is the geeky stereotypes, so if we get to kids before they start to worry about their 'image' it might work out. Then eventually the demographics of computing could change.

fields.title: Reduce Association with Non-computing
fields.post: Addressing "broaden participation in computing" first requires defining "broaden", "participation", and "computing". (Imagine that.) I would suggest two ways to define, and thus measure, "broaden". One rather straightforward definition is simply "increasing the quantity of", but I think that STARS has a much deeper definition in mind which entails bringing "computing" (whatever it is) to all individuals across the dividing lines that people tend to draw around themselves and others. The definitions of "participation" and "computing" are a bit more difficult, since anyone who "merely interacts" or uses a computer is technically "participating" in "computing". I would tend to think that driving a modern gas-powered vehicle is not really "participating" in "computing", although the operation of the vehicle is heavily dependent upon the fuel-injection computer. I would also contend that using a computer in the workplace is not "computing". The best I can suggest is that "participation" in "computing" is intentional and pre-meditated use of transistor-based calculating devices for their intended purpose with the goal of improving "computing". (Recursion!) For example, decorating a wall with CPUs is the intentional and pre-mediated use of transistor-based calculating devices, but CPUs are designed as wall decorations, so "decorative computing" doesn't count. Neither does using a computer in the workplace since from a purely egotistical standpoint I would like to think that my "participation" in "computing" is a little more than that of those who use a computer to type letters, answer email, and otherwise waste their hours at work amusing themselves with online games. I would ultimately and frustratingly say that to "broaden participation in computing" is to extend whatever "computing" means to a larger and more diverse population of individuals. So next time you drive a modern gas-powered vehicle relish the time you spend "computing" in traffic.

fields.title: BPC: Methods vs Madness?
fields.post:
During my most recent mentor meeting with Jen, we discussed the mostly interesting article on "Broadening Participation in Computing" and its subtopics about the issue of establishing some sort of systemic approach with set milestones to broaden participation versus encouraging the mindset behind the aforementioned goal.
In my opinion the article does a good job discussing and providing evidence to support the current situation in computing and its slight improvements over the years: the image of computing as well as the numbers of minorities involved in the computing fields. However, when the idea of somehow forcing a curriculum of computing intended to broaden (ie, pull in more minority students) participation is mentioned, my reaction is to shy away from the method and more toward simply encouraging the natural social evolution (the mindset toward computers and those who study them). This latter ideal can be immensely effective: think of how the stereotype of a computer geek got started in the first place, and then think of how to generate a new one: the hot geeky chick. Hollywood for one has been quite instrumental, and as recently as this summer we are beginning to see this image shift.
I don't think it possible to mandate and structure and set goals to bring in more minorities into computer science. It seems a wasteful effort, and we should instead reach out in general to younger students, yet with an emphasis placed on improving the image to a more widely desirable one.

fields.title: BPC is gooooooood
fields.post: Broadening participation in computing is an extremely good cause. It seems my experience is a little unique, but in my school system in Alabama, there was NO mention of computer science. I was not exposed to the topic until I was an undergraduate. That being said, I think the BPC initiative is so much more than just broadening participation among underrepresented groups. It can also include other students that are not interested in computer science strictly because of lack of exposure. Therefore, all the service and outreach projects that we do as an alliance are excellent. Computing is such an interesting and applicable field, it is hard to not find one aspect of it intriguing. This mindset was further confirmed through my first experience with SPARCS. This past weekend we had our first SPARCS session and I was extremely nervous that the students would find the material boring. I could not have been more incorrect. The students were completely engaged in the material and asked millions of questions about computing and its different applications. This was a great feeling and helps me to maintain confidence in the mission of STARS.

fields.title: Broadening Participation
fields.post:
Stars was established with a goal and support from the NSF to broaden Computer Science education in the country because for some reasons or another, we seem to be falling behind compared to other nations.

So how do we change this? as Stars member there is very little we can do individually, but as stars groups we can probably influence a few group of young minds to see the importance and relevance of Computer Science in their lives. Multiply this group effect by the number of STARS affiliated universities currently participating in STARS across the U.S who are conducting outreach programs and we might get a substantial effect.

But how many universities are affiliated with STARS Alliance? There are approximately only 20 STARS Alliance member (universities). So how effective is the NSF goals?

There is no way of telling how effective the program is, or how many minds we have changed. But with benefits we can see so far, I think there is great potential for success. Take for instance, the NCSU STARS middle school outreach program, each semester they involved at least 18-25 students from a middle school in learning and introducing programming concepts, robotics, and games. By the end of the semester, a survey is taken and a majority of the students expressed their desire to participate in the program in the future. Although we can't accommodate the same sets of students again, we know that the students coming out of these programs are likely to take their interest into their high school careers where they will continue on to take AP courses and programming and preparing way for colleges; doing away with the need for remedial courses once they get to college.

Last year NCSU has only one of these program, but now there is about three groups doing middle school outreach. So this is good.

For women broadening participation, STARS have more female students now because of the recruitments at poster events etc. from last year. If we keep on doing what we did last year with recruitments, embedding ourselves into poster pies and other student organized event on campus, we will continue to garner more interest.

In the end, if NSF wants its goal of participation to have greater success, it should do more at the middle and high school level. That is where students really begin to explore their interests. If and when they get into college, they have already made up their mind, otherwise they wouldn't have come so while the program is very important at the university level to create a sense of identity and community for computer science students, it does not do much to increase computer science interest or participations.

fields.title: BPC, STARS and interdisciplinary work
fields.post:
"Broadening Participation in Computing," to me, seems like a modern social agenda with at least two clear goals: a) increasing the sheer volume of people in the field of computing, and b) making the composition more diverse. And here diverse covers several different dimensions - gender, age, background, culture, etc. I'm not aware of any similar thrusts in other fields, for example "Broadening Participation in Agriculture" or something of that sort, but people who argued for and successfully founded the BPC effort did have a good case to make. Like all academic and research efforts, it was good to see scientific studies being cited to justify their claims. This gives the whole thing a research project outlook too.

I do by and large agree with the main issues that have been brought up. Only the way they talked about stereotypes was somewhat too generalized, I believe. The perceptions of such stereotypes, in my opinion, is limited to certain levels in the academic and professional hierarchy. After a certain point, say when you enter grad school, these stereotypes just cease to exist. I'm not saying there aren't exceptions, but that's the usual case. People engaged in state-of-the-art research - be it in academia or industry - have a lot to worry about already. I do agree with their interpretation of "gender" in the social context, but if you look at it, computing is a relatively recent field, so traditional practices and social norms related to shouldn't even exist. At best, we are still in the process of forming such norms. But the sad reality is the perception of computer science, as pointed out, is misrepresentative - and this incorrect picture is what draws all the stereotypes and social norms.

The best thing about STARS is that the main actors as well as policy makers in this program are mostly students and their faculty mentors who are situated very close to the target audience. It's not a program being run by government officials alone or other external agents. Student members of the leadership core are likely to have faced the same kind of challenges and problems that STARS aims to alleviate, and so they can be expected to come up with more realistic and effective grass-root solutions.
