The level of autonomy given to SLC students in choosing their projects is really awesome. At the same time, regular meetings and the annual celebration help us stay focused on the broad goals. The CSC 116 Tutoring initiative that I am part of this time, is definitely very important and useful. I think of 116 (and other early college) students as having just started a decathlon of sorts, and we as tutors are helping them with a gentle push to clear the hurdles that come their way. Just like fumbling on a real hurdle can both slow you down and be depressing at the same time, I believe without this kind of low-level support (besides good instruction) students can get eventually de-motivated.

Interdisciplinary work plays an important role achieving BPC goals, as it gives every individual a self-motivating perspective of computing. Human cognition is largely grounded in perceptions, and rarely are people able to think at a strictly abstract level. So someone who is better adapted to understanding problems in neuroscience for example maybe better able to get involved in computational work that tries to solve neurological problems. In fact, with the current state of affairs, if an area expert (such as a neurosurgeon) can express their problem-at-hand in precise medical terms then it can subsequently be interpreted by computer scientists (such as knowledge engineers) to come up with computing-based solutions without the area expert having to understand in too much detail how computers work. Such modular combinations and interactions between different fields has a very promising future. As a bonus, it helps bring different kinds of people into computing.

fields.title: BPC
fields.post:
The Broadening Participation In Computing initiative is a beyond great ides for students K-12 because it gets kids interested in computing and computer science at an early age, which is the only way that the profession can continue to progress successfully and gain new employees.

I feel that my life could of been forever changed if I was exposed to a program similar to the BPC initiative at a young age. I really didn't become interested in computing til about 8th grade to high school. I always knew that I liked working with computer and enjoyed math and science but never really thought deeply about what I was going to do with the rest of my life. A program like the BPC initiative could of forced me to push myself harder at a young age as well as informed me to so many other concepts that I have no clue about. I truly do believe that real knowledge is gained at an earlier age and that its the most effective way to learn.

I wish that more schools in the public school system would follow the role model that the BPC initiative set and acquire programs in their schools similar to this one. A lot of young students get discouraged quickliy in school which forever alters their outlook on a certain subject. Instead these students should be given several avenues of exposure into the subject so that they can learn about every aspect and not just completely knock down the idea because of one situation. As a college student I do my best to motivate younger children to stay in school, stay positive and to do what they love to do but it takes more than one person to encourage and help others grow successfully.

fields.title: Broadening Participation in Computing
fields.post:
Broadening Participation in Computing

"Broaden participation in computing" means a lot. It goes beyond just trying to get underrepesentated groups involved in computer science. I think in or to broaden computer science you need to change peoples minds of what computer science is. Most of my friends have a very limited closed minded view of computer science that they have picked up. Based on what they think computer science is they wouldn't want to be invovled in it. If they knew that computer science was more then just programming and making/playing video games then it might be something that they would have considered as a major or minor.

This is one of the main reasons why I like the idea of SPACS. It shows middle school students, their teachers, and parents that there is more to computer science and that it might be something that they are interested in.

Two things that I have personally have seen are popular misconceptions of computing and academic social climate in the discipline. As I've already stated there are perceptions of computer science and of "who" computer sciencists are. It is became of these perceptions that some people don't see computer science as a possible field for them.

If I was exposed to BPC in K-12 I would have been more confiedent in doing computing as a major then I was. I would have also known more about computing and the possible fields inside of computing then what I knew when coming to college.

fields.title: Broadening Participation in Computing
fields.post: Broadening participation in computing is a means of making it available to all individuals despite ethnicity, geographical location, and native language. This shows that any and everyone can be a computer scientist through hard work and dedication. My STARS project makes an impact by allowing me to focus in on a topic of personal interest and exploring how it relates to society. Hopefully my research will be an avenue for prospective computer scientists to want to research the vast amount of possibilities that computer science has to offer. I think that BPC did a great job hitting on the issues and problems surrounding the computing profession. The mere fact that computer science is generally perceived as lacking creativity shows the lack of knowledge that outsiders have on the IT world. This also stems from the fact that computers are typically advertised as something used to simplify equations and/or format papers. Whereas dance, music, and theatre are shown as traditional forms of displaying one's creative ability. Had I been exposed to a BPC outreach at an earlier age, I would have the essentials necessary venture out on my own. I would then be able to focus on enhancing my prior knowledge which would in return give me an advantage against my peers.

fields.title: Broadening Participation in Computing
fields.post:
Well this week’s blog comes right back to one of the reasons I joined STARS. To broaden participation in computing is what STARS is all about but to be honest it seems like a vague statement. It can definitely be interpreted in many different ways. For me broadening participation means adding diversity to the field. To some extent this is the reason for the Hispanic Outreach I wanted to work on. Going to the STARS Celebration made me see how underrepresented Hispanics are in the computing field. Our goal with the Hispanic Outreach is therefore to change some of the stereotypes of what careers Hispanics can pursue and encourage them to pursue degrees in computing.
However, as the article we read pointed out changing these stereotypes cannot only come from the teachers. Programs have to be implemented that teach courses in context relevant to specific groups. Also mentoring programs and informal student groups must be encouraged to give students a sense of belonging once in the field. While I still personally believe that those who are truly interested in computing will pursue a career in it despite not receiving outreach or any assistance the fact remains that there are students who have no idea what career to follow and perhaps because they are misinformed about what a career in computing can translate into they are not even considering computing as an option. It is these students that we must target and let them know how exciting a career in computing can really be.

fields.title: Motivation
fields.post:
If anyone's seen Heroes, then they may recall that one of the characters can see why people "tick". So what makes me tick?

Well, one factor is my family and friends. I think there's a stereotype out there that Asian parents have higher expectations and are more demanding. I'm not sure if this is true for other people, but my parents, as well as other family members, have always pushed me to do the best that I can in school. They have very high expectations. They've worked hard in order to provide me with opportunities and to support me. Therefore, I feel pressured to do the best that I can as to not disappoint them and make their efforts worthwhile. This external pressure turns into motivation, since I'm afraid of failing and letting them down. I also think that my friends, as well as society as a whole, also influence me. I've always done decent, if not well, in school, so I think people just expect me to keep that up. I also don't want to fail while I see others succeed, so I guess it's a sense of competition as well. (Although in recent years, I've started to care less about this friends factor, I'm not sure why?)

However, the motivation from friends and family is all external. While it certainly helps to push me forward sometimes, I don't think that's enough, for anyone. People need to be motivated internally, and that's what makes a difference. To be quite honest, I feel so lazy sometimes and feel tired of having to do all the things I have to do. I would wish that everyday, I could just lay down in a field, under a tree on a nice sunny, breezy day and watch the clouds drift by. As nice as that sounds, I've yet to do it. I guess internally, I just don't want to quit since I've always hated quitting. I know that I have the potential to do more, and that it would just be wasteful if I gave up and just started watching clouds. There are other people who don't have the opportunity that I have, so I want to use it to do all I can to make it worthwhile. I guess I also enjoy the sense of accomplishment when I've been able to get through something.

Additionally, although it's a little fuzzy at the moment, my life-long dream is to be able to help under-privileged people, especially children. I want to make a difference in the world and help a few people to have the same kind of opportunities as I have had. I want to start a school or something like that in other countries, since I believe that education is the way to go. I wonder if that sounds naive, but I really hope that I can do so.

So I guess at the end of the day, although my family and friends help to keep me on track, I just simply don't want to quit but instead I want make use of my capabilities and opportunities that I have so that in the future, I can give others the same opportunities. I guess that's what makes me tick, and besides, who says I can't take a break to watch a few clouds anyways?

fields.title: Why Do I Do What I Do?
fields.post:
Last time (or the time before, or something), you got a small peek into my busy life. I’m sure the 5 of you who are reading this are by now convinced that I’m insane. So why do I do all of this?

I’m really not sure how to explain it in words, but if I’m not busy, I’m usually bored, and not feeling like I’m doing enough.

I think my basic motivation is to make wherever I happen to be a better place. At the moment, that happens to be NC State, its Computer Science Department, and the computing community as a whole. STARS certainly fulfills the third one (and arguably the second).

The only ultimate (post-NCSU) goal I can think of at the moment is to become faculty somewhere. There are plenty of short-term goals I have, some of which further that, though others don’t. Outside of my coursework, my activities typically have the common goal of making something/somewhere better somehow. That motivation never changes. STARS has given me the chance to help computing by providing tutorial support to newer computing students, and I hope I can help grow the computing community (making it “better”).

fields.title: What motivates me
fields.post:
I think the common myth of America is that we are all motivated primarily by money. And to a point, what we do, especially in a global sense, does nothing to stop the propagation of that impression. Our largest companies (to pull in computers here, take Microsoft for an example), employ any and all means to obtain the largest market share possible whether in the US or abroad. Students (and their parents) pay thousands upon thousands of dollars for an education that is intended to then turn around and begin filling their pockets back up with thousands more. Now, this is by no measure the only motivation for a person to pursue a college education and/or career in computing -- but it does occupy a large portion of the industry's mind.
My own personal motivation right now (because, as we all know, motivations are what help shape us and they do change over time), lies in two main areas. First, that I use my time wisely in college, this gift of education, to learn what I can and then be able to use it for good once I'm done with school. Through this learning process (which includes research and volunteering through STARS as well as coursework) it's my hope to figure out how exactly I can apply my computer science and physics knowledge to serving others. Second, that I enjoy what I do. We as human beings are designed to work, and as such finding an area or aspect of work that we enjoy to the fullest is most important.

fields.title: Lucy's motivation
fields.post:
My motivation is definitely my happiness.

I have always measured my success in happiness, and therefore, that is what motivates me. Interestingly, happiness has been my motivator for every goal in my life. That being said, several things in my life influence my happiness and thus motivation. These include my family, close friends, research/class accomplishments, my dog, service projects, as well as numerous other things.

Having a broad pool of motivators is important. If we rely on just one primary motivator, what happens if it for some reason disappears. Multiple things should attribute to your drive in the event one falls short. Also, it is important to maintain all the contributing factors to ensure the "pool of motivators" does not decrease. For instance, maintaining strong relationships with my friends and family takes effort. Sometimes that effort interferes with accomplishing other tasks; however, it is a sacrifice I must be willing to make.

This logic is what led me to STARS. After moving to Raleigh, I left all my service projects in Memphis. Therefore, that aspect of my "motivational pool" was missing. I found STARS to not only be in line with my passion for community outreach but also a venue to fulfill internal satisfaction, or happiness. Again, although my STARS involvement is a time restraint that sometimes conflicts with other events, it is important to me to maintain my service commitment.

Although I find myself not being happy all the time, I find it is extremely relative. Moreover, if one aspect of my life is not necessarily yielding happiness, by drawing upon my pool, I find other things can provide surrogate motivation for the time being. Moreover, happiness from other factors often leads me to be motivated enough to overcome things lacking in my life contributing to deficient happiness.

fields.title: What Motivates Jasmine...
fields.post:
So I had a good idea of what I wanted to say about this earlier this week but after an incident yesterday I really discovered another really true answer to this.

What I brainstormed earlier this week was that my parents, friends, or anyone that is important in my life is what ultimately motivates me. My parents have always been supportive and always wanted to see my succeed. If I am ever in trouble or confused about an issue I can go to them and I know that they will pick me back up and get me refocused on the light at the end of the tunnel. There are probably the hugest motivators in my life besides my friends. My best friends also motivate me to be Jasmine. When they see me down they are to talk to and reassure me that everything will work out at the end.

Besides other people I am motivated by my passions and high goals and standards that I have set for my life. I know where I want to be 5-10 years down the road so I don't let anything stop me from getting there. Yes I am hard on myself at times but I continuously push myself harder and harder so that I can get to the outcome that I wish to reach. I'm motivated by unexpected challenges that are thrown in my life and refuse to give up on anything. Im a finisher not a quitter. Self-motivation really is what drives me on a daily basis. I have seen those that struggle and that could of done so much more with their life with that extra motivation and I don't want to end living life with a whole bunch of "should of would of could ofs".

The last thing that motivates me has to deal with the incident that I mentioned before. Yesterday I was in one of my engineering labs and the comment was made from another student about why they were in ECE. I responded to the student with the same mentality. After a rough week and I had wondered why am I in this major and I shared it with the student. The student responds yes I dont know why you are in ECE either, you are a girl. So I thought he was joking and waited for the just kidding but it didn't follow. So I then realized that was another source of motivation. People who make ridiculous comments like those and doubt my abilities motivate me and encourage me to strive for success. I'm the type of person that wants to prove people wrong because I know that I am capable of getting through this major and obtaining a degree and doing anything I put my mind to. Also comments like those motivate me through the concept of mentoring, something I am very passionate about. It bothers me tremendously that so many young girls shy away from engineering and computer science because ignorant people, like the previously mentioned student, bring that mentality their way. If I could speak to every girl on this planet about that I would because so many females miss that opportunity to do something they love because of a stereotype. So being a role-model and example for younger girls and showing them that a female getting an engineering degree can be done and just being able to share my journey to the degree and story motivates me as well. I strive hard but I work harder.

fields.title: Kat's motivation.
fields.post: My prime motivation, I think, is the rush I get when I've overcome a challenge. That challenge could be anything, really: it could be completing a programming project, learning how to knit lace perfectly, repeating homework problems until I have the correct answers, etc. I like to push myself, and I'm incredibly stubborn by nature. Sometimes that can be detrimental, as it's very hard for me to step back and admit, "I can't do this." But I think my stubbornness gives me an edge, and once I finish some goal I've pushed myself towards, there is no greater feeling in the world. And when I look back and think, "Wow, finally finishing (insert task here) made me feel great," that just gets me motivated to start something new again.

fields.title: Motivation AnyOne?
fields.post:
For some reason, I found it difficult to answer, so I posed the question on one of my friends. What she said came off as more like a poem, but I think it is worth stating.
For a car to be driven, it needs fuel, stable mechanics and a somewhat skilled driver. A car is like my motivation. My fuel is the desire to succeed, the fear of failure and hope to achieve the goals that I set before me. The stable mechanics are my thirst for knowledge, because without knowledge of what I want to achieve their is no fuel to drive me. The somewhat skilled driver is me. With my knowledge and my fuel I know that I can go the distance. The distance is the goal, my success, my goal achieved.
I think this is true for everyone, at least everyone should be able to find a similarity with it.

fields.title: Motivation
fields.post: I would contend that almost all motivations can be reduced to the pursuit of happiness. There are some instances where the validity of this reduction is debatable, but discussion of these sticky cases often leads to some rather unusual conversation about sociopaths. In either case, simply stating "happiness" is rather boring, so I would select "achievement" as my primary motivation. I like to acquire new skills and learn stuff in general. If this motivation were removed, I would probably shrivel up and die in all seriousness. I like novelty, and if I were unable to develop new skills or learn new things, I would become considerably unhappy.

fields.title: Motivation
fields.post:
There are many things that motivates me. I'm constantly changing and doing different things. I may become interest in one thing say knitting or something and be motivated at learning more about it. Sometimes I stay motivated to these things, sometimes it is more of a passing thing.

My friends, family and society also motivate me. They motivate me to do various things both academic and not. I would say that I'm largely motivated by those that I choose to hang out with. Their opinions, feelings, and thoughts matter to me. I try to do well in school because of the motivation my parents gave me growing up. I want to make them proud.

I'm not really sure what if anything I'm in pursuit of. Mostly I think I'm just trying to find my way.

fields.title: My Motivation
fields.post:
Just like everyone, I am motivated, to be happy all the time. But unlike most people I am happy irrespective of what is going on in my life. If I get frustrated or lose my cool it is very momentary and I get back to my happy state very soon.

There a list of other motivators for me. I am constantly trying to expand on my knowledge of anything and everything. There is a saying in my native tongue (Tamil), that “what you know is only a fistful, and what you are yet to learn is as big as the ocean”. “Quest for Knowledge” is a big motivator for me. Another motivator for me is the ability to make a change in someone’s life. I think STARS is a great place for that.

The people who I look up to as idols, to keep myself motivated are:
Gandhi, Stephen Colbert, and my brother. Gandhi for his sheer brilliance and perseverance, Colbert for his satirical commentary, and my brother for his hard working nature.

fields.title: Competitive Motivation
fields.post:
I'm of competitive nature. I find all those around me, whether in a social or academic environment to be competitors. I'm of the belief that everyone wants a slice of the pie, and there's only one; I have to beat out everyone else.

There are times I get distracted, but its never for too long. I keep my eyes (yes, both of them) on the prize. And if I don't collect it, someone else will. That's what motivates me.

fields.title: My Motivation
fields.post:
I consider life itself to be a reason enough for us all to keep doing interesting things. We're lucky to be the kind of intelligent creatures we are, and it only makes sense to utilize our faculties constructively. But among the millions of things we can do with our time, we choose a handful and focus on them more. The simplest and most common reason behind picking a particular thing to do, I believe, is one's self interest. And I am no different.

My primary sense of motivation for most of the things I do comes from my interest in those activities. I am generally not looking forward to specific goals or achievements, rather I try to enjoy the experience itself. Computing and computer science has become a major factor in my life for this very reason. I don't know why or how, but anything related to computers just about drives me crazy. Nobody needs to tell me or push me when it comes to bits and bytes. Recently I have discovered that I am also getting interested in more abstract and inter-disciplinary aspects of computer science, including logic & reasoning, cognition, etc. Again, I don't know why or where such interests originate from, but they quickly become factors in deciding what I do in the short term as well as long term.

Although this kind of self interest is a good source of motivation, it is by no means the only one. And it better not be! Luckily, I also like trying out diverse activities, which opens a lot of doors for me. At times, I also feel like making a significant contribution to the world - be it academically or otherwise. And probably the most important of all, I do realize that there is a long list of well-wishers - my family & friends - who want to see me do well in life and feel proud when I accomplish something great. All this sort of balances my somewhat narrow self-motivation and keeps me on the right track.

fields.title: My Motivation
fields.post: What motivates me is the drive that my mom and grandpa placed in me to succeed at an early age. They always pushed me to my limits and continue to do so even today. Over the years I have seen how hard work and dedication have made lives easier through achieving post undergrad degrees, building a dream house, etc. In order for me to have the finer things in life as well as give back to the community, I promised myself to never give up! One of the main reasons why I applied to be in STARS, was the opportunity to do community outreach with students who shared a passion for technology. My approach to work and play is simple, you work hard and you play even harder! Whenever I sense myself loosing motivation I think about those who look up to me as a role model as well as elderly family and friends who congratulate my mom on raising a young gentlemen to keep me going.

fields.title: What motivates me???
fields.post:
Life is as beautiful as we want it to be...
When we are happy, we ignore the little problems and smile as though we have never seen tears....
When we are restless and dissatisfied, we crib about the smallest of things and forget to enjoy little sweet moments in life.

Most of us need a gentle push to "live" life :) I am no different. As I sat down to answer this question "What motivates me?"- I tried to recollect moments, when I was forced to "move on" and take back my selfish complaints against life.

Here is one such incident. These were days almost 4-5 years ago when I was all disappointed with the work at office, the politics, the attitude of people, the long hours at work and the unavoidable working weekends. To top this, I was having some issues at home, some friends behaving weird ....as they say when something goes wrong, you feel as though the entire creation is against your happiness. That particular weekend, I went with my youth group to volunteer at a home meant for destitute women. We had a role-play and some short interactive sessions with the ladies there. It definitely felt nice to see some smiles and also gave me some satisfaction to see them involving themselves in the activities. As we were leaving, a lady came up to me and said, "Thank you for coming. We had a nice time". I was blank for a moment….then looked at her and smiled. I had observed that she was making a conscious effort to listen to us all through the session. She looked at the clothes that we were distributing and called her friend who had a 9-month old baby. As we were trying to find some appropriate clothing, she narrated something that none of us can forget. She had lost her baby just two weeks ago because they could not get to a doctor in time. She pointed outside the window towards the place where she buried her 12-month old. There was no frustration, no anger nor any hatred in her words. We did not have the slightest of idea that something this tragic could have happened with her. There was silence all around and we did not know what to say. I was thinking about all the little things that were affecting me so much and at once felt how foolish I had been. She heard her friend’s baby cry and walked away almost naturally to pick the baby and console her. This was one of those eye-openers in my life. It was as if this scene was scripted to make me realize that there is so much more in life than the little things that I was cribbing about.

There have been many such moments which have forced me to stop, breathe and open my eyes to inspiring situations. There is so much to learn from people around us....there is so much to absorb into our systems and learn to be grateful for what we have. This definitely changed the way I looked at problems (and even those hyped situations which we assume as "problems") and at life in general. It’s moments like these that motivate me to put aside my problems, put aside the thousand things that may be going on in my life and spend some time to help others in need (and eventually help myself). This is what keeps me going and this is what helps me replenish my batteries :)

fields.title: I have three motivations...
fields.post:
Motivation... that's a word that I use to associate with the many things that I care about. Before I start listing what my motivations are I should begin first with the definition I think best fits this word; Using define feature with Google search, I narrowed down my favorite definition, and here's what Google have to say (fourth word down):

"Motivation is the internal condition that activates behavior and gives it direction; and energizes and directs goal-oriented behavior. .."

People's motivations are as different from each other as the number of finger print patterns in the world(never the same!). To some, maybe it is the desire to achieve some sort of goal, to reach some sort of final destination they envisioned; but in such an interpretation, motivation becomes just a mere reward. Something objectifiable, physical, and strangely materialistic to me.

I don't view motivation from that angle, that is why I like the fourth definition from Google. To me, motivation isn't the rewards I see at the end of the line, it's not something that I will finally get after successive executions of years of planning. Heck, I don't think I could ever go on If my motivations had such a far out distant reward, no matter how great that reward would be.

Instead, my motivation is something I care about, intrinsically, things that I felt and know everyday in my heart to be true and permanent. These things are rewarding at every point of consciousness to me.

These things are: Family, Ambitions(vague, but I'll explain), and Other people.

Family: I can achieve everything i could ever want in life, but with no family to share my joy it would be worthless to me. Knowing that I am studying, or working, or doing whatever I am doing will be shared among my family drives me to preserve in all things I need to do.

Ambitions:
Wait... you might want to say.. isn't that what motivation is all about? Aren't you just using one of the synonyms of motivation to define motivation? No, not really. Since every thing that motivates me is internal, my ambition isn't about finding some place great or ending some where grand in life.

My ambition is out-do myself everyday in every permutations of life's experience. Knowing that I will wake each day to get a chance of knowing something I didn't know the day before, to be reveal of things I couldn't possibly imagine a year ago and to discover things about myself as I grow with time is the most precious and urging of desire to me. Education is simply a tool to help me realize this ambition. I study, work, live, and observe, just so I can grow and become better than I was from the past. The chance to grow is one of the greatest motivation that drives my study and life. I'm not here to challenge anyone or demean any soul, I wish everyone grows, and I especially hope this for myself. There is a saying: "I do not try to dance better than anyone else. I only try to to dance better than myself." For me, this is my life statement, this is what directs my action and motivates me to study.

Finally, the third major source of my motivation- Other People.
For as introverted as I am, I cannot imagine what my life would be like if I had no one around to laugh with me and share their stories, tears or jubilation. I feel connected to people, I empathize with people. In every person, is a parallel reality of my life, it is a possible path of existence for me. The person who's standing in the sheering sun begging for alms, the woman who lost her child, the guy who didn't have a house, the boy who can't see; they're all apart of me. I suppose if you believe that every soul belongs to god, then each of us is just another manifestation of the same being. How can you not feel but a need to help others out then?

The need to help other people and lift them up and share their experience motivates me. This can manifest in many ways to me, doing community work, joining youth groups, participating in activist etc. I work hard because I know that the more I achieve out of life, the more I can give to those I love and those I don't know.

Those are my three motivations. I am not the type of person that can operate on a definite goal, or finite vision. I cannot find myself to pick a grand destination and get excited to work towards it and see that it's eventual fruition would make me happy. My personality requires me to be happy and motivated presently in the movement, and for that, I rely on family, personal ambition, and other people. These three things diverge and branch off into all the other wishes, desires, actions and behaviors that defines me.

I am not motivated by a final destination, but by sheer gratefulness of being blessed with life. But, I suppose this view can seem pretty dull and naive to goal oriented and success-driven people.

fields.title: "What motivates...ME?"
fields.post:
"What motivates ME?"

My everyday goal in life is to pursue happiness. Although I have
my good days and my bad days ultimatly, life is good. My natural
happy attitude helps in my day-to-day journey's wherever I may go.
My pursuit is happiness is just the beginning. It is the center
of pursuit and it is what drives me when things get rough.

A chance for a better opportunity is what brought me to STARS.I feel
it will give me a better perspective on my career goals and maybe
just a little bit closer to what I am trying to accomplish.

There is always time for work and always time for play. Differing
between the 2 is the hard part and the key to my success. Every
decision has its consequences. When I am hard at work I feel
accomplished and focused. I feel like im on task and I have to finish
in order to play and relax. Not only is that how school work
but thats how the career world works. I want to be able to work
in my career and enjoy my job and inturn enjoy all my benefits, whether
that be a big house, money, time with family or long vacations.
As I continue to grow up and maintain my values it gets a little
easier to balance and stay balanced between work and play.

School gets hard and computer science has been a bit discouraging
no matter how much it is my passion. But when it gets hard
my family and my community who supports me no matter what
continues to be my drive. I can't let them down is what goes
through my head and my heart, and I find strength to continue.

My sister is a big inspiration and motivator in my life.
She has accomplished so much and continues everyday.
She is married and has 2 jobs, plus she is going back
to school to further her education. That is alot to handle
at one time and I admire her determination and strength.

Although I have many sources of motivation, all of them are
my fuel to keep going. They all come from different aspects of
my life, whether it be my family and friends who support me no
matter what, or it could be the people who look at me and say
I can't do it. Either way, I'm motivated because I am determined
to come out on top!

fields.title: My motivation
fields.post:
I dont thing that there is one single thing that motivates me. Sure the support of my family is a great motivator for me to go out and reach my goals. I guess the goals themeselves are also motivations. If I see something someone has already done or that I know CAN be done then Im not motivated to reach for that but show me something that cant be done, show me something that everyone agrees is just imposible or highly unlikely and that's what I want to shoot for.

A quick example of this was last semester when I decided to push myself and take 18 credit hours instead of the regular 12. My family and friends thought I was crazy and there was no way I could hope to do well but that's exactly what I did ending up with all As. So in a way prooving everyone wrong is something that motivates me.

One last thing that I could say that motivates me is the people around me. I've seen people, I know people, Im good friends with people that life has just decided to roundhousekick and pull them away from their dreams. And so I look at myself who has everything going for him and nothing holding me back and I say "Why the heck can't I do everything I aspire to?". If people who have everything going against them are still fighting with everything they have for their dreams then why shouldnt I.

fields.title: What motivates me?
fields.post: The pursuit of my dreams is my main motivation. I aspire to create my own business, although I'm not really sure as to what the concept is at the moment. I am very sure that it will entail me going into graduate school, which is my first course. I've heard one of the greatest helps for getting into graduate school. I have landed a few research opportunities and am on my 3rd research project. I also wish to get some professional industry experience before heading into graduate school as well. In the end, the dreams I have set for myself will be the prime motivators in my life.

fields.title: My Motivation
fields.post:
Motivation, that's an odd thing to me, and I'm not quite sure why I have it. I'm not in the pursuit of happiness for sure, because that makes it seem like I don't already have happiness. And if anything I caught happiness, wrestled it to the ground and now we're BFF's. Happiness isn't even qualified to be my shadow because it doesn't go away when things get dark; it's just there, not to be pursued but shared and enjoyed.

I am most definitely my own motivation. I think I want to be 'oh so awesome' just because I can. All my excuses died so I have nothing holding me back. No longer is everyone of my desicions a matter of life and death. My life has been flying under the radar for the last two decades, and it's continuing under the radar. And when I get out, I want to be like fireworks and the world will be amazed. I'm not one to fizzle like alkaseltzer and sit on the sidelines. I'm a rocket of energy flying high and making people think twice.

If my motivation goes away, there is nothing driving my efforts. I don't have people who I have to please. I'm not held to any standards. My life is so cushy now, that I could screw up, flunk out of college, runaway from home, become mediocre, and that would be just fine. I'm not going to do that all, but I could if I wanted to.

Every once in a blue moon I'll find someone who I truly admire. I think though, that since I have a different big picture than regular people, it's easy for me to brush off what some people might consider "meaningful things," like helping the poor and building homes in 3rd world countries. That being said, the number of people I have admired has been relatively low. When I was little I admired Martha Stewart, I'd wake up early just to watch her show. I thought her need for perfection was spectacular. Anyone can be ordinary, but to go that extra mile and be perfect that's what counts. When cancer gets 'cured', it won't be from someone who was average, they aren't going to settle for a treatment plan that works on 71.2% of the cases. No, they are going make a cure that works ALL of the time, because thats what cures do; that's how perfection goes.

My number one personal goal in life has the capability to grow after I accomplish it, and I'm 90% sure that it will awlays be my main goal. I know I can't/don't want to try to, accomplish my goal for at least another 5 years so I will work on semi-unrelated sub goals until then. I usually have the same amount of motivation in any goal I have. I might have more fun in tasks that pertain to my interests, but I'm not going to slack on effort or motivation just because I don't like something. I work even harder, so I can get boring things done and over with.

Overall, my motivation is myself. My life has been the craziest rollercoaster ride, and it has the potential to be a best selling novel, a lifetime original movie event, a thing worth watching out for. And I'm not one to crush my own potential. I want to be a spark that ingnites future dreamers and leads them on to thier own stories.

"Be like the fountain that overflows, not like the cistern that merely contains."
~ Paulo Coelho from Veronika Decides to Die

fields.title: Semester Goals
fields.post:
After discussing my current project with Dr. Xie, we decided it be best I pursue the iTutor project. The project name will probably change into something less random in the near future. iTutor strives to expose behavioral differences between 2 solutions to a given problem, thus helping to teach students. I will be working with another member of the group, Kamar, as well as another undergraduate student who I believe isn't in STARS.

Project Blog:
http://asereu.blogspot.com/

Project Goals:
- Build and implement a working demo
- Present findings to both the ASE and STARS groups

Other Goals:
- Keep the straight A's streak going
- Get a car
- Get a co-op in industry

fields.title: My Goals for the Semester
fields.post:
This is my first year in STARS and I hope to have an enjoyable, educational experience in the program. I'm also trying to balance a very busy course load as well as looking at grad schools. To sum it up:

Academics:
-Get a 4.0 semester GPA (as well as maintaining my current GPA or even raise it)
-Be more prepared for classes by doing the readings
-Stop procrastinating
-Look at grad schools/job opportunities
-Talk to faculty members about my area of interests
-Keep focused and make this a very productive good last year as an undergrad.

STARS:
I'm not very sure of the specific goals as of right now, but in general, I hope to:
-Be involved and actively participate
-Meet everyone (since I couldn't attend the celebration)
-Learn more about STARS
-Have fun

I also hope to have some free time to do some fun projects on my own. I want to explore iPhone app developments just for fun. I would also like to have a more consistently sleeping schedule if possible, but I guess that ties into how well I am at not procrastinating. I guess we'll see how well everything works out when I look back at this post in a month or so. =)

fields.title: Goals for Fall Semester
fields.post:
Whew, there's a lot to get done this semester, so my primary goal is to do it all without getting overly stressed or losing sight of the big picture. That said...

SPARCS
- have a well-developed webpage that students, parents and mentors find easy to use and with a lot of information
- provide mentors with the tools, information and support necessary to really help our students
- collect good data that can be used to improve the program in the future
- engage the middle school students and IMPROVE RETENTION!!!!

REU w/ Veronica
- ensure that Veronica is working on stuff that is interesting and will help her in the future
- get Veronica FACS certified
- come up with cool stuff to do next semester

Class
- A++

TAing
- create cool problem sessions for students that are really helpful
- prepare excellent lesson plans for probabilistic reasoning chapters
- get good reviews from students

Research
- maybe one or two publications would be nice this semester, but with everything else, that might be pushing it

Personal
- keep with the wedding planning timeline
- get enough sleep (ideally 8 hrs/night)

Given the amount of stuff I want to do, it seems like having a monthly checkin with these goals would be really helpful. I think I will assess them at the beginning of October to see how well I'm doing.

fields.title: Fall 2009 - Things to do
fields.post:
STARS things to do:

  • Evaluation work:
    • Support other SLC students in collecting data regarding their activities
    • Interview one lucky SLC student during the semester
    • Share the above work with Jimmy
  • CSC116 tutoring: Play one of the good tutors on our good-tutor bad-tutor agenda
  • Pick up some mentoring experience, and have fun while at it

Grad School things to do:

  • Get a decent grade in the two courses I'm taking
  • Write less imaginative and more realistic project proposals for my course projects - and make them happen!
  • Do some substantial work towards my written prelim (pretty much like William mentioned) - and that includes finding an original research topic

The REAL things to do:

  • Wake up early, at least on weekdays
  • Get to each class on time
  • Play basketball & flag football
  • NOT waste weekends doing nothing

fields.title: Goals for the Semester - Fall 2009
fields.post:
My Goals for the semester
1. To maintain the schedule I make for myself
2. To balance my academics, research and the service activities that I take up
3. At STARS - to get to know the other members and learn from their experiences
4. At STARS - to coordinate the Citizens school project
These would help me plan and organize my life better and definitely add to my experiences - both at a professional as well as personal levels :)

fields.title: 2009 STARS Celebration in Tallahassee
fields.post: This was my first STARS Celebration and I thoroughly enjoyed almost every minute of it. From the heat and humidity (actually didn't like that lol) to the new friendships that I acquired I felt that the STARS Leadership Conference was a great opportunity for me to meet other students who share common goals and interests as myself. My favorite aspects of the conference were the Mentoring Workshop (Nate was awesome) and the networking opportunities that were available. Going into the conference I didn't know anyone and was a little leery about how it was going to be, but I'm glad that I stuck with it and decided to make that trip out to FL. So many different students from different cultures and different past experiences that they endured it was just one word AMAZING. The workshops during the day were filled with so many broad topics to accompany any student's interests and the activities that went along with them were informational and eye-opening. I definitely plan to attend 2010 STARS Celebration in Tampa, cant wait!

fields.title: My Goals for the 2009 Fall Semester
fields.post:
Goals for the semester:
1. Try to increase my gpa and stay on the ball with all of my classes and try to get a 4.0 this semester
2. Become more active on N.C. State’s campus (with SWE, NSBE, BSB)
3. Balance work, class, school work, and the minimal social life I will have
4. Become more involved in the community
5. Don’t let little things stress me out so much
6. Try to stop procrastinating as much
7. When I need help in my classes go to office hours and/or talk to professors when I need assistance
8. Try to step out of my comfort zone and “bubble” and meet new people and experience new things
9. Do Alternative Spring Break in the Dominican Republic
10. Spend more time with my brother
11. Work hard with SPARCS2 and get the outreach project underway and affect at least 5 youth's lives in the process

These are just a few of my many goals I have for the semester. They can be broken down as academic, social, and personal. These goals align with my long-term goals because they will overall make me a better person and a more driven and accomplished student. I will measure my process through the semester by reflecting on the semester periodically about where the state I am currently in and what I have fulfilled on my list. Keeping track of things in my planner and writing things down help me accomplish my goals. I do not have a timeline to reflect back to but I do want to have all of these goals accomplished by the end of the school year. I am excited about this semester and ready to work harder than before ☺.

fields.title: What's Next?
fields.post:
My short-term goals for the semester include doing well in the classes I'm taking, meeting and enjoying the friendship of new and old friends, and deciding what I want to do after I graduate and working towards that. Long-term goals include being a working member in society and doing what God has planned for me.

My short-term goals work towards my long-term ones. By doing welling in school and building relationships with different people I'm increasing the likelihood that I will be a helpful member in society. This all in turns work towards the bigger plan that my life has that I'm currently unsure about.

I'm a part of an organization called Chi Alpha. During the first couple weeks of a new year we're constantly meeting and hanging out with new people. Being apart of this will definitely help me with my goal of meeting and getting to know more people then I currently know.

I don't really have myself on a timeline except for deciding to either try to find a job or go to grad school since there are deadlines involved. I'm fairly certain that I don't want to go to graduate school at the moment and would much rather have a job.

fields.title: Semester goals
fields.post:
For STARS, my goals this semester are:

  • To tutor CSC116 students, helping to combat some of the frustration that first-time programmers feel;
  • To work with Benjamin on recruiting more Hispanics into the computer science field, either through a partnership with existing Hispanic organizations, or by forming a new association;
  • To attend all STARS meetings and amass a certain quantity of free food.

For school, I have but one goal: earn A's in all of my classes. I have yet to do this in my college career, and this may be one of the last semesters where it is reasonably possible.

As for personal goals, I want to:

  • Submit a cross-stitch design to the State Fair. I have until September 25th to finish it, so I have to hustle!
  • Knit a sweater.
  • Find a two-bedroom apartment for my roommate and I. I feel bad taking up a corner of her living room!

fields.title: STARS in Tallahassee
fields.post:
At first I was unsure if I wanted to go. I had to take off from work, spend X amount of hours on a plane, and being my first celebration, had no clue what to expect. Thank goodness I went.

The networking opportunities where tremendous. First off, I met and bonded with a bunch of my fellow students from NC State. This was essential and advantageous for we looked out for one another the entire trip. Everyone became closer friends by the conclusion of the celebration.

We got to befriend students from other schools working on similar or fascinating projects. This brought some diversity, as the cultures of some schools varied greatly.

As for my professional networking, I took the opportunity to mingle with some of the speakers who work/worked at companies in which I have high interest. I was able to obtain contact information from some, and was offered job positions.

All-in-all, I was more than satisfied with the STARS celebration. I look forward to attending the next one.

fields.title: Pixar Dreams
fields.post:
My goal for this semester is to land a summer internship position at Pixar. Being a computer science major and having an interest in computer graphics, this is the best place I believe I can land for my professional career.

To get there, I've loaded my course schedule with essential courses such as "Intro to Computer Graphics", "Intro to Game Development", and "Software Development". The idea is not to just pass these courses, but to also excel in them.

With previous work experience, these college courses, and brushing up on some data structures and algorithms, I believe I can land an exciting position at Pixar Studios.

fields.title: Goals for the Fall 2009 Semester
fields.post: My major goal for this semester is to achieve a 3.5 GPA as well as get more involved with clubs/organizations. This includes community outreach of some sort as well as establishing myself within one of my clubs for future lead positions. In order to achieve my desired GPA, I will focus on completing my assignments ahead of time, in addition to collaborating with more of my classmates to clearly understand the objectives. I will measure my progress throughout the semester by allowing these practices to become daily habits which will in return yield good results. My long term goals are just a combination of my semester goals. So by adapting to a new regime, I plan on exercising my brain to its capacity.

fields.title: Benjamin's Semester Goals
fields.post:
Ok so here is a list of what I plan to get accomplished this semester

STARS Goals:
1. Play an active role in our new middle school outreach. SPARKS2.
a. Assist in looking for schools in any way I can.
b. Thouroughly prepare to give my SPARKS2 lesson.
2. Attract more hispanics to computing, with the help of Mi Familia and SHPE.
a. Meet the leaders of Mi Familia and SHPE - Accomplished!

b. Organize outreach activities.
c. Successfully carry out the planned activities.

Academic Goals:

fields.title: William's Fall 2009 Goals
fields.post:
So, it’s the beginning of Fall 2009 at last. For me, it’s year 2 at NCSU, and year 1 with STARS. I’m fresh off teaching my first-ever class (an experience I’d like to repeat). I’m transitioning between leadership roles, and taking on new responsibilities. I’m beginning to work on my written qualifier paper. It’ll undoubtedly be a busy semester.

My goals for the semester:

A 4.0 GPA for my 2 courses (more work than it sounds like)
Publish a conference paper
Make progress towards my written qualifier paper
To see the CSC116 (intro to programming) tutoring service I’m coordinating for STARS be successful
Be able to bowl at least a 125
Help the University Graduate Student Association & Student Senate continue their excellence
Not traumatize my mentees too much

So why am I doing all this? Goals 1 and 3 certainly come from a desire to not have NCSU run me straight back to NY. As for the conference paper, I came here to do research (and I’d like to be faculty some day). I’d like my for 116 tutoring to be useful for the students, and hopefully prevent people from being scared away from computing. Incidentally, that’s the course I taught this summer. I’m auditing bowling this semester, and would like to become a decent bowler. I am serving as a UGSA executive officer and a Student Senator this year, and want to do my best to advocate for NCSU students (especially grads). I’d also like to gain further insight into how a university works, and gain further university service experience.

Will this be an easy semester? No, but I wouldn’t have come 550 miles to NCSU if it wasn’t a challenge. Will I get much sleep? Probably not. Will this be worth it? I sure hope so.

fields.title: William's STARS Celebration Experience
fields.post:
Before we do anything else, I must tell you about how my Fall semester started before it started. The (very early) morning after giving my 116 class their final, I got on a plane for Tallahassee, FL for the 2009 STARS Celebration. This is where all of the schools in the STARS Alliance come together to discuss what they did in the past year, and what they intend to do in the coming year, and throwing in some student success tips along the way. It’s a fun time, you get to meet a lot of interesting people, and hopefully come back ready to hit the ground running. There was some mentoring training, some good outreach projects, and some interesting undergraduate research projects.

Something that stuck out for me were a couple of cool games developed over the summer at UNC-Charlotte. Most especially cool was their “Table Tilt” game, in which players with iPhones forming a table must collaboratively tilt their phones to make balls fall in the appropriate holes as quickly as possible. And from the small world department, I had met a couple of them a month earlier at a conference in the UK!

Towards the end, we decided on what we’ll do in the following year. As mentioned previously, I’m running a tutoring service for our introductory programming class. Basically, my group provides open lab hours in which students may walk in for help. Another student and I do this for 3 hours/week, and several other students contribute approximately 1 hour. I consider this important, as students aren’t always comfortable talking to instructional staff, their schedules aren’t always compatible with theirs, and economic realities have, unfortunately, reduced TA support for the course. My first-ever job was tutoring (primarily intro) students, and it was this that got me interested in a faculty career, starting me down the path that led me to NCSU.

There are lots of other cool and worthwhile projects going on at NCSU, though those are best described by my colleagues, so I highly recommend checking out their blogs.

All in all, I hope my work with STARS in the coming year is as fun as the Celebration was (minus being up all night grading exams).
