fields.title: STARS Celebration 2009 - Reflection
fields.post:
I was very impressed with this year's STARS Celebration. In my opinion it was definitely the best by far.

This year I had the opportunity to participate in the Mentoring Workshop as a facilitator. It definitely offers a different perspective than participating as a student. You have the opportunity to guide discussions as well as the responsibility to ensure that people are participationg and also that they are polite. I think this role will provide additional benefit as I work as a mentor in the upcoming semesters.

My one regret at the celebration is having limited opportunity to see others' work. Having a poster at the poster session kept me busy the entire time and I didn't get the chance to talk to others about their work as much as I would have liked to. I did enjoy what I saw of others' work at presentations and I thought that there was great diversity in the sessions this year.

Overall the Celebration got me excited and prepared for a great year of STARS!!

fields.title: STARS Celebration Reflections
fields.post:
While at the STARS Celebration, I thought about a lot of things in computing that I had never really thought about much before. Before going I knew about some of the things that you could do in computing besides programming, however, I had never really given all that much thought to them. While at the conference I was able to hear and go to workshops on various topics and hear what people were doing in computing. I really enjoyed the lectures by Tiffany Barnes and her work in learning through games. I also think that CSDT (Culturally Situated Design Tools) are really cool and should be used more often to help individuals see and understand the math that is around them in their everyday lives. Before going to the STARS Celebration I only had one friend that I had meet through the department of computer science. It was nice meeting and hanging out with STARS members from NC State during our stay in Tallahassee.

Some things that I think would have made the conference better are: better scheduling and having everything in a central location within walking distance. Some of the sessions felt too short and that some things were rushed while other seemed too long. If everything was within walking distance you could add the time it takes for traveling to having longer times in sessions.

To end off topic with a video: funny video

fields.title: STARS Celebration 2009: Do you have computer love?
fields.post:
More than anything else, this celebration helped me a lot in discovering all the different aspects of the STARS initiative. Having known STARS only from poster presentations and this website, it was a big eye-opener for me. The scale and variety of work being done by the SLCs is really impressive - and you've got to be at a STARS celebration to realize that.

I will just be starting out my first year with STARS, and I'm already excited about all the tasks that lay ahead. Challenging, but possible. And the annual celebration, as most would agree, is itself an important incentive to work hard. You get a chance to showcase your work at the next celebration - which brings in healthy competition as well as an opportunity to present in a conference setting.

Besides the several excellent workshops and sessions, I enjoyed the Black Archives tour very much. "Culturally-situated" being one of the buzzwords of this year's celebration, the tour was an apt way to make everyone familiar with local history and African-American heritage. As stressed throughout the mentoring workshop (and in several other sessions), it is very important to understand peoples' background and culture before engaging in any form of social activity with them. Hope to see such excursions in every celebration schedule.

As I reflect on the amazing time spent at the celebration, I get the feeling that STARS is as big in its aspirations of bringing diversity in computing as its self-sustained source of motivation instilled in the SLC members. Everyone at the celebration (and I mean everyone) had a personal willingness to work towards their chosen goals, and were united in their love for computing. In the coming academic year and beyond, I hope to draw much inspiration from my new friends in the SLC and their hard work - to squeeze out that extra hour every week for STARS. Honest.

fields.title: STARS Celebration
fields.post: The STARS 2009 celebration was the first celebration I had attended since I officially joined STARS at the start of the spring 2009 semester. The celebration ran like a typical conference, but I found the SNAG'EM game rather amusing from multiple standpoints. Clearly the game designers intended SNAG'EM to facilitate the mingling of conference attendees, and I would content that the designers succeeded in this goal at the start. As the game progressed, playing SNAG'EM became a data-mining exercise, which almost circumvented the need for physical interaction between players.

fields.title: STARS Celebration: sandwiches for everyone!
fields.post:
I am very happy to have attended the STARS Celebration '09! The conference did a very good job of building excitement for the upcoming year, and I'm very happy to be working with all of you awesome people.

One aspect of the conference that I particularly enjoyed: the keynote speakers. My personal favorite was Dr. Tracy Camp from the Colorado School of Mines. Her presentation on wireless sensor networks was easily accessible to a novice like myself, and above all it was extremely interesting.

The workshops and presentations were also very fascinating. I especially enjoyed the Culturally Situated Design Tools workshop, the stress management presentation, and the mentoring workshop. I also learned a lot from the "Getting Things Done" presentation and CRAW's advice on obtaining jobs and internships.

I rate the STARS Conference '09 five out of five sandwiches!

fields.title: STARS Celebration
fields.post: This was my first year at the STARS celebration. I had a good time at it. The mentoring workshop was interesting in its own way. I have not been to one where the speaker had so much energy. The CRA-W workshops were all great. The most useful of which was the one about setting up our own research lab. The other thing was we were able to network with a lot of people. I also got to know more about STARS. The only downside that I saw was that there were not enough sessions for graduate students. On the whole I had a jolly good time. Lastly, I knew only a couple of people from our home team before we left, but the extended lunch at Cici's Pizza and the wait in the hotel made us get to know each other better. As a team we had a great time in Tallahassee.

fields.title: Summer Activities, Fall Semester, and First Drupal Post
fields.post:
Okay, it's not official but I'm migrating my blog posts from blogger to our drupal site now for better centralization and this is probably more preferred by Stars because it helps to keep track of all the members' activities.

alright having the sudden appearance of my blog on this drupal site now demystified, let's get to the meat of what my summer activities (our first blog requirement) entails.

My summer did not include, unfortunately, any traveling out of the State or the continent, even though the airlines probably offers a lot of incentive for anybody to travel at this moment (in this general economic worry period that is). Had I left, I probably wouldn't be able to afford coming back (big smile).

So, I spent most of my time in Charlotte NC, taking up my least favorite activity but with most profitable outcome. Gardening. I considered it profitable because I was able use everything we grew in that garden as recipe for a good vegetarian meal (I'm not vegetarian, I just like eating raw vegetables, right now I'm hearing someone say eugh!).

The gardening was not fun, nevertheless, building a miniature greenhouse for it was a wonderful way for me to pass the time.

In between the gardening project and fun uncle responsibilities I had to take on I also took a summer course on Linear Algebra.

I heard this class was tough and I had expected to struggle through it. But I didn't. My guess is that I was probably saved by the fact that the professor probably wasn't able to crammed everything in that short summer session and also because it was not heavily proofed based. So perhaps that was the difference in the class i took and the ones my fellow students took? I don't know, what does a regular MA305 course entail? Could some one tell me.

I don't know what was taught at another class, but generally for the class I took, we went over different methods of solving big homo and non-homogeneous systems. We did linear interpolation, determinants of NxN vectors, inverse, Span Set, Basis of Span, Linear dependency, some block multiplication, traffic system, electrical network, finding eigenvalues and vectors and that sort.

What I enjoy most about that class is that it is algebra! Didn't require much math at all. Mostly I just went through tedious manipulations of matrices to get them in row echelon form or the reduced form. Who knew you can solve a large number of algebraic systems that way right? Well, at least I didn't till I learned from that class.

There was quite a handful of lecture notes, a dozen actually, so the instructor tried his best to gloss over "everything important". It just happens that sometimes, the most important things are the one that rarely gets committed to my working memory :D.

Anyway, I got out of course really excited. But I wasn't excited because I just completed MA305, I was excited because I learned how to reduced down huge matrix to find the determinant using at least three different methods. Using row echelon reduction and expansion method, diagonalization? (not even a word but the method could be describe so anyway), using some weird maps of lines and slashes, and of course the normal way taught to us by Calc I or Physics 205? I don't remember which one. That method only works well on 3x3 though :( . This wasn't the meat of linear algebra and wasn't a big deal, nevertheless I got excited over. Just because I like seeing a 10x10 matrix reduced to 3x3 then find that their determinant is exactly the same!

Finally, let's just get to Fall, this semester's plan. I am planning to do rehab center with Mei and other stars member from another university. I'm still planning to participate in Anne's wireless project.

It's 5:00 am, I'm up and the rice is smelling great. This is Saturday morning, what else am i to do but ramble about my finite experiences?
Okay.

Until next time.. aloha!

fields.title: STARS Celebration
fields.post: The 2009 STARS Celebration was a huge success! This being my first year as a member, I learned a great deal of useful about the mission of the alliance. I now fully understand my role as a member and can better align my project. Although attending the various workshops and speakers was interesting, the pinnacle of the celebration for me was spending time with and getting to know our home team better. We spent a lot of time getting to know one another, and everyone seemed to immediately get along and share similar values and goals. We have such a passionate group and I know that this year we, together, can achieve great things! I cannot wait to begin working on our various projects and get this year started!

fields.title: STARS Celebration
fields.post:
So, if it wasn't obvious enough, I thoroughly enjoyed myself at the STARS Celebration this year. I met many interesting people, and saw some very exciting projects. Minus a hiccup in flight plans, it went down without a hitch...

After playing the Snag'em Game set up by UNCC I have become even more outgoing and more comfortable with approaching random strangers/potential friends. I have grown leaps and bounds in my networks which is great. Although, I find it odd that I had to go all the way to Tallahassee to meet people who already live close by.

My favorite workshops were probably the Culturally Situated Design Tools, and other gaming/educational ones held by Tiffany Barnes. After looking back at the schedule, I think I went to all but one of her workshops. The mentoring workshop was good as well. I came to realize I'm more of a non-listener than I thought so that leaves something to improve upon which is good.

I felt the celebration was logistically sound, except for several time overlaps and crunches that hampered the seminars going on. Also, there would be times when I wanted to do multiple events at the same session, and others where nothing interested me.

I think going to the STARS Celebration has definately made some of us closer as a group and I think that will definately help when we have to work together on projects and such. As far as the projects I want to do, I will be continuing my efforts with SPARCS Middle School Outreach and will be starting research on Crystal Island. I am mostly excited for the research because I can finally see if the educational gamage/comp sci is really what I want to do. I had that as my idea since like the start of 11th grade, so actually teseting it out is a good idea (i think).

fields.title: STARS CELEBRATION
fields.post:
As I came back from the STARS Celebration I felt ready and prepared to go out and change the world, or at least get more students involved and interested in computing. This was my first Stars Celebration so I can't compare it to any previous ones but I'd like to say it was overall a success. As a new STARS SLC member I wasn't sure what exactly to expect but as soon as I arrived at Tallahassee everyone was extremely nice and welcoming from our own NC STATE group to those from other universities. As the week started we dove right into mentoring workshops which were actually quite fun. Later throughout the week the different conferences covered everything from what our fellow STARS members are doing to advice on how and what to do to get into grad school. The parts I enjoyed most had to be the poster sessions because they allowed us to explore what other members where doing and it allowed for networking.

At first I thought I would be overwhelmed and not know what project to pick to work on during the year and at first I was right. Once I began to see how interesting and fun some of the current projects were I just wanted to try a little of everything. By the end of the week however I began to see a pattern in the number of Hispanics in computing. It became clear to me that this was something I wanted to help out with along with taking the already established SPARKS program and expanding it to a less privileged middle school.

So now the school year is about to begin and all I hope for is that I can balance out all the goals I have set out for myself without affecting my grades. Let's see how that works out.

FUSION!!!!....

fields.title: Week 13:  Spring Banquet
fields.post:
Last week we had the spring banquet. I was thrilled with the turnout and the group received compliments from ePartners and the faculty who attended. We had 100% attendance from our students and an ePartner representative from 6 of our 7 ePartners. I was so impressed with all of the student presentations--they did a really nice job of presenting their work in the short 3 minutes they had. The ePartners were really interested in the projects and we still had ePartners talking with students 45 minutes after the banquet officially ended. Teresa Dahlberg, the STARS chairman, gave a very interesting keynote and seemed very interested in the student presentations.

Logistically, I would recommend renting chairs and round tables next year. Dr. Adams suggested holding the banquet at another school next year to help build our partnership with them. I would also recommend using a microphone for the presentations as some of the students were hard to hear in the back of the room.

fields.title: Week 12:  Semester Reflection
fields.post:
Here is a look at our goals from the beginning of the semester:

Level 1 Goals
* Update member profiles (Completed)
* Update projects and "image forthcoming" placeholders (Completed)
* Update logo (Completed)
* Add events to the calendar (Completed)
* Update news items (Sadly, did not get to this one)
* Update STARS description (Completed)
* Add posters (Completed)

Level 2 Goals
* Create savable online STARS application (In progress)
* Check whether scrolling marquee for news items is Section 508 compliant (Did not begin)
* Create links to other Raleigh STARS groups (Did not begin)

Level 3 Goals
* Add capability for STARS application review and management
* Automatically populate news items for RSS feeds
* Render STARS applications to PDFs
* Check that entire website is Section 508 compliant
* Add alumni functionality
* Fix drupal feeds

We did revise our goals partly through the semester. We had to stop work on the online application so that we could archive old members and projects. We successfully finished this functionality at our second to last meeting. We also had to spend time during our final meetings working on the poster and banquet presentation. I think we did a nice job of making sure what we did this year could easily scale for future years. I wish we all could have dedicated more time to the project. I think it might be beneficial for the website team to meet for a 2 hour time block or twice a week next year. Trying to squeeze in mentoring time as well as accomplishing tasks seemed to be very tough. I won't be on the website team next year, but I am excited that both Rob and Mark will be able to continue with the project. Hopefully, they will be able to finish the online savable application! I really enjoyed working with both of you!

fields.title: Banquet
fields.post: I think the banquet went extremely well. I was very impressed with the presentations everyone gave. Everyone seemed to know exactly what to say and conveyed the material in their presentation extremely well. I also had the opportunity to have some interesting discussions with our corporate sponser and professors during the poster session. I got a lot of good input on how to improve SPARCS in the future, ideas for future activities and additional data that may be interesting to collect. Can't wait for next year!

fields.title: Banquet
fields.post:
I thought the banquet went rather well, but I really don't have a reference "banquet standard". I was most surprised by the interest that the e-partners expressed in all of the STARS projects. Many e-partners stayed for some time to visit and discuss each poster.

One area for improvement that I can identify is interaction with the e-partners before the presentations. Most of the e-partners at my table talked to each other, not to the STARS members. I think that efforts could be taken to stimulate conversation about STARS projects, but I'm not sure how this could be done without making the presentations or the poster session redundant.

fields.title: STARS Banquet
fields.post:
I think the banquet went very well. All of the sponsors seemed very interested in our posters and projects. I met some nice people from cisco & ?? who were interesting. I think both of them mentioned they were in the NAVY at some point and they had fun stories to tell. I liked the fact that I was seated by random people I didn't know to well, b/c then I could reach out of my comfort bubble and learn new things.

During this banquet I did notice that people didn't stand in the same area when they presented. There were people far to the edges, close up front, against the screen, and just all over. I think if we had a podium or something, people would know where to stand when they presented, or at least have a general center to stay by. Some of the people who were sitting at the back edges might have had trouble hearing the speakers b/c they weren't in the same area.

My favorite STARS project this year was SRARCS. I am very interested in education and I love kids, so helping them learn about computing was a great experience. I think I will definitely keep it for next year too. I think I also want to try and do crystal island stuff next semester as well.

fields.title: Semester reflection
fields.post: This year I think I got a good deal accomplished. I was able to pick up the SPARCS program, and I had a lot of fun with that. I did adjust my goals a slightly for 116 mentoring, the help 3 people thing didn't quite work out. But my one girl is doing great now, and is studying for her java exam as I type this. I told her to call me with any last minute questions she might have. To improve for next year, I think STARS could participate in a couple more campus activities as a group. That way we can get to know each other better, as well as let other people on campus know who we are and what we do.

fields.title: Spring semester reflection
fields.post:
I believe, in general, that my set goals have been and are still being accomplished. My level one goals consisted of establishing contact with and working with the City of Raleigh (check!), develop (check!) and begin implement the plan (check!) for a wireless mesh network downtown.
Level two goals involved pulling in some outside support, which turned out to be an intrinsic part of working with the city government, as per their agreements with Cisco and now an implementing vendor. I did get some interest from other NC State students, and hopefully some will choose to work on this project come August.
And level three (a test network up and running) is definitely not done, but not to worry, this is expected to be accomplished during next semester's work, building on the work to be done over the summer.

fields.title: Spring 09 Poster Session
fields.post:
Side note:
Someone needs to fix the timing on this WRAP login thing, or I will be forced to murder it. This is not the first time I've lost a whole blog post because I took more than 10 minutes to write it. Can we at least have a "warning, to continue, with all your data intact, please login" instead of it wiping everything?

Blog post:
Our poster session was quite successful both in showing off our projects to visitors like the computer science department tour group and in sparking interest in fellow students to join STARS. I believe I heard at our meeting that we gathered more applications this year than the same time last year! Myself, I also got to talk with some students involved in the wireless mesh network testbed here on Centennial, and dialogued about their participation over the summer or throughout the next year. Should be great to have some more hands and experience working on this project for the City of Raleigh!

fields.title: Plans for the summer
fields.post: In so far as I have a general idea of what I am doing this summer, then yes, I have plans. In the sense of actually planning being completed, then no, I do not. The first month is simple; I will return home and work at Jefferson Lab, the physics research lab I've been working at for almost the last three years. After that, around the middle of June I will take off for China. I will spend approximately six weeks there, living with some friends of the family and learning the language through immersion. I do hope to make it Beijing this time, but even if not I will get to visit Hong Kong. From there, I expect I'll only have about a week or so before the STARS celebration, and from there back to school! I have no doubts that it will be a busy summer.

fields.title: Revising a poster
fields.post: I must say, revising an old poster is a whole lot easier and less time-consuming than creating one from scratch. Now, not only am I grateful that I had a bit more experience creating one than I did last semester, but I am additionally pleased by the way revising my poster showed me the progress my project has undergone so far. For instance, now I have a whole column devoted to what actually has been done, as opposed to what hopefully will be done. Microsoft Powerpoint and Autocorrect have tested the limits of my patience once again, but I prevailed against shifting text spacing and margin hopping.

fields.title: Poster Session
fields.post:
In my opinion, the poster session went well. We had a number of students walking to class, who stopped, listened, and seemed genuinely interested. I noticed that the e-partners weren't there, was this intentional? Personally, I would prefer for them to come only to the banquet, simply because it is a more formal occasion. Also, I think some random people ate the cookies, which should probably be under lock and key. As for improvements, the time wasn't the best for a few

Project-wise, the HUD is nearly done, and Jon is integrating my changes into his copy of CI.

fields.title: Goal Reflection - Website
fields.post: Most of the goals complete this semester fell into the category of level 1 ("minimum") goals. In fact, the only goals completed with the exception of 2.4 were level 1 goals. (Goal 2.4 should technically be a level 1 goal, but it isn't.) Most of our efforts focused on updating basic elements of the website and developing a reasonable scheme for managing members and projects. We did some initial planning for goal 2.1, but progress on the goal was stymied by much needed work in other areas.

fields.title: Poster Session
fields.post:
For being my first poster session I wasn't too sure what to expect. But from what I experienced it seemed like it went fairly well. We had groups of people come through and they asked us all about STARS and what projects we were working on. I think the parents were asking more questions than the kids were but they still seemed pretty interested. Lots of parents seemed to like the SPARCS stuff so that was nice.
State students came through with each round of buses so that was good. Some of the older guys were talking about different encryption activities that we could do wit the middle schoolers, but at this point, having them all run linux programs seems a bit too difficult.
I think we can improve next year's poster session by having someone at each poster area when people are around. I saw a couple groups of people go look at a poster area, but there wasn't anyone around who knew the topic, or if they did they were at a different section.
Overall it went really well, and I think I am better prepared to explain my part for another poster session.

fields.title: Summing up the progress of the STARS Website
fields.post:
We have recently created a more stable archive systems for our members and projects page. As the site ages we need to be able to handle its growth. This was not done in the most effiencient way originally. At first we demoed the idea of just keeping one large archive page, one for members and another for projects page. But as we looked back we found this process cumbersome. For example, the archive members page could handle any "new" members to its page, simply because each entry would be unique. But as for the projects archive page, most projects are still being worked on, they just evolve in their focus. So should we have multiple entries of the same project and separate them by year/semester. In the end, we decided this would eventually turn into a mess in a couple of years, and who wants that to be their legacy with the group? So from that experience, the drop down system was born. While this may seem simple from a user perspective (person-viewing the site), a lot of debugging was done on the back end to have java script work with both Internet Explorer and Mozilla Firefox. If you ever made create a site you know exactly where I am coming from.

Future Work Ideas for next Fall 2009:

  • NEW: Possible script written that will make the creation of new pages easier.
  • Creating a database for students to save unfinished STARS application.
  • Updating the News Sections with something that will dynamically search the web for related topic

There are some other ideas but these are what occurred to me while writing.

fields.title: Proof of STARS Evolution
fields.post:
Another school year is closing and with it comes the end of STARS. It can be said STARS has grown a lot in the two years I have been a member. In the beginning we were a small group just thinking of ideas of ways we could connect with the community and spread our message. Now, we have growing ties and partnerships with neighboring middle school, the faculty, and even downtown Raleigh. In case you the reader are unaware on what I am talking about. SPARCS a group within STARS meet up with kids at Centennial Middle School, and get them involve with Robotics and programming, helping dissolve the image that computer science is boring activity, a common idea that occurs to students mind when deciding what major to do when the enter college. Also within our group we have members working with students in introductory computer science class. This to me seems to be an excellent way of keeping students who may be completely new to programming within the major. I know for a fact if I was taking that class and had the same opportunity these student have, I would take snatch it up without hesitation. Finally, there is the group of students who are working with city of Raleigh, to bring up a City-Wide wireless network. As of now they are mainly focusing with downtown area but the ideas that they are considering to include is amazing.

If you wish to hear more on the other things students are doing within STARS check out: http://research.csc.ncsu.edu/stars/index.php?page=projects

fields.title: STARS Banquet
fields.post: It is pretty amazing how time flies. I cannot believe it is April and time for the STARS banquet. One year is almost over and it has been quite a busy year! Being a member of STARS certainly helped motivate me to take my role as a student in Computer Science more seriously. Also, whenever I attend conferences, I keep a keen ear for diversity and commuity outreach. I just came back from the TAPIA 2009 conference where one of the speakers talked about how public schools are really needing all the help they can get as far as obtaining computing resources and getting people to work one-on-one with the students. This has me really thinking. I know we already have a STARS outreach with the Centennial middle school. But this middle school is rich. There are many other public schools that could really use help. I could think of a few things such as having after school activities for some public school students and this can be done by STARS members -- but this would be labor intensive. STARS students are pretty busy already with their courseload and research and internships. The challenge is to come up with a community outreach that is easily done and that will have an impact or make a dent into the problem of fostering and developing skills in science, math, and computing.

fields.title: STARS Poster
fields.post: The STARS poster session went really well! I think that Lauren Hayward did a very good job printing and framing the posters! Excellent job, Lauren! And they were all displayed in the East Atrium. Students who were coming and going that afternoon in between classes stopped and asked questions which led a lot of STARS members talking to clusters of students about their research or community outreach. I invited 3 students to try to sign up for STARS and I think they will apply for next year. Regarding STARS activities, I think that while the middle school outreach and the research activities are well-situated, we need to have a "repository" of options for internships -- something to the effect that a previous STARS member worked for that company and that future STARS members are "helped" as far as seeking internships for the same company... I know the COOP office already has this but it would be good if we can have something that STARS can foster as far as internship alliances.

fields.title: Week of April 13
fields.post:
As is typical, reflecting back on this semester sees some goals accomplished, some delayed, some lost. Nevertheless, I would consider it a successful semester thus far.

Goals achieved:

- Designing, coordinating, developing a new version of Crystal Island. This is still in progress, but we successfully piloted a preliminary version last week, and I am convinced it is leaps and bounds better than earlier versions, in terms of learning effectiveness.

- Implement student modeling component for written prelim and CI study.

- Help guide Karl as he implements Crystal Island backpack feature w/ HUD indicator

- Publish a paper in AIED-09 as a first author

Goals delayed:

- Defending my written prelim won't occur until May, but I've finally made a huge amount of progress on it, which is more than can be said for the prior several semesters

- Expanding the nursing home project. This ended up being a bit too much for this semester, but hopefully David's sustainability efforts will keep the project going for next semester, so that it can be expanded in the future.

fields.title: Week of April 6
fields.post:
I felt that the STARS poster session went particularly well this time - the best one since I have been involved in the group. Attendance and interest seemed especially strong. The posters were well-visited by passing students and faculty, and it became an excellent recruiting opportunity. I had a chance to talk with a pair of students from Shaw who were just starting in their own STARS chapter. They were very interested in Crystal Island and educational games, so it was a fun conversation. I also got to chat with a student (Tyler) in Michael Young's game development course about game AI, which was fun. He is working in Unreal Tournament, and has run into some of his own interesting development challenges.

Karl and David both had a number of visits to their posters, with interesting feedback. Dr. Adams had some helpful comments for how to improve David's poster, in particular.

Karl demoed a working version of the knapsack HUD feature he's been chipping away at for the last month! I was really pleased to see that he got it working. He has sent me the code he wrote, so I can soon get to incorporating it into the latest version of Crystal Island.

fields.title: Week of March 30
fields.post:
My summer plans will involve staying in Raleigh, continuing research in the IntelliMedia lab. Early May will see our big CCMS data collection, the week of May 11 - 15. Shortly after I plan to defend my Written Prelim exam, finally earning my Masters and moving forward in this program. : ) Then, the summer will include:

Unity game development for CI-5
Developing the Narrative Generation pipeline for the Narrative Theater, and doing some preliminary development there
Cleaning and analyzing data from the big CCMS data collection
Working on my oral proposal using the data from the big CCMS study.

Hopefully from the summer's work, we'll be able to put together some ideas for submissions to the International Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces (IUI), and the International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS).

Should be a busy but productive summer!

fields.title: Poster Session
fields.post:
I thought the poster session went rather well. The large volume of student traffic (see note below) during the class change period from 2:05 PM to 2:20 PM and the prospective student tour group gave us high visibility. I think Lauren already pointed out in her post that it was unclear who we are and why we are having a poster session from the perspective of a casual observer. I think the suggestion of wearing the STARS shirts is a good one.

Note: The ECE 220 class that let out at 2:05 PM ate almost all of our cookies, and we consequently ran out, much to the disappointment of those who knew that there should have been cookies. (Those who didn't know that there were originally cookies weren't terribly disappointed.) The point of a poster session, however, is not to provide unlimited cookies, at least in the conventional sense...

fields.title: Week 11:  Poster Session
fields.post:
We held our poster session yesterday, and I am really happy with how it turned out. We had the session from 1:30-3:30 so a few big classes let out during our session so we managed to get a lot of foot traffic. A professor and a few students from Shaw came and talked with us. If I was to do it all again, I would have more cookies and punch (we ran out of cookies at about 2:30 and punch around 3:00) and have more flyers. I would also have someone in charge of making sure that everyone who picked up a cookie at least got a flyer and heard a little bit about STARS. We had several students ask about joining, so I'm hoping we get a good number of applicants this year. The posters looked fantastic--everyone did such a nice job with them! It was neat to be able to walk around and see the wide variety of posters we had. A tour of potential freshman happened to be scheduled during our event, so they also walked around to look at our posters. I was glad we started setting up about 45 minutes early as we were fully setup about 10 minutes prior to the event starting. I'm wondering if it might be more effective in the future to have everyone wear STARS shirts instead of business casual so it is more evident who we are.

I think we still don't have a clear message of what we are and what we do. We really need a clear, concise two sentence description that we put on all of our advertising. It's just really hard for people who know nothing about us to grasp.

fields.title: This Summer
fields.post:
Well, currently I don't have too many plans for this summer. I'll be doing the usual traveling, Edisto Island, King's Dominion, Cedar Point, Ohio, Pennsylvania etc. I'll be taking summer classes for a little bit. I want to get physics out of the way and possibly an english.
On a side note, I plan on learning how to drive again this summer, hopefully get my license. It's been put off for the last couple years.
I'm looking forward to going to the convention in Florida at the end of summer it should be interesting.

fields.title: Summer plans
fields.post:
My past two Summers were property of the US Government, so this one, I'm being selfish and spending it all on me.

This Summer will feature plenty of:
-Sleeping
-Hot pockets
-Wang's Kitchen
-Swimming
-FOSS development (KDE perhaps)

I applied for a position at Red Hat on the off-chance that they'll pick me up.
And maybe I'll take a Summer class or two.

As for the CI, I finally got the HUD working!
There is a square in the upper-right corner of the screen which shows the item that is currently in the knapsack.
I have some fine-tuning left in order to get it ready for prime-time, but it's in a much better state than previously.

I still have yet to fix the map overlay feature, as well as the enhanced note-taking functionality, but the knapsack HUD was the biggest task.

fields.title: Many, many enriching and rewarding activities
fields.post:
The past four weeks has been a blur of activities. I have not been able to keep up with blogging because I have been putting my time into doing the research work and presenting at conferences, etc. etc. I guess what I mean is I had not had much time talking about my work... instead I have been putting my time into doing the work. But I like STARS and the vision it has so I am still committed to its mission. The following are my acitivies the past weeks:

March 4th -- NCSU Career Fair -- where I met with several potential employers and had follow-up interviews

March 18th -- NCSU University Graduadte Student Symposium -- I was nominated 1 among 5 students from the CSC department to present a poster of my research work. The experinece was really terrific. It helped us get to know what the other departments are doing and how other students are doing their own research. It also showed us the quality of research that needs to happen in order to be a winner. There were winning posters, about 5, picked from across all the depts.

April 1-4 -- Tapia Conference on Diversity in Computing -- where I presented 3 posters and 1 paper. It was a terrific conference. This is my second time to attend Tapia. I was really looking forward to it because I made friends the first time and wanted to touch base with colleagues. The first time I attended back in 2007, I only had a poster but the conference was an eye-opener and I really was moved by the spirit with which they pushed the idea of fostering diversity in computing. The speakers that were invited were top notch and all spoke of research or activities that helped the mission of diversifying computing. The research was top nothc as well. This is why I endeavoured to attend again this year. I got a scholarship to attend the conference and I was able to present my research in two formats -- psoter and paper.

April 4 -- when I came back from Tapia I participated in the CSC Symposium on Graduate Research and really enjoyed the experience of hearing the other graduate students from VTech, Auburn U. and from NCSU present their research. I also presented mine and got good feedback. The experience is really very educational and enriching -- you see how other students do their research and you are able to make friends with and interact with the other students frlom the other schools. This was really a terrific event and I am glad I had this opportunity to participate!!!

So now this week will be the STARS symposium and I will be presenting research I did at Oak Ridge National Lab where I did an internship last summer 2008.

In the meantime, amidst all these, I am running experiments for my dissertation research. I have finished running 40 subjects and am data crunching right now. I am still laboring and toiling to make it to the finish line and complete my degree. It has been busy but the activities and the "busy-ness" is all oriented towards converging goals, to finish my degree, to be a good top notch researcher, and to be able to eventually mentor future students (if in academia) or junior colleagues (if in industry). I know now what it is like to pursue research and actively interact with colleauges. The conference grants that I received from Tapia and Grace Hopper (for the past two years of conferences) have helped me tremendously. I previously also presented at an IEEE Pervasive Computing conference (2007) and that was also very educational and enriching. I am just thankful that I am amidst very supportive colleagues in the field who help junior colleagues participate in these conferences and help with their formation. It gives me an example fo what to do when I join the ranks of my professional colleagues.

fields.title: Week 10:  Creating the archive members & projects page
fields.post:
We made huge progress this week on our archive pages this week. We determined the best way to implement the archive so it worked in both IE and Firefox. Then we began moving all of the information over from the original website to the format of our new website. We finished up the archive for 2006-2007 and now we just need to organize our page for 2007-2008. We are working very hard to make it easier to update in the future.

I've been busy this week making all of the preparations for the poster session and the banquet. I feel like our meeting was really productive this week. We gave each other tons of feedback on our posters, so I'm very confident the poster session will be a success. We are actively recruiting students for next year. I'm hoping we get a bunch of applications.

fields.title: Summer Plans
fields.post:
I will be working at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, NM, for almost the entirety of the summer. The group I will be working with is known as the Center for Cyber Defenders (CCD) and focuses on many aspects of computer security. Most of their past projects included network visualization and analysis, but I think they worked on an algorithm for the SHA-3 hash competition last year named SANDstorm. The group this year has a good deal of interest in reverse engineering, so we'll probably do a bit work in that area as well.

One great aspect of the CCD is that as an intern, you get to work on an ongoing project in another Sandia division (provided you have the clearance) in addition to your project(s) at the CCD. Hopefully I'll get to join some of the physics or engineering projects that my sources inside Sandia have told me about.

fields.title: Summer Plans and Project Update
fields.post:
My summer plans so far are up in the air. I'm hoping the get a research internship at SAS. I think it would be a great opportunity that would look fantastic on my resume, but hiring so far is at a standstill. A fall back would be an RA position, but even that isn't guarunteed either. Whatever I do, though, I will be doing some travelling. My fiance's sister is getting married in France this summer so I'll be attending the wedding. Immediately following I have a conference in Brighton, England. It should be a fun few weeks.

The last SPARCS session was this past Saturday - at least the last regular session. It went well and I really enjoyed going through the feedback on the final surveys. For the most part students had very positive things to say. One of the most poignant comments refered to making sure everything worked before the session. Very insightful input from a 13 yr old :) I'm really excited for our field trip this Saturday as well.

fields.title: Week 9:  Master's Defense
fields.post:
I decided to veer off my typical blog posts this week and talk about my master's work. I have been studying distributed pair programming and defended my work this week (and passed!). I have been extremely nervous about the defense all semester, and it really wasn't as scary as I thought it was going to be. I talked with my advisor after my defense and she said that getting a Master's degree is really all about persistence--if you work hard, you can succeed. And looking back over the last 2 years, it really is true. So I encourage anyone who is even considering the Master's degree to go for it. You can do it!

I wanted to share a few of my results from my work. A quick intro--pair programming is a practice where two programmers work together to develop code, design, algorithm, or test. Unfortunately, programmers can't always meet in the same location to pair program, so sometimes they pair program from separate locations over the Internet (distributed pair programming). What I found is that students who have access to a common lab space may not take advantage of distributed pair programming. However, students without access to a lab space (for example, distance education students) can really benefit from distributed pair programming. Most students who tried distributed pair programming found it to be enjoyable and productive, which is encouraging. Dr. Williams plans to take some of the results from my work and include them in the next STARS pair programming workshop.

fields.title: Poster
fields.post:
So, me and the other guys doing SPARCS decided to meet up last night and work on our poster. We kept the same intro as the previous poster, and updated the other activities on the board. Jen said she was going to do a poster that was mostly about the results of the surveys she's been collecting. So our poster is more of a description of the different activities we did with the kids...

Because not all of us went to every event this semester, there was usually one or two people who could give a good description for a particular activity. I think we pretty much worked on it equally with each other. We did a mini blurb about each program at the top, and then listed our 3 main objectives or learning goals at the bottom. We didn't have real pictures to use yet, so we found generic ones from clip-art. We decided to change them later when we find good pictures. We started to write up the proposal for the poster, which will be reviewed at the next meeting I suppose. We had a few things we weren't sure on, but decided to ask others for help on later. Overall, our meeting was rather productive and we got a lot accomplished.

fields.title: Week of March 23
fields.post:
This week I was in Palo Alto, CA presenting a paper at the AAAI Spring Symposium on Intelligent Narrative Technologies II. The event was a lot of fun - I met and re-met a number of members of the AI & narrative community, and got to participate in a lot of really interesting discussion.

As for project updates:

Crystal Island - Karl has been plugging away trying to get bitmap images to draw to the HUD. He has been using a tutorial, but as of our most recent meeting last week he had not yet had any success. We looked at the problem together and I offered some suggestions for directions to explore, and hopefully soon we'll find out if any of them work out. Also, Karl showed me a quick sketch of his new poster layout. Creating the poster should be his main activity for this week, because they are due to Lauren on Friday. Unfortunately, we weren't able to meet at our regular Thursday meeting time because of delays I had in my flight back from Palo Alto.

Nursing Home Project - David has made another visit to the nursing home, and the group has begun to include search engine activities with the residents. We have decided that it's getting kind of late in the semester to attempt to expand the nursing home project to multiple locations, so we have decided to focus our further efforts on creating a best practices document that can be passed along for future volunteers. David will also be focusing on revising his poster this week. He has already submitted one draft to me, and I have sent back revisions.

fields.title: Week of March 16
fields.post:
Computing is such a vague term, that I'm having difficulty characterizing what it means to be good at computing. Computing could refer to programming ability, or problem-solving ability, or the ability to work with abstract models of computation, or having basic computer literacy, or being an effective network administrator, etc. And I think that each flavor has its own answer.

For example, I believe that anyone has the ability to be computer literate, because computers are intentionally designed to be usable by humans. All that is necessary is experience and support, and ultimately anyone should be able to use a well-designed machine proficiently. That includes the the young, the elderly, the physically, mentally, and emotionally handicapped, etc. The burden here should be on the interface designer, not the user.

For other areas, like programming, I think that hard work is responsible for the bulk of one's effectiveness, but innate talent can help make a good programmer a truly great one. Some people are extremely comfortable thinking in those terms, and that is not true for everyone.

I believe having the ability to reason about complex, abstract concepts like non-traditional models of computation, and developing proofs about those models, requires a substantial amount of innate intelligence. That sort of work is so abstract that it can be very difficult to do without a substantial amount of cognitive ability (much more than I have, at least!).

fields.title: Innate computing abilities
fields.post:
I think computing has becoming more and more an innate ability for our and future generations. The more we are familiar with how to use computer applications and the Internet, the easier it is to then innately understand how computer programs and computer networks work and are constructed. So in a sense, the human race (and here I refer to those privileged enough to live in a technologically rich country) has adapted to such an influx of computerized items.
On a more "single person" scale, there are those who are certainly more suited to computing, and there are those who desire to be good and thus work at it. I have heard that a single-track mind is required to program, and while this may be a good innate quality for some people, it is my opinion that more is required: namely, a good defense against velociraptors (http://xkcd.com/292/).

fields.title: Goal reflection
fields.post: As we come back from spring break and end our first week returning from our much-needed rest, the wireless mesh networking project for Raleigh is progressing quite well. Directly after coming back, I emailed our contact at the IT Department of Raleigh, Jonathan Minter, and got things moving again after our school hiatus. Now, as can perhaps be expected, government-run projects might be a bit slow. So our original time-line for this project has actually been pushed back about a month. With the addition of S-Don to the team (yay!), however, things may be a bit easier and faster to work through. We attended a meeting this Friday where the City of Raleigh presented some items of importance concerning the project to the vendors all considering bidding to work on the project with us and the Raleigh IT people. They all seemed half-amused and half-approving when we were introduced as university students here to work on the project (and as free labor). So now the plan is to continue this half-government half-industry project in a couple weeks by reviewing, grading, and selecting the submitted proposals, after which we will be involved in the implementation of the network.

fields.title: Building Unity
fields.post:
Now, it is common thought in the business world that the best way to ensure that members are all on the same page plan-wise is through a meeting. However, this structure was formulated under the model of top-down approach, namely that meetings are held so that the leaders of a single project may communicate ideas to those working on the project, or so that workers may each report on their progress. It is my opinion that STARS is constructed a bit differently than this.
We are all involved in different projects, and some of us are involved in more than one project, or at least more than one aspect of a single project. In this way, our meetings are more geared toward sharing non-identical experiences and gathering outsider input on any issues with which a single project is having trouble. So it seems a bit harder to maintain unity under those conditions, but there is no reason why it still cannot be achieved. In a previous post, I mentioned support and general liking toward out monthly meetings, and I think that those meetings to indeed promote unity within our chapter of STARS. But I do think more than that, we could encourage inter-project knowledge and support to promote unity in much the same way that I know the larger scientific community does today in the world.
My dad is a scientist working at Jefferson Lab, an energy research lab focusing on accelerators and particle physics. As a scientist (on whatever random organizations like NSF perhaps), he is also involved in reviewing other projects all over the country. For example, he regularly travels to and corresponds with the LIGO group in California, a research group studying (trying to find) gravity waves. So while this might not have a specific correlation to his own work, there is still a nice overlap inside the overall scientific community. I think we could apply this same method to our STARS group. Perhaps each person could be involved with someone else's project by reviewing and offering suggestions to that other project. In that way, unity is maintained not just on the personal level, but also on the technical and project levels.

fields.title: Progress and Posters
fields.post:
Our past SPARCS dates have been very spread out, so there really isn't much to mention on that front. I'm working on getting the final surveys together for the students to take at our final regular session this Saturday.

Regarding posters, I've decided that the content of what SPARCS is and the type of activities we do should be covered by poster(s) from the mentors - instead of me just doing it all. That way I can focus on analyzing and presenting the data we got from the surveys. I hope to do sort of a "lessons learned" type poster. I'll start my analyses after I have the final surveys in this Saturday and see what is worth presenting.

fields.title: Progress + Poster
fields.post:
Progress has been frustratingly slow. I'm trying to modify the HUD in Crystal Island to display the currently-held item. Right now, I'm trying to make *anything* pop up in the HUD.
Additionally, I've modified the existing knapsack code to exclude some large items (crates and oil drums).
The goal is a polished knapsack, ready for use in the April study.

As for the poster, we're going to diverge a little from the template. Instead of the traditional 4-panel layout, we'll merge the panels into one on the left, and one on the right (Video Tagging Tool and CI Improvement, respectively), with a description of CI above.

fields.title: Do you think certain people are innately good at computing or have they adapted to it?
fields.post:
I think people are just adapted to computing. They say it is easier to learn something when you are younger, that goes for foreign languages, computing, and anything else. The students/professionals today in computing have probably worked with computers and technology at a young age where they had time to adapt and learn it.

As I work with the residents at the nursing home, I found that this was really the case for all the residents. The residents have a difficult time getting used to the computers and learning e-mail and typing. They are improving though as they try their best to get used to it. If the residents worked with technology at a younger age, I am sure they would've been a lot better with computers.

fields.title: Week 8 Update
fields.post: We had to side-step a bit this week. A previous member pointed out that we did not have all of the previous members on the website. So this week we devised a plan for how the website will hold this information and began implementing it. We discussed the poster proposal for the celebration and the poster. We've reserved next week's meeting to work on the poster.

fields.title: Project Progress - Website
fields.post: Progress on the website this week primarily consisted of developing a mechanism for managing old member profiles. The scheme we settled upon involves creating a new member page for each academic year. When setting up the member page for the new year, the old member page is archived and accessible through an academic year dropdown. The page is set up such that minimal changes need to be made when updating the website for a new academic year. A similar mechanism will be implemented for the projects page.

fields.title: Innate Computer Science
fields.post:
I would imagine that certain people are innately good a computer science. Throughout history, there have been those individuals such as Newton and Einstein who are demonstrably better than their contemporaries at solving problems in their field. I would therefore completely expect that some people are better at computer science than others.

However, I think that distinguishing between innate and adapted computer science skills is rather difficult. Innate computer science skills are probably most identifiable at a "younger" age, whatever that age may be. Those who have adapted to computer science at such ages will probably exhibit greater difficulty solving computer science problems. At "older" ages, the actual experience in a computer science field will likely overwhelm the distinction between innate and adapted skills. Innate computer scientists may be able to assimilate new knowledge or uncover new breakthroughs faster than adapted computer scientists but only marginally so.

To sum things up, innate computer scientists do exist in my opinion, but their existence is not notable.

fields.title: Spring Week 8: Are some people just meant to work with computers?
fields.post:
I tried ever so hard to come up with a good title for this post but couldn't come up with anything better. I feel like it is such a missed opportunity. Oh well. I think it is a matter of upbringing and what you do as a kid that decides it. I know I started on the computer very early on with one of those disney things where there was a cover over the keyboard with different characters and stuff. I was exposed to it very early and just grew up with it. Does that mean I was going to be good, or even enjoy computing and computer science? Not at all, but it certainly helped I would imagine. I also played with legos a lot too. The whole idea of doing things one step at a time, slowly building from the ground up, making sure everything was right before moving on, helped too. It made me realize early on that you cant move on to the 5th step before you finish the first 4. You also get an idea for encapsulation (Ohhh, big vocabulary words! Yay for CSC 216!). Often times there would be small little pieces built as seperate things then added to the whole to make things easier to follow. This certainly seems to correlate to Computer Science. Who knows. It is all just a way of thinking. For some it comes much easier, for others it takes some time, or maybe it takes more than that. I really can't be sure. I just love it and wouldnt have it any other way. Just dont make me do Chemistry!

Ok, so there isnt much more to report on the coop this week. Still working on some small things. Might have my work cut out for me starting tomorrow with a calendar to redo. Always something to change or fix.

SPARCS has had a long break and we will have another meeting with the students next weekend.

Now the mentoring project. I love the idea, and think it should definately be looked into in the future. However, it needs to be run by someone that has much more time to commit to it than I have had this semester. It isn't a lot, but by my being off campus all the time, I have not had the flexibility to work into a different schedule. It is really frustrating. I'm sad that I couldnt do more. There is simply just too much going on for me. I wish I had come to this conclusion earlier. I'd be happy to talk to someone for the Fall on ideas for starting it. I'm hoping to be a TA for 116, so be sure to keep in touch.

That's about it. It's nice to be all caught up.

fields.title: Spring Week 7: Looking back on February...
fields.post:
Well, February is over and so is spring break. Everyone came back to campus last week, and it made things ever so much more enjoyable. Work goes on though, even through the break that everyone else enjoyed so much.

This week at the coop was focused completely on getting all of our testing for the new phone's internet browser working correctly. Much of spring break was spent on this same task, so it was hardly an easy task. I finally finished it on Friday, and what a feeling! It took some out of the box thinking to get it all done, but it now works pretty well if I do say so myself. Granted, access to the ATT network is still sketchy during the day, but thats about it. We shall see as the weeks go on how it holds up to constant testing.

More or less things are static with the other two projects. I'm going to give the updates on them in my blog for the next week, which will get me up to date on everything!

fields.title: Spring Week 6: Unity in STARS
fields.post:
Well, I think I kind of jumped the gun with my last post. What could we do to build unity in STARS. Unfortunately, that is a rather difficult thing to do with so many different schedules. Even if a time did line up just right, free time is so valuable that it's hard to say, everyone come and lets do unity stuff. Instead, I think it would be cool to say, hey lets all go to dinner this night. We know everyone can't make it, and that is ok. Lets just do it everyonce in a while just to meet and talk outside of a professional environment. Meeting socially is what will bond people. I dunno. It's just an idea.

Ok, so it was the week before spring break. At this point I was scrambling to try and find housing for the following week. Getting kicked out of the dorms is not fun. Paying 240 bucks to stay at school for spring break is even less fun! I was able to get a studio apartment through NC State for 30 a day, so things worked out. By this point I was working on a new phone with very unrefined software. It was a new experience working on something that did not have a bunch of support for already. It was completely new. Nothing really big happened with it, so it was just some minor adjustments.

fields.title: Spring Week 5: Monthly Meetings, and more on the projects
fields.post:
As far as the monthly meetings go, it is nice to meet up with everyone to see how things are going. Granted, I also like the fact that I get some free pizza out of it, but that is just a small perk. It is kind of a shame that the group doesn't get to hang out more like we did at the celebration in August. As it is, though, scheduling is hard to deal with. I can't really think of anything to change.

As far as projects go for this week, things in the coop went along well. I was still getting more comfortable with the system. If I remember correctly, we started to look at a new program that was in development that would help considerably with new phones. However, it was a VERY new experience for both myself and Justin, the other co-op in my team. Needless to say we just let the program run and tried to figure out what it was doing afterwards.

Not a whole lot else was happening at this point, so I'm sort of out of things to talk abut in this post.

fields.title: Spring Week 4: Review of January....
fields.post:
Well, I have returned. I'm slightly behind if you hadn't noticed. So I'm going to try and give a recap of each week really quickly. Here we go!

January was the start of something really new. It is the first time I'm working full time. Making real money is a great feeling, let me tell ya. It was interesting meeting new people and getting used to the system. I still had a lot to learn, but I was coming up to speed well. As far as the co-op was concerned, things were going about as well as I could have hoped.

SPARCS for the month of January was pretty easy for me. I'm more or less done with that project as far as planning. We had one meeting for it with the students, and attendance is down a bit. Shame. Things were going really well.

In all the rush with getting used to the job and everything, the mentoring project sort of took a back seat. More on this will come later.

Overall, January was a month of crazy schedules, new environments, and always something new around the corner. Unfortunately, as a side effect of all of this, some things have slipped. I have not had nearly the time to hang with friends as I have had in the past. Also, just personal time to relax has been scarce. At this point I was beginning to see that I was spread out too thin. I was starting to think of what needed to go.

More to come in the next post!

fields.title: Talent vs Hardwork
fields.post:
Question: Do you think certain people are innately good at computing or have they adapted to it?

First off, I don't think the two are mutually exclusive. However, regardless of whether or not someone is innately good at computing, they need to be able to adapt, because computing is a field that is constantly undergoing change. Someone who earned a CS degree in the 80s probably learned COBOL and FORTRAN, languages which are nearly dead in today's software world. If those people didn't adapt to the changing environment (in this case, languages), they found themselves without a job.
It reminds me of a saying, "hard work beats talent, when talent doesn't work hard." Sure you might start out as the leader, but you aren't going to keep your position at the top without any work.

fields.title: Week of March 9th
fields.post:
This week David and I were not scheduled to meet, as he and his team were planning on traveling to the nursing home for a visit. Hopefully this week they will try adding search engine lessons to the activities they do with the residents.

I did get to meet with Karl, and we had a productive meeting. We reviewed his progress on the knapsack HUD features. He found a useful tutorial on drawing images to the HUD, and he has written some of the code but not finished getting it integrated into the existing knapsack code. We discussed the schedule and project priorities for the next 1.5 months in preparation for the big April Crystal Island study.

I also discussed poster preparation with both David and Karl. Both will begin planning their updated posters and putting together an early first draft for review at next week's meeting. We'll spend the following week doing revisions and finalizing it before sending a draft to Lauren by March 27th.

Karl and David have both done a nice job making steady progress on their STARS projects this semester and attending regular STARS meetings. I am looking forward to seeing their poster drafts next week.

fields.title: Innateness VS. Adaptations
fields.post:
On the question of "do I think certain people are innately good at computing," my answer is of course.
...

Certain people are innately good at everything. I know I'm innately good at computing. If I wasn't naturally good at it, I don't think I'd be trying to work myself into the field. I want to be doing something I enjoy and that I'm good at.

However, do I think most people are innately good at computing? No. Most people I talk to in the department struggle with thier work and need a lot of practice at it inorder to do well. Many starting freshman in CSC do have to adjust the way they think and process things in a way condusive to computing. Once people adapt to computing, I think it becomes a lot easier for them like second nature or something. But I have to say I think computing isn't something your innately good at, the CSC department is tiny compared to many of the other majors around campus. People like doing what they're good at. And for most, computing is too much work.

fields.title: week 7 looking back/forward project update
fields.post:
So looking back I think I did well with my CSC116 mentoring goals...

All goals are completed, with only waiting on her final grade to be at least a B. Which at this point seems highly probable.
* My mentee has gotten A's on her last couple assignments,
* When she asks me a question, she can usually figure out the answer herself by the time she's done.
* She recognizes her syntax errors a lot quicker, and we have developed strategies for her to use on how to debug her programs.
* She is now able to help others in her class a little too.
* Because she has made so much progress we have dropped meeting with each other to just every other week.

This month we definitely built up her confidence in java. So instead of coming to me first thing, she actually tries to do most of her work. She understands that she just has to try different things, and have an idea of what to do before she starts coding. Having her be able to finish the bulk of her programs by herself has been a big accomplishment, so that way she isn't stuck depending on someone else the whole time and can think things through for herself.

I think next month we'll start reviewing things for her final exam. On her test there were a couple of concepts she was confused on, so we'll go over those, and hit up the list of the teachers outcomes, and see which of those we'll need to touch on again.

fields.title: CS Innate?
fields.post:
Over the years I've come to think that some aspects of being good at computer science are somehow innate. Computer science requires a different way of thinking about the world. You have to be able to abstract ideas and implement them in a different way. You have to think logically and realize that what you "mean" to do is not necessarily what you are doing. For some people, thinking in this way is easy and natural while for others it isnt.

That being said, I don't think there is anyone who *couldn't* succeed in computer science with enough effort. If you train yourself to think that way then there should be no problems. But I do think it may come harder to individuals who are less inclined to think that way on their own.

fields.title: What would help build unity within our STARS group and/or with other STARS groups
fields.post: I believe social events could help build unity a lot. The problem with these events is that everyone has to like them in order for them to be effective. For instance, going to the movies, skating, bowling, etc. Everyone has different interests as far as what they enjoy doing and if we can possibly find an activity that we unanimously agree on partaking in, unity would increase exponentially.

fields.title: Which of your goals did you complete this month? Did you complete a level of goals? Which of your goals do you plan to complete
fields.post: I have been unable to fully complete some of my project goals due to my college workload as well as some other things going on in my life. I am currently focusing on preparing a paper, poster, and presentation for a conference I shall be traveling to early next month. My preparation for this conference is top priority and I shall represent NC State to the best of my ability :)

fields.title: Do you think certain people are innately good at computing or have they adapted to it?
fields.post: I would say yes but this innate skill greatly depends on their affinity for computing. It is a matter of a person's mindset. For instance, I took the foreign language class Japanese last year. I have a great interest in that language and that same interest led me to unconsciously retain more of the material than in other classes where I have little or no interest.

fields.title: monthly meetings
fields.post:

I think the monthly meetings are very successful. Each STARS project is done by 1 or 2 people, so there isn't much mingling with the rest of the group. One way to improve the meetings is to get an update from everyone's project. I remember us doing this a few months ago, and I liked to hear how other groups were doing.

Well, my big goal for the past month was to come up with what to do for our final field trip at SPARCS. I think I've decided to take the kids to the life and science museum in Durham. There were a lot of feasibility issues with all the things I was considering, and in the end I think this is the best comprimise between relevent material and feasibility. fields.title: Meeting Improvements
fields.post:
Good
-Organized
+We rarely ever get sidetracked, there's always a clear direction with meetings
-Short
+During STARS meetings, I've never been thinking, "when am I ever gonna get outta here?!?"
-Food
+Added incentive to come to meetings

Improvements

+A few times I've felt we didn't really accomplish anything at the meeting, could these "filler" month meeting be rolled into the next month?
-Room
+The room we are in is great, but do we have other options?

Overall the meetings have been great!

fields.title: Team Unity
fields.post: Team unity is one of the most important qualitative aspects of a team. Unfortunately, it is also the most difficult to control. In order to build unity amongst ourselves, and our relationships with other STARS organizations, we must be willing to do one simple thing: spend time with each other. The only issue with this possible solution is with people's time commitments. I know it's hard enough as it is to find time for one monthly meeting for us, so it would definitely be a challenge to have a meeting with others STARS groups. To elaborate on "spending time", I mean doing something as a group, whether it be going bowling one night, or playing ultimate frisbee. It is also important that the events don't turn into what I like to call "forced fun", or things that no one really wants to do, and have very little value.

fields.title: Late blog that will clear the air on missing blogs
fields.post:
My apologies for my last blog, I meant to return to it with a weekly update to my blog but it never happen. By the time I returned to the blog I found myself not knowing which task was done in what week. So hopefully I can use this blog to give a clear update for all the missing blogs of February.

The idea of revamping the members page has been brought up at our weekly Website meeting. With our current design we have ran into problems with correctly linking previous members with the same project description that they had when they were working on it. (Project description often change a year if not a semester, as members find new ways to improve on present ideas.) So we (Lauren, Mark, and myself) have discussed setting up members and projects page based on semester/year using a drop down window to link to old semester/year and seeing which members worked on what.

Also the first steps for building database to manage STARS application has been underway by setting up the environment. There is also a wiki page in the making to help future STARS members setup an identical environment in case they wish to make improvement on our "final" release. The deadline for the database is April giving us close to three weeks to complete something, but if we are unable to get it functional by that time we will just have applicant's fill out the file and send to the liaison as usual but hopefully it will not come to that.

I almost had a heart attack just now. After clicking backspace key only expecting a character to disappear, I was taken to the previous screen. Fear that had lost all the above ^^^ information, I almost didn't even try clicking the forward button, since I have been disappointed before on other websites for losing what I have entered in a text box but has not been submitted in similar situations. All right I just wanted to rant that out.

We aren't sure if we'll be able to release it for the application process this year, but we will definitely have it finalized before the end of this year so it will be ready for next year. I'm working on writing the requirements for the website this week. We created a STARS Website book on Drupal and I'll be putting the requirements in there. Spring break is next week so we won't be meeting.

So as this month comes to an end, it's time to do some project updates. SPARCS is going good as usual I suppose. Not much happening there until the end of March.

She seemed to be having difficulty with constructors vs instances variables and passing parameters. She still slips on parameters every once in a while, but she is getting better at it. She has another project due this friday, so I'm supposed to meet up with her tomorrow to help her with any remaining questions she might have. She still doesn't like java that much, but she is happy she is finally understanding it.
Well, I guess that's all for now. I'll update later, happy Spring Break everyone.

fields.title: STARS Unity

Perhaps we ought to organize fun STARS events, like movie nights, or bowling. If we tacked them on to the end of the STARS meetings, this might ensure that most people would go.

As far as unity with other groups, I think we should really get more involved with WICS. They have many of the same goals as us, but sometimes seem to lack organization. I think a joint 116 mentoring project with the WICS group would be an excellent idea.
