fields.title: Equality in the IT department
fields.post: Very effectively backed up by recent data, the article examines the great discrepancy between pay and compensation increases for African Americans and the traditional majority whites. I certainly do agree that some imbalance gender-wise can be explained away, and that there are many fewer reasons for a racial imbalance, regardless of any sort of social mumbo-jumbo some people dream up. As expected, the satisfaction rates with their income parallel the same rates of pay, making African American workers less happy with their compensation than others. It is surprising, however, and definitely heartening to hear that although African Americans may be paid less, they are more satisfied with their decision to pursue a career in information technology. Thus this seems to indicate that in the long run the IT profession will both benefit from these satisfied workers and hopefully in turn reward them with equality here just as it has been done before.

fields.title: What has driven women out of computer science?
fields.post: Although they certainly seem to have a lot of statistics to back their suggestions up, their rational for why there are declining numbers of women in computer science seems to be me to be quite weak. The author offers a parallel between more women in the field and no video games, and then the large-scale implementation of video games and fewer numbers of women desiring to pursue a computer science degree. Then too there is the assumption that girls choose their career paths based on the desire to not be seen as a geek. Assuredly, there are some weak-minded females out there who do hold to these views on decision-making, but it is my hope that these are not the best reasons researchers can come up with to explain this gender imbalance. I did however, enjoy the comparison between "weak" aspects of computer science like web design and "hard" aspects like software engineering, especially coupled with the fact that more females enjoy the former and more males enjoy the latter. :P This article was obviously written by a man.

fields.title: Improving Monthly Meetings
fields.post:
I would like to begin the examination of monthly meetings by describing the two monthly meetings I have attending in my rather brief STARS career.

January 13th Meeting
This meeting served primarily to introduce new and returning STARS members to the whole STARS group. After introductions, Lauren reviewed mentor relationships and project assignments. Kristy tried to communicate with the group regarding posters and something about a "roadshow", but most of her efforts were fruitless. Members then met with their project groups to establish a meeting schedule. The pizza and soda were also tasty.

February 11th Meeting
The main item on the agenda was Stephane's presentation on the Centennial Challenge, which was met with unbridled disinterest. Lauren also reviewed the timeline for STARS posters and delivered some updates regarding STARS meetings.

Suggested Improvements
1) have each project group report on their progress (or lack thereof) since the last monthly meeting
2) have a STARS member deliver a presentation on something interesting (not necessarily CSC related)

I think that these suggestions would make the meetings more engaging.

fields.title: Reflection/Looking Forward
fields.post:
I think things are going well so far. I pretty much completed the first level of my goals. I've been meeting regularly with my mentee for 116. I went to my first SPARCS event which was really fun. Working with the kids and seeing what different ideas they had for the mindstorms was interesting. Most of them seemed to enjoy it, and by the end they were making up their own programs and designs. Plus, I know a bunch more names to go with faces.

by the end of the month, I hope to have more enrollment in the mentor program. if not thats okay, I think that class is rather easy anyways... meeting with my mentee after lunch seems to be working out well. we both have an hour or so free to touch base and see what's happening. something that I can improve for next month is probably helping out more with getting things set up at SPARCS. we had some technical delays and other issues arise before we could start the program.

fields.title: Semester Goals
fields.post:
Given the positive feedback obtained at the poster session in December, it became my goal to pursue the contacts with the Downtown Raleigh Alliance and the City of Raleigh's IT Department, and then to commit to helping to or even initiating their wireless mesh networking project.

Level 1 Goals:
Finally establish a working relationship with Raleigh's IT people (those who will run the overall project).
Discuss and develop a plan and structure working in conjunction with the aforementioned.
Begin implementation of a wireless mesh network in downtown Raleigh.

Level 2 Goals:
Adding on to the previous goals, it would be considered more successful if organizations like the Friday Institute or other students from NC State also became involved, as well as achieving support from Cisco or related experienced and generous company.

Level 3 Goals:
In addition to all of these goals, it would be amazing if before the end of the semester we had a test network up and running and we able to begin running some research on the traffic, load, or other aspects of it.

fields.title: Week of Feb 2nd

Two major accomplishments this week: David coordinated the Raleigh Rehab group's first trip out to the nursing home. The group decided to visit every other Friday at 3pm, and they had their first visit this week. Next Thursday, we'll be getting together to discuss his goals for the project and start thinking about opportunities to strengthen and grow the service effort, as well as enable it to persist after he finishes his involvement in STARS.

This past week Karl installed the most recent version of Crystal Island on his machine, played through the game, and attempted opening the associated source code (previously he had been working with pure Half Life 2 source). He ran into a few problems getting the Crystal Island project properly loaded, but during out meeting we resolved that issue. We also discussed technical avenues and requirements for implementing a HUD indicator for knapsack contents, as well as HUD code for the enhanced note taking functionality that he will be implementing. We found good places in the code for him to start working on these.

Roman and I are still working on successfully coordinating our first face-to-face meeting.

I have successfully implemented secondary features of the project, aspects that can be defined as additional project features. fields.title: Spring Week 3: A bit of an update...
fields.post:
Hello once again! So I'm always late on these things. Oh well. So freakin much going on. Hardly have time to do anything anymore. So I'm just going to give a little update on all the projects. Not a whole lot of detail, just a bit to get everyone caught up.

The co-op is going well. I finally have a little bit more guidance in my position. Overall, I'm starting to get settled in and used to the environment. Different from school, but its kinda cool.

SPARCS is still going along. We did Lego Mindstorms this past weekend, and it was pretty sweet. Unfortunately, attendance is down to about 10 people. It is sad to think that some of the kids are missing out on such fun things. Oh well. There isn't a whole lot more we can do about that.

Finally, we have the mentoring. I had a meeting last Wednesday for all interested students, and had emailed all the professors about it. We had a grand total of one student show up! And she is Veronica's suite mate. So, ya. Back to scratch with this. I'm working on drafting an email to the professors again to ask if we can come into the classes next week and actually tell the students what this is. From what I heard, the teachers were not exactly enthusiastic about what I was offering. Anyway, That is still an ongoing project. Hopefully there will be more to come. I'm kinda frustrated with that right now.

Well, thats about it. Now, I'm just exhausted. Untill next time!

fields.title: first nursing home visit of the semester
fields.post:
Our nursing home group made our initial visit for the spring semester this past Wednesday. We went at around 4:30pm and found out that the program coordinators leave at around 5pm, so they wanted us to get an earlier time. We decided that we would meet every other Friday now at around 3pm. So our next visit will be on the 20th.

This visit was a success. The residents wondered where we were for the past two months. They missed us :) . We could only work with 3 residents because their dinner started at 5. The 3 residents we worked with seemed like they had the e-mail thing down. Mr. Henry was e-mailing his son-in-law for the past few months about fishing trips and such. He also subscribed his e-mail to receive the winning lottery numbers everyday, which we thought was really cool. He is still having trouble with using the keyboard, so we are going to start up the typing tutor our next visit so they can get better at typing.

fields.title: Hope for equality in IT
fields.post:
I thought that this was an interesting article. It really brings into focus the point that equality in different fields is coming quiet slowly. I do find it interesting though that we were able to have an African-American elected president and yet the equality in the IT field is highly lacking. I would have imagined fields such as engineering would reach equality first before the position of president. It makes me wonder what is really the cause behind the lack of racial minorities in computing. I think it may have a lot to do with the idea that people have a hard time "seeing" themselves as computer scientists. Overall it was an intersting article.

On a side note: I don't like the line about "explaining away" gender differences in pay because of maternity leave, etc. The fact that people think it can be explained a way puts less emphasis on finding a solution to the problem.

fields.title: Spring Week 2: Are Women Really Driven out of Computer Science?
fields.post:
Hey! It's been all of like 2 minutes since I last wrote! Yep, I'm still waiting on laundry to finish. So I will sit here and jam out to some tunes as I report a bit on the projects and write a little bit on this NY Times article.

I'm in my third week at my Co-op and everyone there is so nice. Its very different going to this environment as opposed to school. It is surprisingly laid back to this point. Yes, there is an urgency to finish the specific task at hand, but its not as if we are constantly being hounded by quizes and tests to check our understanding or anything. It is also REALLY nice to not have any homework. However, I do feel as though I am kind of detached from the other students on campus. Sure, I still live on campus, but I just don't have that same connection anymore. I am still trying to find that right balance of work and play. I imagine it will come soon enough. Things still havent settled down enough to find a routine.

In SPARCS we have already had our first session of the year. It was kind of improvised, but went over well enough with the students. It is amazing to see how they have grown. I can't wait for the next one. I absolutely love Legos. Not a whole lot else to report on this. It is just sorta going.

As for the Mentoring project, I am in the process of writing to the professors to see if they are interested in offering their students mentoring. Unfortunately I've been behind on everything and am still working on this. I'm sorry to everyone that is taking part in this. I'm working on getting things running. There will be more to report on next week.

Finally, a little comment on the article. It's really kind of shocking. Then again, there are other things to think about. I wonder if the number of men going into Computer Science has increased? I mean, typically they are looking to go into video game design and the like. This is a blooming industry that generally guys are more interested in. I wonder whether that has had enough of an impact to skew the numbers that much. Now, that is just me speculating. It could be completely wrong. The whole article is just food for thought. Really makes you wonder what it will take to get equal representation.

Have a great rest of the week, and GO STATE!!! Beat Carolina!!!!!

Semester goals. What a broad topic. I guess there are a few different things I will have to cover here. First, I will start with my Co-op, and then I will continue to the CSC 116 Mentoring project. I'll finish up with a final note on SPARCS.

Now for the 116 Mentoring. Again, I'm rather vague. Level 1 is for myself and my counterparts to make friends to some of the 116 students and have a good time. Thats it for this blog. Time to write the one for this week :)

fields.title: Warning: Long Rant on Women in Comp Sci
fields.post:
So after reading the New York Times article What Has Driven Women Out of Computer Science?, I find myself at a new state of wonder. In general, I have always been a minority in my classes, if not for one thing, than another. Nevertheless, I don’t feel like a minority because I just fit in so well. However, after reading this article of back in the day when the boy-girl ratio was just 6-1 in comp sci, I begin to wonder, why did it drop so much? Heck, if the ratio was 6-1 now that'd be awesome. I think now in my classroom of 100-125 students, there are about 4 girls including myself. That makes the ratio roughly 30-1. So now it really puts into focus how much of a minority girls really are.
...

The article talks about how comp sci is a family thing, and kids join the major because their family did computers. Neither of my parents did computers, one did chemical biology and the other did factory work. Then it says how the girl games failed. I personally enjoyed the Barbie computer games. Plus, Talking Barbie even came with her own mini desktop computer. How cool was that? The girl games worked fine for me. Then when the article talks about the pejorative figure of "nerd" and "geek"; I'm thinking more along the lines of "geek-chic" and "adorkable.” This article was published in November of 2008; did they completely miss the Tina Fey thing? Outgoing girls with a nerdy vibe are totally in right now.

So although I disagree with much of this article, I will agree on the getting students involved with computer science at a younger age. I liked computers since 4th grade when we were making pictures in Kid-Pix. I think my little sister was three, when I started showing her how to work a computer. There are numerous studies out that say learning things are easier at a younger age, like speed reading, 2nd/3rd languages, music, swimming. Why should computers be any different? I think MySpace is responsible for 80% of 12-19 year olds learning html codes. All you have to do is make the programming, coding, computing, networking, whatever it is, relevant to students, or at least appealing. Spice it up with fun activities, or cool graphics. Once people are interested, then you can begin to delve into the deeper less appealing stuff. As a writer, if you open up with, “The sociological patterns that occur in society can be directly correlated with the environmental factors that an individual experiences as a young person,” not that many people will be interested. However, if you open with, “When I was little I would think of ways to kill my daddy,” you just hooked a massive audience.

Do I think there are too few girls in comp sci? Yeah… sure, I guess so. Do I think they are being driven out? No Way! I think the bigger issue is that the field isn’t as appealing to women as others might be. I think girls these days want to strive for bigger and better things like curing cancer or solving world hunger. When you ask the average person what a computer scientist does, they’ll pretty much blank. Comp Sci lacks the PR of doctors, lawyers, and fashion designers; it’s just the way things currently are. Can it be fixed? I think so.

fields.title: Week of Jan 19th
fields.post:
This week was a bit unusual given the holiday and snow day, which interrupted my weekly STARS meeting plans. I intended to have kick-off meetings with each of Karl, David, and Roman, but ended up only being able to have a meeting w/ Karl. I was able to have e-mail contact with both David and Roman, fortunately.

David is about to re-commence this semester's trips to the Raleigh Rehab Center service project. This project was a great success last semester, and David deserves a lot of credit for making it such an active and fruitful effort. Hopefully this semester we'll be able to expand the program's reach or activities, and also make the necessary preparations to ensure that it continues after David is finished with STARS at the end of the Spring.

Later last semester, Karl implemented an excellent mini-inventory system in Half Life 2 that I intend to add to Crystal Island soon. I have also given him a copy of Crystal Island to tinker with on his own. Moving forward, we have a number of project ideas and goals for him: first he intends to put together installation instructions for his face tagging tool. Next, he will work on some of the extensions requested by Joe Grafsgaard for the face tagging tool. There are also a number of Crystal Island projects he can work on, including a streamlined note-taking functionality and updated map overlay feature. Karl's choice among these projects will be solidifed after he completed the face tagger documentation. In terms of semester goals, he hopes to have a "complete" and well-documented version of the Face tagger tool that is in use by the IntelliMedia research group, as well as a collection of enhancements contributed to the Crystal Island environment that will be deployed in a large study with CCMS in April.

Meetings with Roman have been a bit challenging given the distance and conflicting schedules, but we hope to be able to meet next week. Roman has been working on creating web forms to be used for story collections on the Narrative Theater project. He has made some progress on this, and I hope he can finish it early this semester and move on to building tools for dynamically presenting information to the user over time (to be used for dynamic hinting, eventually).

My goals for the semester are to help ensure David, Karl, and Roman achieve their respective project goals, and succeed academically in general.

fields.title: Project Progress - Website
fields.post: The STARS website project is currently in the planning phase, and the team produced a rather comprehensive list of goals and objectives. Many goals require only "simple edits" to existing website content, such as updating member profiles and project descriptions (1.1 and 1.2). Other goals, such as the online STARS application (2.1, 3.1, and 3.3), will require a substantial development effort. Some goals (4.1) may not see completion for some time, but such goals are fortunately classified as "outlandish".

fields.title: Project Progress

So far this semester we have had one session on computer security. I think it went relatively well. The material may have been to difficult for students, though. fields.title: Poster Session
fields.post:
So my blog is going to focus on the administrative stuff, since thats where my head was for most of the session. Overall, I think the poster session was fantastic! We had a great turnout of students, faculty, and industry representatives. Some things that I would do differently and keep the same next year:

  • Start setting up about 40 minutes ahead of time! We screeched in finishing everything up right as the clock ticked 1:00. I wish we wouldn't have cut is so close. I had two people help me setup, but I wish I would have had 4--there was just a lot to carry! Additionally, we had some industry sponsors arrive early (I didn't know people did that any more), so it would have been nice to be setup a few minutes early.
  • Bring a can opener! So this wasn't the end of the world as I was able to sneak one out of the faculty lounge, which I didn't even know existed until that morning, but thats one thing that I wish I would have just brought with me.
  • Plan my outfit at least a day ahead of time! By the time I started picking out my outfit for the event, it was about 11:45 the night before. I freaked out when ALL of my pants were too short to wear with my heels. It was completely devastating. I don't know what happened to my pants, so I think I'll blame it on the dry cleaners. I kind of freaked out and, of course, I didn't have any tights at my apt, so I had to go pick some up at Harris Teeter the next morning. Not the most ideal situation.
  • Buy punch ingredients a couple of days ahead of time! Who would have thought that Harris Teeter, one of the nicest grocery stores in Raleigh, would not have concentrated fruit punch? It seems like a staple. Well, they don't. I had to make a last minute run to Food Lion that morning. Thats right, FOOD LION saved the punch!
  • Hold the event in conjunction with Posters and Pies! I really think this boosted our turnout. Posters and Pies was scheduled 10:40-1:00 and we were scheduled 1:00-3:00. Posters and Pies really raps up around 12:30, so I think it would have been even better to start at 12:30. Since the industry sponsors were already around for Posters and Pies, they stuck around for our event, which was great.
  • Bring a camera! Ok, so this sounds like an obvious one, but Kristy and I both forgot our cameras, so we had to go searching for one in order to capture the moment.
  • Bring a spare outfit! I'm actually borrowing this tip from Ms. Heil from Senior Design. I made a last minute trip out to my car before the event in my heels, and it almost killed me. I should have left my tennis shoes on until right before. The parking deck is just too far when you're carrying heavy stuff to be walking around in heels. My feet ached the entire event.
  • Enjoy delicious punch! I really just had to throw this one in here, because, lets face it, my punch was amazing!

fields.title: Poster Session (and cookies)
fields.post:
In my opinion, and relating to my project, the poster session went VERY well. I had all kinds of people, from fellow students to those heavily connected with pertinent research and industry, ask me questions and seem quite interested in becoming involved next semester, particularly for getting a wireless mesh networking testbed up and running in Raleigh. I thoroughly enjoyed discussing current events in this field, as well as the various theories on implementation, with these interested people, and received a whole lot of encouraging feedback. Contacts from within the university as well as outside its boundaries (Cisco, the Downtown Raleigh Alliance) expressed pleasure and a willingness to set up meetings with me sometime early next spring semester to discuss how best to move forward with this project. I certainly am now much more looking forward to my STARS work this coming spring, and hoping to see this project through to fruition.

Oh, and the cookies and punch were quite tasty as well. :)

fields.title: Poster Session
fields.post: I thought the poster session went well for the entirety that I was there :) I got some good questions and was able to answer them. I'm looking forward to continuing this research next semester and will surely get everything up and running.

I did learn something new at the session. A student who came to look at my poster pointed out some new technologies that are being designed for instructing computer science so I plan to look into those to incorporate into future SPARCS sessions.

As a bonus, I can confidently follow conversations that might drop terms such as API, or client library, etc. These terms seem to come up frequently in application development. Now, at least I can follow other's in conversation and occasionally do a nice vocabulary tech word drop so I can sound smart too!

fields.title: Creating a Poster
fields.post:
I've decided that creating a poster is not difficult- however, having a group of people definatively decide that a poster is at a final version IS. I became completely lost trying to keep track of which version was which, thus making it very appealing to pretend that the poster does not exist and just to stick my head in the sand over the whole thing. I resisted this urge, however, and managed to work with my group editing and completing the poster.

I thought having one meeting devoted to reviewing other group's posters was a good idea. It forced us prepare a final version of our poster. I determined that once I corrected the grammatical errors caught by my STARS mates, that this would be the final version and ready for print.

I think if I need to work with a group next time to create a poster, I will pick a "due date" where we must write an AGREE message to the others in the group by that time over whatever the latest version is. If you don't write AGREE by then, well then too bad, you lost your opportunity to vote. Sounds cruel, but that's the way the world works!

fields.title: Poster Session
fields.post:
The poster session went pretty quick. I thought I was going to die standing up in one spot for two hours straight, but I survived and learned some interesting things while doing it.
I was really impressed with Anne's poster. Somehow, I was completely out of it, and never really had the opportunity to really read up on her project this semester. I read her poster about meshable networking in Raleigh and I thought "wow, that's a GOOD idea" It's very useful and practical- additionally, it will help Raleigh become more of a urban center and be an asset financially speaking for the RTP area.
What a forward thinking idea. GOOD JOB ANNE!

fields.title: STARS club...bonding....
fields.post:
Looking back over the semester, I feel that I got to know my fellow STARS people pretty well. The initial trip to Auburn really put a jump start towards meeting the various people in our group. We had primarily meetings, not too many social functions, although we did get to watch a ECU v NCstate game together. Sometimes it is difficult because we're all very busy and come from such different walks of life.
However, I hope to help get people together more often to promote the feeling of unity within the group. I'm moving to a condo that has a pool table, shuffleboard, poker tables (for the gutsy), pool, firepit, grill, movie room, etc in downtown Raleigh. Hopefully, getting people together in a nice relaxed social atmosphere that includes games/water/fire could help every one feel a better connection.

fields.title: Semester Reflection
fields.post:
For me, this semester reflection turns a bit more into a reflection upon my first college experiences, starting way back in the summer. My very first act as an NC State student was traveling solo to Auburn for the STARS Celebration. Thus my perceptions of State and college computer science research were first shaped by being involved in STARS and this research project: and they were, of course, encouraging.
In terms of my self-initiated wireless mesh networking project, I can say with satisfaction that I have fulfilled all of my personal goals. I have definitely pursued a area of research that I find fascinating and totally relevant in today's society. I have also started inroads on perhaps initiating a testbed in the City of Raleigh, both for research as well as for the benefit of citizenry. Thus I am satisfied and encouraged by my experiences this semester in such a research organization that desires to both increase the knowledge of its members and the participation of minorities in the super-awesome field of computer science.

fields.title: Creating a Poster
fields.post:
Not that I didn't think doing a poster was a good exercise, but what I didn't expect was to be so involved after I began. We were all given a template, of course, for our STARS formatted posters, but I was not sure initially how to proceed, or even what to put where! I did enjoy decorated my poster with our NC State colors and logo (wolfpack pride ^_^), and then settled down into the harder work.
I eventually did figure out some sort of system to divide the essential points of my work/research on mesh networking and free wireless systems. This sort of organization certainly helped me align my thoughts and accomplishments more constructively, something which I think will serve me well during the upcoming poster session. My experiences on my project this past semester have been a bit disjunctive, in terms of flowing smoothly from one step to the next, and so creating my poster to reflect logical transitions was both helpful and a bit challenging at the same time. Still, I do believe I have learned a lot about how to professionally present my findings in poster format.

fields.title: Thanksgiving
fields.post:
I know I don't have to write a blog topic this week, but I'm going to do one anyway. This Thanksgiving, for some reason, I got the crazy idea I'd get the backpack feature for Crystal Island working. Generally, once I start working on something, I can't stop until it's done (except for paperwork, I can drop that at any time). After a day, I had some very basic functionality. Was that good enough? no, of course not. So, the next day I fixed a few exceptions, and made the feature configurable. Here's a breakdown of how it all works:

The stow/retrieve function is a Console Command (ConCommand in Source), with a Console Variable (ConVar) which stores the location of a safe spot (for objects). The reason I chose this route is ConCommands can be bound to a key, allowing for great usability and configurability, and the ConVar can be changed in-game, and is saved in the configuration file.
I added a pointer to a CBaseEntity (the basic entity class in Source) which holds the entity currently being stored (null if there isn't one), as well as getter and setter methods (this is all in the hl2_player class)

Here's the basic outline of the function

  • The user presses the key (or uses the stow_item command)
  • The method checks if there is an entity being held by the player (via GetPlayerHeldEntity())
  • if not Null (item being held), check if there is *not* an item stowed (getStowedEntity())
    1. force the player to drop the item (ForceDropOfCarriedPhysObject())
    2. Stow the item held (setStowedEntity())
    3. teleport the item to a hidden location (Teleport())
  • if Null (no item held), check if there is an item stowed (getStowedEntity())
    1. Teleport the item to the user's position (Teleport())
    2. Make the player pick up the item (PickupObject())
    3. Delete the reference to the stowed item (setStowedEntity(NULL))

It's a little more complicated then that, but that's the gist of it (it's only about 60 lines, most of which are comments).

The only caveat is this was created in a Single-Player mod, while Crystal Island is a Multiplayer mod, but it shouldn't be very difficult to transfer over. Also, a possible future extension would be to allow for storage of multiple items (right now, it only stores one item), but for right now I'll finish polishing this first.
I'll bring it to the poster session so I can get feedback/show it off.
On a side note, I thought that string parsing would suck in C++, but it was actually pretty easy (I used the strtok method to parse the comma-separated values - never learned that in my C class for some reason)

fields.title: More reflection
fields.post:
Wow, it seems like yesterday I was reflecting over the past month. Well, this month, I worked on some qualitative goals, namely understanding the source engine. This is pretty much the equivalent of opening a new book, closing my eyes, flipping to a random page, pointing to a word, start reading, and try to make sense of the entire book. Fortunately, the Valve developer wiki is a great resource and has great documentation on *most* of the classes (some classes have abysmal documentation).
One of my goals was, "Complete individual features/tasks in time to be used for studies (these have yet to be defined)" This has been further defined to include:

1) Improvement of the note-taking feature
2) A microscope mini-game (feature)
3) An authoring tool

Obviously none of these will realistically be fully implemented by the end of this semester, but they will become realistic goals with hard deadlines next semester.

Also, I helped out Allen (my mentee) with some more homework/projects/advice. That is working out well, and I'm pretty sure he's sticking with CSC.

fields.title: Poster Status
fields.post: My poster has been coming along well, mainly because I've been adding on to the same basic ideas as last semester's poster. I take that back, only half of my poster is similar to last semester's because of the addition of the usability section. The video tagger section is similar to last semester's, with a few noticeable updates. Also, after a few problems last semester, I will not use openoffice to create my poster. I'm a free software advocate, just as much as the next guy, but the frustration of dealing with minor, albeit important, formatting issues is too much to leave to chance. I will resign to using powerpoint (although I'll use the school's license).

fields.title: SPARCS MIDDLE SCHOOL OUTREACH
fields.post: Saturnday 11-22-08 at Centennial Campus Middle School. It was part three to the Alice Programming. The Centennial student learn about how to creat their own method and how to creat a new variable. Once again the student enjoy the session we had for them.

fields.title: Week 12: Semester Reflection
fields.post:
Well, the end of another week is here! And thus it brings us to the weekend before Thanksgiving, letting us know that Christmas is just around the corner! Yay!!! Anyway, onto the blog for the week.

Well, the semester is drawing to a close, and exams are approaching. As that happens, we wind down what was a great start for the SPARCS program. We still have one more weekend coming up for it, but it is more or less done with for the semester. Things have been going swimmingly. We have retained pretty much every student, which is a big step up from last year, losing half of them by the third session. This was one of our big goals. We really wanted to have the students continue through the entire year and not drop on us. The students are also really starting to open up and enjoy what we are doing. Sure, we have had some bumps along the way with some difficult material in Alice, but overall they are having a blast.

Next semester, I will be co-oping with Sony Ericsson, and will be running the CSC 116 mentoring program. In addition to that, I will still participate in the SPARCS outreach. Should be a busy semester :)

Have a great Thanksgiving everyone!!!

fields.title: Semester Reflection
fields.post:
Wow - the semester has flown by. The poster session is in two weeks. I thought I'd start be reiterating my goals from the beginning of the semester. Goals in bold are completed.

Level 1 Goals

* Update members page on the website with new members
* Update projects page on the website with new 2008 projects
* Create an archive page for previous years' projects (The basic page is up, but there is a little more I would like to do with it.)
* Create a clear description of what STARS is and what STARS students do. (Can't believe I let this one slip by me!)
* Check on current sponsorship with Ken Tate and Kristy and update website to reflect this
* Plan and execute the end-of-semester poster session (In progress)

Level 2 Goals

* Get the STARS website posted on the CSC website
* Create a page for Alumni STARS members to detail life after graduating
* Make the STARS application an online application
* Create links to other Raleigh STARS groups
* Include a Google Calender to the Events page
* Plan an event with the other STARS groups (We had a Reaching for the STARS Weekend. Next semester I'd like to do something with all of the Raleigh groups.)

Level 3 Goals

* Verify that the entire website is 508 compliant
* Develop a log in process for Alumni to enter their information
* Plan a "fun" STARS outing
* Plan a STARS road-show for local high-schools
* Expand and customize the Drupal site to better fit our needs. For example, get the feed aggregator working correctly, customize the template to better match the STARS website, and create some sort of auto-backup system.
* Partner with other CSC student organizations to plan a training workshop for high school Computer Science teachers.

So, reflecting on these goals, I didn't accomplish as much as I would have liked. I think the work for next semester is clear and we have some more ideas to add in. Rob and I have a tendency to chat during meetings about what is going on in our lives (which I don't think is necessarily a negative) and we rarely pull up the goals to see where we should be headed. I think that is the primary reason why we didn't accomplish as many of our goals. However, I think we had a very successful semester. We updated what really needed to be posted and even got Google calendar on our site. This has made it so much easier for me to post upcoming events. Next semester, Rob won't be interning and I should have more time to devote to the project, so I'm excited about what we'll accomplish. Our big goal for next spring is to put the STARS application in an online form.

As far as events for next semester, Marivic suggested having some women in industry come talk with us about professional development. I would really like to pursue this idea next semester.

fields.title: Week of Nov 17th
fields.post:
Some ideas for STARS next semester:

- If any students are looking for a new STARS project, it would be fantastic for someone to try and revive the STARS / ACM / WiCS scavenger hunt that was partially planned last Spring. Hopefully enough groundwork has been laid that it could actually be executed this semester, as long as someone was available to actually dedicate some time to making it happen. I think a scavenger hunt with the STARS name attached could give a lot of good publicity to the organization.

- I think organizing another STARS movie night would be fun for sometime early in the semester. I think having group activities is a nice way for the group to bond, get off campus, and have some fun. Any movies anyone wants to see? I still haven't seen Dark Knight in IMAX. . . Grabbing a group dinner out sometime might also be fun.

- Last year we had an "Applying to gradschool" info session led by a couple of the STARS graduate students that received some very positive feedback. This might be appealing to a broader audience, as well as to students at the other Raleigh STARS institutions. We have several first, second, and third year grad students who could probably contribute to this event again. I am sure I still have my slides from last year.

- I think that having both a dinner and a separate poster presentation at the end of the year last year was not a good use of resources or time. I would strongly encourage combining these two events into a single event this year.

fields.title: Week of Nov 10th
fields.post:
This week I met with both David and Karl to help them with their respective posters. Both of them have done excellent work this semester, so it is a pleasure to have the opportunity to help them structure their projects into a presentable form.

Helping with Karl's poster has been relatively straight forward, since I have been closely connected to the project for some time now. Karl now has version 1.0 of his face tagging tool available, and it should begin seeing use very soon by Joe Grafsgaard for his written prelim work. In Karl's poster, he talks about his progress on the face tagging tool and some of the valuable feedback / requested extensions offered by Joe. I'm hoping that Karl will be able to demo his tool during the poster presentation. Additionally, some of Karl's poster is looking forward to the work he will be doing in the Crystal Island environment this / next semester, implementing gameplay extensions. All in all, Karl's progress is very exciting for our lab and work in Crystal Island.

Helping with David's poster has been a little bit more challenging, because I am less familiar with his project than I am with Karl's (I just began mentoring David this past month). Fortunately, David has been fantastic in terms of being pro-active with his poster and his nursing home project. I think he has put together a really nice poster that effectively emphasizes the activities he and others are organizing at the Raleigh Rehabilitation Center. I was particularly impressed when David told me that not only had he taken photos of their activities at the nursing home, but he had already gotten residents' signatures on consent forms allowing him to use the pictures in presentations / posters. David's poster talks about how his service group is helping residents with typing skills, basic computer usage, and e-mail. Further, he briefly mentions some future plans for including web cams and microphones to the sessions. I am confident this is *very* exciting for the folks at the Raleigh Rehab Center, and I'm excited for STARS supporters to see his poster presentation.

fields.title: Week of Nov 3rd
fields.post:
I have completed some of my semester goals (laid out in my initial blog post), and partially completed others. As seems to always be the case, I haven't progressed as far on my goals as I may have initially hoped, but progress is progress. In order of their original presentation:

1. Written prelim: I have not written or scheduled my written prelim as originally hoped, but this was probably an overly ambitious goal to begin with. Fortunately, I have still made substantial progress on it. I have a much clearer direction on what to do, I am developing a concrete schedule for accomplishing shorter term goals for the project, and I have a newly revised goal of finishing it (taking the exam) prior to Spring break. It's kind of silly that it has taken as long as it has, but this time I feel confident that it will actually get accomplished. My written prelim will focus on using dynamic bayesian networks for modeling user state (e.g., content knowledge) while playing Crystal Island. I'll implement a version of Crystal Island that has the bayesian framework plugged in and informing some simple scaffolding in the environment, run a focus group of think-a-loud studies with the game, and perform some qualitative analysis on the data. So while the project isn't as far along as my original goal hoped, it's much farther along than it WAS.

2. Crystal Island: I have successfully implemented several new versions of Crystal Island for a pair of studies with middle school students this semester. While the versions represented incremental advances rather than large leaps, it was still gratifying to refine the narrative environment and get experience conducting large studies with middle school students.

3. Narrative Theater foundation: Roman has been working on building some of the basic infrastructure for the Narrative Theater, namely tools to collect stories via web browser. Our group has not yet migrated to a new game technology for internal reasons, but the shift is expected to occur in the Spring. However, we have begun conducting a large scale corpus study for the project which has been quite successful thus far. This is a major milestone for the project, and should provide a valuable springboard for a lot of work throughout the Spring.

fields.title: Internship Poster
fields.post: Rob, Kate, and myself were working on our internship poster for the end of the semester event for STARS. I learned a lot from my internship and discovered how a mature process for software development looks like. I also learned what my other friends in STARS are doing in their internship. We are really fortunate to have NCSU close to the Triangle area -- one of the best places in the country for the IT industry. More than this, we are lucky to have these companies value NC State graduates!! The department is producing good students. We must be doing something right!!! We should get our next to final poster this week and have it shown the first week of December. This has been a very busy semester for me but with lots of skills learned from both my academic research and internship.

fields.title: Posters!
fields.post: This week we are working on posters for the end of semester poster presentation. I have only made a few posters in the past and I am certainly not an expert. We ended up taking last year's poster for the same project and modifying it to have current information. I am very excited to be showing off the Google Calendar integration. I did my best to maintain intentional alignment throughout the poster--but thats really the only design technique I know. I am excited to see how everyone's posters turn out!

fields.title: Poster
fields.post: The post isn't coming along as well as I expected. The problem I have exists with results I expected to have obtained by this point in time. Regardless of the case, I am meeting with my graduate student mentor later today, and together, we'll be sure to turn the project into something presentable.

fields.title: REFLECTION/LOOKING FORWARD
fields.post: As far as this month goes, I am still working on generating a test driver, one of the initial tasks required of me. There are complexities when it comes to comparing method behavior. When it comes to methods with return values, it's easier to compare them, but for void methods, I will require use of observer methods. Thus I am still within this phase, which is probably the most important of all. With the deadline coming up, I doubt I'll be able to get any good results, but I sure will try.

fields.title: Exciting Use of Computer Science
fields.post: I find how computer science can be applied to almost anything these days to be the most exciting thing of all. It ranges greatly from computers, obviously, to even things such as the anti-lock brakes we have in our cars. You see computer science everywhere in today's world, and it seems that it will only increase in use. My interests lie in the game development aspect, and I am astounded at how it has evolved in such a short period of time.

fields.title: WiFi Project Update
fields.post:
As the end of the semester draws nearer, many things, including my STARS project, are inevitably wrapping up to a conclusion. And while sometimes it seems like I'm counting the days that keep slipping away, other times I feel that I have fully used the time I had to accomplish good things. In speaking of my project, I have decided to classify it under the 'service learning' aspect of the STARS initiatives. And although in this case the community in which I am trying to 'do good' is a bit lacking in response, other aspects of the involved population have come together to make this a truly engaging and informative experience.
In terms of the goals I had outlined in earlier posts, I did not, as previously supposed, manage to create a working relationship with parties interested in pursuing a wireless solution for the City of Raleigh. I did, however, complete my goals of developing a working knowledge of the current theories of mesh networking, along with their current implementations, effectiveness, and known vulnerabilities. As such, my work on my poster and completion of my project is resulting in the distribution to public knowledge of the implications of a city-wide wireless solution and a proposal to the City of Raleigh suggesting such a planned solution.

fields.title: Week 11: Posters
fields.post:
Hey! Its been all of like 5 minutes! I figure if I have the time to write, I might as well get completely caught up. So, here we go!

Yep. So we are now making posters for this semester. We are pretty much going to keep it to one poster for SPARCS, so I am here for help if Jen needs it. I am really curious to see how they all turn out. Its a pretty neat thing to see all the results from the semester on all these projects. There were so many good ideas at the convention this semsester. Anyway, thats about all I have to say. Have a great rest of the week!

fields.title: Week 10: Reflection
fields.post:
Well, I am behind again. Dont you just love all that hw and stuff that seems to clutter our lives so much? It seems so hard to keep on top of stuff when more just keeps getting piled on. Sigh. Thats life though. Onto this past weeks blog entry.

Well, over the last month, we have done two SPARCS sessions (I will go ahead and include this past weekend since it has happened). It has been really exciting to see it come to life and meet the kids. There is always something new to learn and you never know who you will meet. I mean, we just started messing with Alice this weekend, and I figured it couldnt really be that exciting. I mean, you just drag and drop commands in. Sure, there are cute characters, but what could be that cool? Well, it turns out that all the "mistakes" you make on the way to the final project are the most amusing things ever! You try and have a bunny move, and instead the head just falls off! Sorry if that is morbid or anything, but it was hilarious at the time. These kids have such imagination. It makes you wonder what happened to all of our imagination from middle school. Its a shame we done have it anymore.

So, thats my reflection. Back to the world of work and stuff. Yay.....

fields.title: reflection
fields.post:
Level 1 Goals:
-Find a nursing home that will be best to work with from the list of possible locations.
-Make sure the nursing home has enough computers, laptops, webcams, and possibly a projector for the visually impaired.
-Set up a network in the nursing home if they do not have one.

Level 2 Goals:
-Teach the residents how to use e-mail and other communication services a computer can provide.
-Collect e-mail addresses and contact info from resident's loved ones so they can communicate with each other.

Level 3 Goals:
-Try to get more volunteers so get more residents involved in this project.
-If loved ones come visit the residents, we can maybe do an "outreach" activity with the little kids that come visit.

Our project completed Level 1 Goals after last week's visit to the nursing home. I checked out two laptops from the CSC department on Nov. 4th and used them on our visit on the 5th. Each one of us can now work one-on-one with residents instead of just working with one computer. It went really well, and the residents had fun with it. We were unaware that the nursing home had wireless, so that sums up the level 1 goals. We haven't included webcams during the meetings, so in the future we plan on including them. We are working on the Level 2 goals now. The residents know the basics of e-mail use, but need to get more familiar with it. Hopefully we can try to complete the Level 3 goals next semester.

fields.title: SPARCS MIDDLE SCHOOL OUTREACH
fields.post: This past Saturday was the secord workshop of the Sparc Middle School Outreach at Centennial Campus Middle School. Are focus for this workshop was Alice Programming. We talked little bit about Alice and let the students do their on programming on Alice. Students had so much fun working on the Alice.

fields.title: exciting use of computer science
fields.post:
I've seen many uses of computer science in the real world. One that interests me is when it is used in sports. In tennis, they use a computer vision system known as Hawk Eye to pinpoint where the tennis ball lands on the court, just in case there is a discrepancy between a player and referee. Players are granted two challenges per set, and its definitely made an impact in past tennis tournaments. Hawk Eye helped settle a BIG controversy at Wimbledon 2007 during the Federer-Nadal match. If you go to the link at the bottom, you'll see that Hawk Eye picked up on something that even the cameras at different angles could not pick up. Its very useful, and it looks like its here to stay for future tournaments.

Hawk Eye innovations is working with many other sports, and you can find more information here: http://www.hawkeyeinnovations.co.uk/

fields.title: Facebook
fields.post:
I finally figured out how to post simple Javascript apps on facebook. I don't want to try to teach anything more complicated than making a simple radiobutton based quiz, so I'm feeling good about the level that I've built the apps. However, I want to figure out how to manipulate a Javascript API-REST object (my apologies if the jargon there is wrong). I want the students to be able to invite friends to try his/her app and to have the app results appear on "the wall". I'm sure it won't be too complicated once I figure it out (that's usually how these things work) but in the meanwhile I'll be pondering over that and attempting not too get overly fustrated at myself for not solving it quicker!
Once I get that determined, I would like to make a simple Java to Javascript lesson plan, describe some of the basic architecture behind facebook, then show them how to submit an application (trickier than one would assume). Hopefully, that'll give anyone the basic tools to make simple apps that they could share their friends, thereby receiving positive reinforcement from someone other than us computer dorks ;-)

fields.title: STARS Poster
fields.post:
The Internship poster is coming along very nicely, and I give the most credit to Marivic! Rob and I were really impressed by her "draft" (more like a beautiful, final copy). So we certainly have what we need by Friday's deadline.
For once, I'm ahead of schedule :-)

fields.title: Poster Status
fields.post:
Truthfully my poster is not started. However, I do have plans.

Panel 1 - Description of STARS. What our goals are, how the sessions are structured, and a bit of info about last year's program

Panel 2 - CSUnplugged. A description of the activities, how successful they were, with some data from the students

Panel 3 - Alice. Same basic info from above.

Its a busy week so I'll have to start later than I'd otherwise like, but I'm sure I'll be done by Friday :)

fields.title: Reflection/Looking Forward
fields.post:
So, in order to reflect on my goals for last month I figured it'd help if I reposted here:

Level 1
Retain 50% of students through the entire program. Last year, we only retained about 1/3 so hopefully we can do better this time

Level 2
Get an overall positive rating on surveys.
Have an increased interest in computer science careers between pre and post surveys

Level 3
90% interest in computer science careers on post survey

So far, we're doing great on level 1 and 2 goals. We have unfortunately had 1 drop out to date, but that was because our activities were too low level for him. This was an eighth-grader who already knew about binary number storage, the Eliza system and had written programs in Basic and C++. Given this, I'm not too upset that he found learning all these things "boring". Other than that 1 student, we have increased numbers over the past session, and really increased the number of girls (from 3 to 6) so I really think this year is going to be a hit. We have two more sessions this year and overall I think my personal goal will be to keep the paperwork more organized.

fields.title: What is the most exciting use of Computer Science you have seen?
fields.post:
(Can't believe I'm so behind on my blogging! Ah, the stress of too much to do at once!)

The most exciting? Wow, let me tell you, I am into computers strictly because I think they are one of the most exciting things around, especially since you can come up with so many new and cool applications. I have to say, what with election fever these past few months, electronic voting machines and their related systems are certainly a very intriguing use of modern computer science and networking theory. Intriguing, not in the least because still the four largest suppliers of these voting machines still cannot get it right. The more sane among us computer scientists and assorted educated bloggers (sadly, not very many politicians) are calling for open source software powering these quite essential devices, or at least a decent audit once in a while. Consider this: instead of having to manually, taking a whole lot of time, count millions upon millions of ballots cast all over the country, meaning no central effort can be made; instead, to instantly transmit results of any sort of voting outcome (election, proposals to a state's constitution) to the public. A pretty ingenious idea, yes? And the mechanisms behind this concept, including not only the designing and programming of the machines themselves but also the networking involved to link together these data from the machines to a central tallying location, but while employing good security (currently lacking), are certainly very exciting. Now, what would be even more exciting would be these silly companies opening up their doors (practically transparent anyway) and letting more people who are knowledgeable and care about security to delve into the protocols currently employed and devise more robust solutions to the automation of our democratic process.

fields.title: NCWIT Practices Workshop
fields.post:
I spent the last few days in California at the NCWIT (National Center for Women & Information Technology) Practices workshop. The NCWIT staff, faculty from various colleges and universities across the US, people from the workforce, and social scientists all got together to talk about the practices they have used to try to recruit and retain women in computing. The theme for this workshop was Multiple Pathways to an IT Career, which focused on how to recruit women from all possible pathways, some of which include high school graduates, historically black colleges and universities, tribal colleges, community colleges, and the military and their spouses. I had previously only thought about recruiting young middle or high school age girls, so I found the workshop to be extremely mind opening.

It was very cool to meet people from various areas that were all working towards the same goal. I met a representative from the Girl Scouts, which I thought was pretty neat as I was a scout for 11 years. She pointed me to the Gender Chip project (http://www.genderchip.org/) which I'll have to check out soon.

NCWIT is also developing several "in-a-box" packages that people can use to quickly and easily implement programs. One of their most recent "in-a-box" packages is Pair Programming In-A-Box, which I thought was pretty amazing as I'm studying distributed pair programming. They are currently developing a Roadshow In-A-Box. I picked up the concept paper for it, so hopefully it will help us as we plan our first high school roadshow next semester.

fields.title: helping a fellow student
fields.post:
I apologize for not keeping up with my blogs, I will be catching up this week.

I enjoy helping people out with whatever they need. This past weekend some of my friends needed help with calculus stuff because they had a test coming up. I did not hesitate and helped them out. Its really cool knowing that whenever I need help I've got people there to help me out as well.

fields.title: Exciting Computer Science
fields.post: This week's topic is What is the most exciting use of Computer Science you have seen? I'm not sure about the most exciting ever, but I do know the most exciting Computer Science research project I've seen was at a Grad Cohort for women in computing last year. There was a Master's Degree student there presenting a poster on her thesis research, which was focused on collaborative online shopping. She had created some sort of a browser plugin that allowed you to shop with someone (either by sharing the same screen or by sending links periodically) and then split the bill if you wanted. She was an HCI student, and I was so impressed that she had a "fun" project that would interest young women. It made me excited about computing! I wish there was a way to gather all of these fun projects that would appeal to young women and share them. Computing is so much more than just boring programming.

fields.title: Week 9: Exciting Uses of Computer Science
fields.post:
Hello again! Its been about an hour since I last posted, but I gotta keep up somehow. Anyway, I will get right into it. Then I have some more news to tell after the post.
The most exciting use of computer science I have seen. Of course I come up with a question I have a hard time with. There are a couple of really neat ones. At the conference, we had the opportunity to listen to a woman who dealt with internet security. She told us about all the things website could do make users more secure. She was especially adament about keeping children safe on the internet and using social networking sites like myspace and facebook. She used computer science to automatically provide fail safe procedures to help prevent people from posting unwanted information unintentionally.
Another one that just seems really intriguing is with security in general. Maybe it is just the mystery behind national security data, but it is just kinda cool.

Well, this weekend, we had our first SPARCS! Woot! That was fun. We had a few more students than we originally thought since a field trip was cancelled and some students from a sister school still showed up. It made for a good sized group that had a lot of fun. It will really be interesting to see how the group bonds and grows as the sessions go on.

In other news, Dave has unfortunately left STARS. Therefore, I have switched mentors to Jen. I'm unsure of what will happen to the wii project since it was really Dave's brain child. I'm turning all my focus to SPARCS now though, so I'm ready to get the ball rolling with the HTML portion that I will help teach in a little over a month.

Thats about it for now. Untill next time, stay safe and stay warm. That cold weather is so bitter. Brrrrrr....

fields.title: Week 8: Helping a fellow student
fields.post:
Well, life has been busy as can be. Why does it always seem that way? Enough excuses. Its about time I got arount to posting my blog. Sorry for being so late on it.
So when did I help a fellow student. Seems like a fairly easy question. It seems like there is something every day, and yet I can't pick out a specific thing looking back. It's not something that I have to make the effort to do. This sort of stuff just seems normal. I guess a real recent thing was helping a friend back up their hard drive. We all have accidents, and hers was something that would involve repairing her laptop. She didnt't have a protable hard drive or anything to back up her files on, so it just seemed natural to help out and let her use mine. It's nothing fancy or hard, but it seemed like the right thing to do, ya know?
Anyway, thats about it for me. I'm going to get to my blog for this week in a few min. More like an hour probably. I have yet another meeting to go to now! Life never stops going at a milion miles an hour.

fields.title: SPARCS MIDDLE SCHOOL OUTREACH
fields.post: Saturday at Centenial Campus Middle School 10/28/08 was the first day of meeting up with young student. Teaching the student about computer programming and things about a computer. And from time to time we will have little breaks let the student play in the gym. Have lunch and a little snack. Overall the young student enjoy the first day of the outreach program.

fields.title: Folding @ Home
fields.post:
Without a doubt, the most exciting use of computer science I have ever seen is the Folding @ Home project. Instead of purchasing a multi-million dollar supercomputer to churn out data, Stanford chose to program a distributed client, which uses the spare CPU cycles of volunteers' computers to solve small work units for scientific research. The best part of this project is the results are relevant to everyone! The project deals with protein folding, an essential mechanism for nearly all life, one that causes many maladies (including Alzheimer's Disease, Huntington's Disease, a large portion of cancers, and many others) when it goes awry. Over 57 research papers have been published from F@H results, building a foundation to a complete understanding of how the human body works.
The F@H project took what seemed to be a Sisyphean task, and came up with an innovative solution that has blossomed to become the largest (virtual) computer, operating at 4 PetaFLOPS. This project has so much potential, and fortunately it has received a large amount of attention, which translates to tangible results.
It is necessary to note this is not the only distributed computing project. There are many different distributed computing projects, but none rival the size and scope of the F@H project
Link:
http://folding.stanford.edu/

fields.title: Helping a fellow student
fields.post: This week, I helped a fellow student (my mentee - Allen) on one of his Java assignments. This Friday, one of the Java class projects was due, so we went to the library to work on it. Unfortunately, none of the computers we could find ran linux, and when Allen tried to open his source file in Windows (notepad, specifically), it opened all his source on one line (Windows represents line breaks with \r\n but with Unix it's \n). Next, we tried to use Putty to open Nedit, but it complained about some X server failure. No problem, Vim to the rescue! So, in addition to helping Allen out with his project, he learned about Vim, and more importantly, whenever you experience a problem with computers, there is always a workaround, it just takes a little perseverance.

fields.title: Looking Forward
fields.post:
Over the course of this month, I have been working towards two goals: polishing up the Video Tagging tool, and start working on Crystal Island directly. Unfortunately, the finalizing of the video tagging tool hasn't progressed as fast as I had hoped, mainly because I personally prefer adding new features, as opposed to stabilizing a codebase. The good news is progress on the Crystal Island front is progressing nicely, and there are an abundance of potential projects for me to work on. Here are a few of them:

-Backback feature
-Rewrite the note-taking feature
-Implement a microscope mini-game
-Create an authoring tool (very vague requirements at this point)

First, I need to practice modding Half-Life 2 (Crystal Island is really a modified HL2), and once I've had some experience with that, I'll move on to CI. The most important tasks are the backback and note-taking features. When playing CI, the user must pick up items and carry them around the map. Unfortunately, the 'action key' used to pick up and drop off items is the same key used to open doors, which means when a user picks up an item indoors, they have to drop the item to open the door, and hope the item doesn't get lost. Many CI users have requested this feature, and from a HCI perspective, it will greatly add to the playability of CI.

fields.title: Week of Oct 27th
fields.post:
Wow, I think Daniel's blog topic suggestion is a fantastic one. Great job, Daniel!

I think Computer Science is an extremely exciting area to be in because it can be applied to SO many areas. However, the area that excites me most is the potential for virtual world and gaming applications to improve people's lives. In the last ten or so years, there has been an explosion of interest in using games for learning, for treating post traumatic stress disorder, for conducting business and academic meetings, for investigating social behaviors, and more. Virtual environments are not just fun; they provide users with safe, accessible, and rich environments where users can express themselves, create content, and do things that are difficult to do in reality. They also provide fantastic test beds for testing out new developments from virtually every applied area of computer science: new networking techniques, AI techniques, software engineering practices, human computer interaction paradigms, etc.

I believe that the research community has now recognized the potential of gaming and virtual world applications and is beginning to build substantive and interesting systems. I think that the logical next step will be to start conducting rigorous empirical studies of these environments to actually determine what works, what doesn't work, and make real tangible progress in the field. Evaluation can be a hard problem with complex, subjective systems like games and virtual worlds, but progress can be made and I'm really excited to see the field advance over the next several years.

fields.title: Week of Oct 20th
fields.post:
This week's project update has both good news and some bittersweet news.

Good news first: Roman and Karl are both making strong progress on their projects, both providing deliverables in our meetings this week. Roman passed along the javascript and html code that he has been working on for Narrative Theater infrastructure. Unfortunately, he also came down with strep throat this week so we didn't get to meet face-to-face to talk about it. I'm going to check out his work soon to offer some feedback, and then we'll get together to chat and determine the future steps next week.

This week Karl demo'ed a 99.9% finished version of the Face Tagging tool. We found one small bug in it that he's going to iron out, and then it should be available for researchers in the IntelliMedia lab to begin using. Former STARS student Joe Grafsgaard will likely have a lot of practical use for it in his dissertation work, so Karl and I are excited about that prospect. Additionally, Karl has now successfully installed all of the tools that he'll need to do Crystal Island development on his personal machine. This coming week he is going to start getting elbow deep in tutorials learning how to build Half Life 2 mods. For the rest of the semester I'll probably be working in Half Life 2 code myself, so it will be good for us both to be in the trenches together.

Now for the bittersweet news. Bitter: unfortunately, my other St. Aug's STARS student, Wayne, has had to end his participation in STARS. It sounds like he just has too much on his plate this semester with tough classes and baseball practice. The sweet part: he now has the time to focus on his classes and baseball, and hopefully that will relieve some stress from his shoulders. I'm sorry that he won't be able to continue with STARS, but I wish him lots of luck with his semester and future endeavors!

fields.title: Exciting Use of Computer Science
fields.post: So, I'd imagine most researchers feel this way, but I think the most exciting use of computer science is the area of research I am in - Artificial Intelligence applications in Education. There is one thing I read about recently that I thought was incredible though. It is a creative narrative technology that allows students to create digital stories using real world objects. Children use a variety of tools to import video and pictures into the digital environment. They can then animate these objects to create stories. This is a really hands on approach to technology that I think will have a very interesting impact. Students will be very actively engaged, using all their senses, but then they still have access to the computational power that technology provides. Overall I think it is an incredible project that I hope to read more about soon. Here is a link to the paper I discovered this weekend if anyone else is interested: http://staff.bath.ac.uk/pssrj/ChildrenNT/JCAL19-2/Fusai.pdf

fields.title: Project Status
fields.post:
So, this past Saturday was the first SPARCS session and I am EXTREMELY thrilled with how it went. The students seemed be engaged and really understood the material. They asked thoughtful questions and really seemed to enjoy themselves. Additionally, the administrative things seemed to go off without a hitch which I think allowed for a really smooth, successful day.

One thing I am worried about going forward is the different skill levels we appear to have among students. We have students ranging from 5th-8th grade and little experience to giving some of the mentors a run for the ir money. I was beyond impressed when one student knew the ELIZA system by name and had intelligent things to say about it. I hope that we will be able to cater to his advanced knowledge and interest without losing some of the younger students.

fields.title: GHC Post Conference Notes
fields.post: THe GHC conference was held at Keystone Resort, CO. It was a beautiful resort! We were some 9,000 plus feet above sea level. I touched base with old friends and colleagues during the conference and made new acquaintances, too. All in all there was much to do by way to attending the talks and workshops, professional networking, and just smoozing with the top female leaders in IT. It was a great conference this year. BUt what made it even better is that this is the first year we (NCSU WICS) was able to sponsor 10 female students to attend GRace Hopper this year!!!!!! Claris Castillo, Suzanne Balik, and I co-wrote a proposal last year requesting funding from Cisco to sponsor 3-4 students to send to GHC this year. The proposal was approved summer 2008 and we obtained some funding! BUt WICS had left over funding from last year and this was pooled with the Cisco funding. This plus, "homework" and "legwork" done by Penny Markijohn, Kate Lemanski, and myself research air fares, hotel room rates, and getting registration paid for allowed us to send 10 female students to the conference. This was a first!!! I am so glad for these 10 students. Hopefully, this will be start of something in the years to come.

fields.title: Ever feel like a Minority?
fields.post:
My answer to the proposed question is a resounding YES!!!

I'm a non-traditional female student in the undergraduate computer science department. So even among my minority group I'm a minority. However, someone has break new ground so it might as well be me.

However, I do at times miss my past life as an English major when I was part of the majority. I realized how much I took that for granted. It is true that you don't get special allowances, but it's very easy to meet and form bonds with your peers. Even when I was out in the working world, I worked in a female dominated setting and made very close friendships.

I'm interning this semester and I am the only female among my coworkers. I think they realized pretty quickly that HOOTERS is out of the question for going out to lunch, but they handled this restriction with style and grace. Not only am I learning how to be a minority, my coworkers are learning how to deal with a more diverse set of coworkers. Maybe next week I'll introduce them to meditation practices and old foreign films. Hey, I can dream.

fields.title: STARS Website Update
fields.post:
So I thought this week I'd give a quick update on how the STARS website is going. We're about to start developing an online application for STARS that we'll be able to use for next spring's recruiting. We are allotted 1 database, which we are already using for the STARS wiki, so we're just going to add a couple of tables to this database. Not ideal, but it should work. Since the pages are already php, I'm thinking we'll probably end up using php to process our forms. I personally am not a big fan of php as it is a very flexible language that makes it very easy to create sloppy code that is hard to follow. I'm also not sure if there is a way to separate the logic from the view, so I think we'll probably end up doing all of the form processing in the web pages themselves. This will probably be a very simple application, so hopefully that won't be a big deal. My other concern is that I don't think it is possible to unit test php code...so we'll have to stick with the more black box approach of HttpUnit. But, it will be a great opportunity for me to brush up on php again.

I guess the first steps we'll be taking are to write out some brief requirements of what we want to achieve. Who exactly will be our users? Do we want to allow for the applications to be viewed online by reviewers along with annotating them? TBD. But I'm very excited about doing some coding!

fields.title: How you have helped a fellow student recently?
fields.post:
As someone who is eternally interested in computers and networking and the like, when someone brings up in conversation, in that mournfully discouraged tone of voice, that their computer/printer/router/internet is broken (my favorite being the last one), I generally jump in with my opinion of or solution to their problem, and maybe even offer to come take a look at it and see what I can do.
Such an event occurred not once, but twice this past week. One my classmates' printer is a wireless printer without any sort of means for her to hook it up manually, and her roommate had just reinstalled (reconfigured?) their router, so now she couldn't print anything. Now, I could just give her 6 cents and tell her to use the library, but because problems intrigue me I went ahead and went up to her room to fiddle with it. Managed to re-adjust the permissions on the router configuration, and then got her laptop setup to talk politely with said printer, and everything was good! Things like that always make me happy, even if they do cause me to be terribly frustrated first.
The second 'incident' happened with some software issues (Microsoft--big surprise). Apparently the latest version of Excel-whatnot hates files saved using the older version of Excel-whatnot, plus the learning curve to graph a simple scatter-plot is now suddenly huge. And the help files? Completely unhelpful. They seem to contain as much information as needed to tantalize you with the hint of answer, but not enough to actually clue you in on how to do something. Anyway, we managed to figure it out (two heads are better than one), and rescue her old files from nonexistence. But the experience was good fun as always.

fields.title: Helping Someone
fields.post: As far as the last few weeks, I've been in constant contact with my mentees, who are either from the STARS project or the NCSU College of Engineering's START Program. Most mentees have questions regarding things they would like to pursue after freshman year (ie., internships, coops, etc.). I've provided them with ifnormation on how they can go about pursuing them.

fields.title: Project status
fields.post:
OK, so there's been a change of plan with my project. I admit it, I couldn't figure out a way to make windows desktop support exciting. Practical, yes, exciting, no. So, seeing the point is to inspire underrepresented groups and make them dream in ways that Dr. Watson cannot, I decided to switch things up a little:

> I'm really excited about the idea of using facebook apps to get students
> who would not be interested in pursuing comp sci interested in pursuing
> the subject. I frequently run into females who took AP computer science
> in high school but decided not to major (or even minor) in computer
> science in favor of other majors in college. Many times, they seemed
> stunned that computer science can cross over into other subjects like
> English, Education and Psychology. I see facebook apps as a really good
> way to introduce the idea of social computing to the inner geeks hiding in
> an extrovert suit.
>
