> So I've been slaving away trying to figure out the world of facebook apps.
> I'm still green when it comes to tech although I'm figuring this out
> (slowly but surely). I would love to devote my time this semester towards
> creating a stable lesson plan to teach introductory facebook applications
> for students in an AP Java class, but I doubt I'll get it together enough
> to actually try out my faboo lesson plan on students this semester.

Wish me luck!

fields.title: felt like a minority?
fields.post:
I felt like a minority when I moved to Weddington, NC my sophomore year in high school. Before I moved down I was up in Maryland where my high school consisted of about 30-35% Asian. I just never felt like a minority because there was such a large Asian population. I usually hung out with the same people growing up, all of them being Asian.

In my high school down in Weddington, I was the only Asian in my graduating class. It felt awkward being the only Asian in all my classes, after being used to having 6-7 Asians per class back in Maryland. It was difficult at first, but I got used to it. I learned that you can't just stay within your little clique for the rest of your life. I had a tough time meeting new people back in Maryland, but it definitely got easier moving down to NC, because its pretty much what I had to do since I didn't know anybody.

fields.title: Feeling like a Minority
fields.post: It was in high school when I truly began feeling like a minority. I was enrolled in mostly AP or Honors courses and was almost always the only Black student in those classes. It was nothing uncommon to me since things were that way throughout most of my life. After completing high school and now coming into college, the situation is still the same. I am already used to it but I see other Black students having trouble adjusting, and as a result, are unwelcoming of those different than them.

fields.title: Reaching for the STARS Weekend
fields.post: I had business at home so I did not attend.

fields.title: Feeling Like a Minority
fields.post: As a white male, I have almost never felt like a minority. However, as a Computer Science student, I often feel in the minority. Very few of my friends and colleagues are studying for a degree in engineering, let alone Comp Sci. But other than that, I rarely feel in the minority. Being in the majority, I do recognize the need to be inclusive of everyone, because a community with open communication between everyone is the ultimate form of collaboration, and the best possible work environment. Computer Science is amazing, because the computer doesn't care what race or gender you are.

fields.title: Week of Oct 13th
fields.post:
Although it was kind of painful, we successfull submitted our Narrative Symposium paper on Friday night (early Saturday morning). It came together pretty well, in my opinion. The title ended up being "StoryEval: An Empirical Evaluation Framework for Narrative Generation". We should receive reviews back in about a month.

This week we begin preparations for the next, intelligent version of Crystal Island for a study at the end of the semester with the CCMS eighth grade. Also, I need to do some processing of the trace data from the Onslow County CI study that we did 2 Fridays ago.

This week I hope to be getting the final version of the Face Tagger from Karl with various usability issues resolved. Former STARS member and IntelliMedian Joe Grafsgaard is going to be using the tool this semester for work on his Written Preliminary Exam, so it'll be nice to have it finished, polished, and ready for prime time.

I've thought of another nice project that Karl could work on in Crystal Island - streamlining our note taking functionality.

This week I'll be catching up with Roman and Wayne to see how they are progressing with Javascript and creating a web-based story collection tool. To be continued. . .

fields.title: Week of Oct 6th
fields.post:
This week I'm primarily working on a paper to submit to the AAAI 2009 Spring Symposium on Intelligent Narrative Technologies. The topic is more or less 'an evaluation methodology for intelligent narrative generation'. It's a thought piece / synthesis paper, but hopefully it's interesting to the community and leads to some thoughtful discussion.

Karl gave our lab version 0.5 of the Face Tagging tool, and will be spending the next week fixing up some final minor usability issues with it. He has started trying to get Half Life 2 modding going, but it looks like he's going to have to pick up his own copy of Half Life 2. It's a drag, but a reality of developing with the environment. As soon as he gets it, he should be jumping right into some of the modding tutorials to get his feet wet.

This is an off-week for meeting w/ Roman and Wayne. Hopefully they are still making progress on Javascript stuff. I'll be meeting with them to get an update next week.

fields.title: Have you ever felt like a minority?
fields.post:
Short answer: yes.
Long answer: Yes, by being the single or one of the few females in a class.
Longer answer:
Last year in physics (PY208) I was one of two females in the class, and in math (MA242, MA305) I was the solitary female present. This year, I have the pleasure of being one of 5 women in a lecture hall of over 100 students in my discrete math class (CSC226).
Now, I am to the point of being sort of used to this by now, and as a not-shy and pretty assertive person I'm usually not bothered by it, and am able to initiate conversations with some nearby guys and they'll figure out I'm not actually infected and that we have some common ground (namely, computers). Still, there are many cultural differences even between males and females, and so sometimes I am left feeling awkward or out of place. Despite the jokes about the estrogen levels in the room, it becomes apparent over time that with diverse populations come diverse and innovative ideas, leading to things like my study group with two girls and three guys. A good mix, for such a weighted beginning configuration!

fields.title: Reflection/Looking Forward
fields.post:
I confess to being a bit discouraged as to the 'goal completion' aspect of my project. I am sure I can whip something up in terms of concrete results for a certain aspect of my project, but not that I will able to show results in the main area of my project, namely working on a wireless networking system for Raleigh. I have had encouraging conversations with both people in the workforce and professors here at NC State working on similar areas, and I have certainly expanded my knowledge of technique and current working theories of mesh networking, and for those goals I am content.
Given the time remaining, I may decide to shift my focus in this project to a research or informational angle for this semester, such that I would be fulfilling my community involvement goal as well as my own personal goal of finishing a project for the poster session.
As I mentioned in a previous blog post, I could emulate the idea shown to us during the conference in Alabama this summer by the students from the learning-disabilities school and direct my efforts in an informational way. I could also follow others advice and test some current theories out in a physical network here on campus and investigate the vulnerabilities, and then present these findings. Depending on available resources, I will attempt the latter and fall back on the former if necessary.

fields.title: Week 7: Ever Feel Like a Minority?
fields.post:
Well, despite my best efforts two weeks ago, I still managed to get behind a week. Brilliant... One of these days I will get it right. Untill then, thanks for bearing with me. I have 3 specific things to cover in this blog, so let's get started!

First off: have I ever felt like a minority? This is a touchy subject to be sure. Let me start off with some background. I have lived a good portion of my life overseas, 3 years of which in the Netherlands. While there, I was in a privat school, the British School in the Netherlands. While there, we had people of all nationalities in classes. We had uniforms, so it wasn't like we could prejudice people based on what they wore, or didn't wear. I had friends from as far away as Brasil to the US. It didn't matter if someone had a different color skin or had a funny accent. We were adaptable and thrived on the diversity from that room. That really taught me about the uselessness of judging someone on the color of their skin or their accent. It also taught me that you can spell color as colour. And an eraser is a rubber, but thats another story all together. Anyway, fast forward to high school. I was in all the AP classes with the "smarter" people. To say the least there was a heavy asian population in my school zone. For the typical asian stereo type, and I by no means think this is true of all people, they were all in the AP classes, and they were a riding majority. So in that sense, being white in those classes was a kind of minority. I didn't really realize it though. With my background, I enjoyed having those different perspectives. It also pushed me to work harder since they were being pushed by their parents to succeed. Then I come up here to NCSU. It's weird now. There is a clear higher percentage of caucasians here. I feel like there is so much more being left out. Back to the point though, I have sort of been in a minority, but also have been far from it. I don't know whether that whole story made any sense or was in any way relevant, but I feel like it was good to be said. Now onto the other points.

My projects. As far as SPARCS goes we have our first event Saturday. Should be interesting to say the least. I am curious to see how it goes. As for the Wii, things have been busy so I am still searching for a time to meet with Dave. Fall break made things tough just cause so many people leave.

Final point: I am applying for a CO-OP through Cisco! I'm super psyched about it! It would start in January, so that would become my project and I would present to some group of middle school students. Maybe the ones from SPARCS? That would be cool. Anyway, I thought I would just let everyone know about that. I'm really excited about the possibilities for it.

Thats it for the week, as if thats a small amount :) Possible blog topic: most exciting use of Computer Science you have seen. Its a possibility. Until next time, see ya!

fields.title: Feeling like a minority
fields.post:
I have definitely felt like a minority in my time here at NCSU. As an undergrad, I was one of the few females in my computer science classes. I remember sitting in my 216 class the first day as people slowly trickled into the classroom...one by one the guys came in...and then class started...and I was the only girl. It completely surprised me as I really had no idea that computing was for guys (shocking, I know!). I was so baffled that first day. And then I got used to it and we all started to get to know each other. I definitely stood out in classes, and on more than one occasion, I have introduced myself to a guy in a class only to have him say, "We've had classes together before." It's a little embarrassing, but it really is hard to keep everyone straight when it's a bunch of guys and they can easily pick you out of a crowd. By senior year, I didn't mind being the only girl. I had learned to deal with the guy geek culture and actually enjoyed being able to easily get help when I needed it from the guys in the class.

This summer, I was part of IBM's Extreme Blue program in RTP. Out of the 12 student interns (3 MBAs and 9 technical students), I was the only female. I had several people assume I was the MBA, which was kind of annoying, but I survived. The most challenging part was that, unlike undergrad where I had general education classes which had more girls, I spent all day with these guys. About 90% of the time, they were completely great and understanding...only a few awkward situations...But they never said or even implied that I knew less than them because I was a female, which I found very impressive. The only frustrating part was that I didn't always feel like they could relate to the factors and values I look for when searching out a job.

I'm much more comfortable now being a minority. Do I enjoy it? Not particularly. But I can survive, and lets be honest, sometimes it is more pleasant to work with guys than girls. :)

fields.title: Feeling Like a Minority
fields.post:
I suppose its easy to feel like a minority when you actually are one. As a female in Computer Science, we are pretty heavily outnumbered. It can be kind of frustrating sometimes to know that you always stand out. It can be nerve wracking to feel that extra attention and pressure. Also sometimes I feel like I'm representing my entire gender and trying to dispell any myths that women are less good at math, science and engineering. I'm probably putting too much pressure on myself, but I think its a common feeling. Relevant comic

But there are definitely advantages to standing out. People are more likely to remember you which makes networking easier. There are also a lot of great opportunities that come around from being a minority. For example, I just got back from the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computer Science. Its an excellent conference which provides an opportunity for networking, career searching and learning that really only exists because we are a minority.

fields.title: September Reflection
fields.post:
Whew...September was a busy month. I think we made good progress with the SPARCS outreach project though. Unfortunately due to conflicts with the schedules of 3 schools we weren't able to have our first session in September, but it is planned for Oct 25. We have an entire schedule laid out and a paradigm for creating schedules and topics for individual sessions that I think will work out really well. I'm still hoping we can get more female and minority students interested in the program, but unfortunately it hasn't happened yet.

This month I look forward to getting SPARCS started in full swing. I don't have any really specific goals other than ensuring that the sessions go off without a hitch and we have a diverse group of students as mentioned before.

fields.title: Goals
fields.post:
Submit Combinatorial Testing Paper to Tapia 2009 Conference (completed)
Check out iTutor project (completed)
Extend the ASMProxy to generate a compilable test driver (in Progress)
Consult with Justin on the project interface

fields.title: Week of Sept 29th
fields.post:
This week I was able to have meetings with Roman and Karl, which were both productive. Karl gave me an update on the Face Tagging Tool, which he is still finishing up. He ran into some small requirements-related issues that we clarified with regard to how to save log files to the machine. My hope is to have the tool for use in our lab sometime this week. Karl and I then discussed his coming projects, including an implementation of a knap sack feature in Crystal Island, as well as developing an IntelliMedia-internal tool sometime next semester. Details on the tool are still sketchy, but the idea is that he would help us construct an authoring tool that would be used in conjunction with the character dialogue generation system that we're developing for Crystal Island. It may be some time before we know more detail, but there is no shortage of things for him to work on in Crystal Island in the meantime.

I was able to give Roman a tour of the department and our lab, as well as a demo of Crystal Island. We then discussed grad school, classes, and his progress with Javascript. We agreed upon a milestone date for his first deliverable: he hopes to give me a Javascript implementation of the story collection tool in about three weeks. We also reviewed the Google Sites wiki that I assembled for the project, so hopefully he'll be able to take advantage of that soon as well.

This week was largely spent in preparation for a coming paper submission (AAAI Spring Symposium on Intelligent Narrative Technologies II) and a major Crystal Island study on Friday. We're busing in 60 eighth-graders from Onslow County to come play Crystal Island, so getting everything prepared is taking a lot of my attention.

fields.title: September Reflection
fields.post:
I think I'll start out my September reflection by examining my goals...Completed/in progress goals are bolded.

Level 1 Goals

  • Update members page on the website with new members (completed)
  • Update projects page on the website with new 2008 projects (in progress)
  • Create an archive page for previous years' projects (in progress)
  • Create a clear description of what STARS is and what STARS students do.
  • Check on current sponsorship with Ken Tate and Kristy and update website to reflect this (completed)
  • Plan and execute the end-of-semester poster session

Level 2 Goals

  • Get the STARS website posted on the CSC website (completed)
  • Create a page for Alumni STARS members to detail life after graduating
  • Make the STARS application an online application
  • Create links to other Raleigh STARS groups
  • Include a Google Calender to the Events page (completed)
  • Plan an event with the other Raleigh STARS groups (completed)

Level 3 Goals

  • Verify that the entire website is 508 compliant
  • Develop a log in process for Alumni to enter their information
  • Plan a "fun" STARS outing
  • Plan a STARS road-show for local high-schools
  • Expand and customize the Drupal site to better fit our needs. For example, get the feed aggregator working correctly, customize the template to better match the STARS website, and create some sort of auto-backup system.
  • Partner with other CSC student organizations to plan a training workshop for high school Computer Science teachers.

I didn't complete a level of goals, and I didn't complete all of the goals I intended to for September. However, I did achieve some of the goals I didn't set out to. Working with Rob has been great! Every week we create a task list for each of us, which we do our best to complete. I think creating the task list has been extremely beneficial. In order to improve our goal reaching, we should probably read over our goals at our meetings when building the task list.

The goals I would like to complete during October:

  • Update projects page on the website with new 2008 projects
  • Create an archive page for previous years' projects
  • Create a clear description of what STARS is and what STARS students do.
  • Plan the end-of-semester poster session (begin)
  • Make the STARS application an online application (begin)

fields.title: nursing home project (september)
fields.post:
The nursing home service project is going great so far. Our group completed some of the goals listed under my first blog entry. We made another visit a few days ago and started working with some of the residents. We made e-mail addresses for 4 residents and taught them the basics of how to access and use their e-mail. It was a lot of information for them, so we decided to type up instructions for them to refer to.

We are still trying to work something out with setting up a wireless network so we can bring laptops and work with more people at a time.

fields.title: CSC 116 Mentoring First Couple of Weeks
fields.post: So after dividing up the mentees Bellanov, Karl, and I got to work on setting up initial meetings, assuming that if they filled out the application they were pretty much a lock to be in the program. Well that assumption turned out to be wrong. We each only received a couple of responses back and we also ran into another problem, the people we were hearing back from weren't freshmen and some weren't CSC majors. This was an unforeseen obstacle but in retrospect I should've seen this coming. The curricula for CSC majors says that for freshmen in the fall they will take E115 and then in the spring they will take CSC116. The only way a pure freshmen would be enrolled in CSC 116 in the fall is if they take and pass the E115 place-out exam which most freshmen aren't even aware there is a place out exam much less have the time to prepare for taking it. I think that this program will be much more effective in the spring when the classes will be predominantly freshmen. That is not to say we are going to give up this semester though. All of the CSC 116 classes just took their 1st test this week. They also have completed 2 programs thus far. So I think now they have a very good idea on whether or not they have a firm grasp on the material or if they need some help. My plan is to e-mail the professors again and to ask that when they go over the test in their classes that they could give my program a little plug in and let them know we're still available all the way up until October 18th (the day after the drop date). Hopefully we will be able to get some more people at that time. Also I will be creating a group on Facebook for the mentees and communicating with them that way. This is because people are much less likely to ignore facebook communication than an e-mail to their unity account. So for the next couple of weeks we'll try to get in contact with the people that have signed up and then hopefully around the drop date we'll have a flood of more applicants. My fingers are crossed.

fields.title: Wifi project -- NC State info
fields.post:
This past Tuesday I took the opportunity to meet with Professor Peng Ning, who is involved with networks and security. I spoke with him and asked for some guidance in the research arena for the newest initiatives in wireless networking, and the security aspects thereof (as I myself have personal interests leaning that way). He was able to point me more toward the "mesh networking" aspect, something I believe I may have mentioned in a previous blog post. One of his students had recently written a paper detailing problems with scheduling fairness in wireless backhaul mesh networks, and I am using this as a jump-off point to further investigate the vulnerability/efficiency of such a network for implementation on a city-wide scale (think, City of Raleigh).
On that front, nothing new to report. I am waiting to hear back, but if nothing occurs by the end of this week, I shall force the issue early next week.

fields.title: CSC 116 Mentoring Set-up
fields.post: I initially e-mailed all 4 CSC 116 professors to set up days that I could come into the classroom and give my presentation. Except for one, every professor was very excited to hear about the program and was very accomadating. I set up the application online using SurveyMonkey and made it accesible through a freewebs website. The first class I went into I wrote the site on the board and some information about the program and just talked to the class about the program, its benefits, and why they should join. Being that it was a morning class people straggled in late, were rubbing sleep out of their eyes, and finding it difficult to pay attention to basically a lecture. So after only receiving a few responses from that class I decided to switch my approach and put together a powerpoint and adjust my presentation so that it focused more on benefits and the students had the application in front of them while I was presenting and they could sign up while I was talking. That approach I felt was more effective even though the responses didn't "pour in". After going to all of the classes we had a total of 14 responses. Bellanov, Karl, and I went and sorted through the responses and assigned each mentee a mentor and said that over the next couple of weeks we would start setting up initial meetings with our mentees and meet and see how everything was going.

fields.title: GHC Conference
fields.post: Hello! I am here in Keystone, CO and the GHC conference is tomorrow. I am very much looking forward to this conference. Last year I attended Grace Hopper and it was great!!!!!! This year, I am back. I hope to touch base with old colleagues and make new ones. I am also presenting research. I have two posters to present. One of my posters was entered into the ACM SRC competition. I have to attend an additional presentation as a result. Grace Hopper is a great conference in that it is a great gathering of women in computing and engineering who share experiences and supportive interactions. I can't wait to see my friends!

fields.title: Mentor meeting with Kate McCarthy
fields.post:
Kate and I had a mentor-mentee meeting over dinner at Dalat. It was a great meeting!! We discussed a lot of things from research to courses to internships, everything a student in computer science is curious about. I must say we were able to share experiences and notes... Kate is great in that she is open to a lot of things. I hope I had conveyed a lot for her to gain pointers. On the other hand, I enjoyed hearing feedback from her and her notes and experiences. We are both profitting from this relationship. Take care all!

Marivic

fields.title: Summary of Summer ang Beginning of semester
fields.post:
Hello! I am so happy to have joined STARS. I truly enjoyed the STARS conference last August and came out of it inspired!!!

The following were my activities this past summer:

June-August -- graduate internship at Oak Ridge National Labs
July -- proposed my dissertation research
July -- attended CRA-W Summer School on Logic Programming
August - attended the STARS conference in Auburn, AL
September - December -- Qualcomm internship
Fall semester -- enrolled in dissertation research and doing my research
October -- presented at Grace Hopper Conference

I will keep STARS updated on my activities.

Thanks a lot! Marivic

fields.title: Week 6: Looking Back... Looking Forward...
fields.post:
Well, I'm back again! Ya, you just got done listening to me ramble on about other stuff, so you get to do it all over again! Woo! Hopefully they aren't that boring. I like to think that it is rather amusing to read some of these. Anyway, let's get to it!

Well, as far as goals for the month and so, the SPARCS program is going along swimmingly! Unfortunately I was unable to attend the meeting today due to a conflict. However, I will be working with Chris from St. Aug on the Web Page part of SPARCS. This means a lot to me personally because it is how I originally got into Computer Science. I know it is simplistic, but I really do enjoy it. It's easy and kind of mindless. You can do things and get to see them instantly. I really hope to be able to instill some of that passion into a few of the students we will be working with. My goal is to get in touch with Chris by the end of this week and see how he wants to handle things. He was a part of SPARCS last year so he knows a bit about how to schedule a day and such.

As far as the Wii-mote goes, things are kind fo hit or miss. Dave and I have a lot going on, so we meet when we can though it is not often. Things are moving along though, so we shall see how it all turns out.

So, overall, things are moving along. Wow, how weird, 12 weeks till the day before my last exam. My, how time flies. I suppose I will talk to everyone Thursday! Looking forward to the meeting. Curious as to what will go on. I'm finally caught up on Blogs! Celebrate!

fields.title: Week 5: Reaching for the STARS Weekend
fields.post:
Wow. This is not great at all. I get later and later. I will be posting two tonight. Gotta get caught up again. Enough preface, lets get to the meat of stuff!

Wow, its already been a week since the Reaching for the STARS weekend! Definately a lot to look at and learn from. It was really neat to meet some professionals from IBM and hear about the company overall, opportunities, and just general tips and tricks. A big shout out and thank you to Mr. Donald McCoy and Mr. Grady (I appologize, but I completely forgot your first name and can't seem to find it) for coming and speaking with us. It was a thrill to meet you and learn about the company and the many opportunities that it presents. Extreme blue seems like a really neat program.

As for the football party the next day (Saturday), I really hope people enjoyed it. It was cool to sit down with people and enjoy the game. If I had any suggestions for next year, should we get to do it again, I would BEG you to put it on a weekend we didnt have a home football game. I know it probably wasn't something that was taken into consideration, but I for one love going to the games. It was a shame we couldn't go to it in person. Oh well. Enough dwelling. It was fun, and the pizza was great Lauren!

So, overall, the event was awesome! It was eye opening and beneficial to meet professionals and to talk about what the possibilities are. Definately something we should continue in the future! And, next time, please come to it people! You really missed out on a lot of opportunities. I know it sounds cliche, but its true. Ok, enough on this topic! Time to move on to the next week!

fields.title: Project Updates
fields.post:
Since I was unable to attend the Reaching for the STARS weekend events, I will use this entry to give an update on the SPARCS project.

Since last time, we have solidified a set of dates for the SPARCS session. Our first session will be Oct 25th and we will hold eight sessions throughout the academic year. It is amazing how difficult it can be to coordinate the schedules of three different schools.

This Monday, we will be meeting to assign roles within the SPARCS mentors group. I hope to give small groups of students responsibility for teaching a particular topic. They will be responsible for preparing the teaching materials for the students, surveys on the effectiveness of them and writing up results on these aspects to present at future STARS workshops/poster sessions.

fields.title: STARS Week 9/19-9/25/2008
fields.post: I have not been able to meet with my Grad Student from NCState, due to scheduling conflicts. But in this event it has not stopped me from continuing on with learning Java Script. In my String Processiong Language Class we have worked on adding Media Files to web pages, CSS Textile file, etc. I have also learned that writting in Java Script Language it is similar to writing codes in C, C++, and Java. Being that all of them are case sensative. The only difference That I have come to find thus far is that Java Script is used in the web browser. I have continued to Study Java Script and I am ready to get into the lab this week for hands on action.

fields.title: Week of 9/21
fields.post:
Unfortunately, I was unable to participate in the reaching for the STARS weekend. Friday schedule overlapped with my classes and band rehearsal. As for Saturday, I am in the marching band and was required to attend the game (in fact, our day began at 6 am because it was a 12pm kickoff).

But I should hope that the game proved lively conversation at least for the Saturday portion of the schedule. Go pack!

fields.title: Week of 9/14
fields.post:
When I first entered school, my dream job had a really generic description : to work in industry. Since then, I have had the opportunity to experience working in the software development industry and have been able to further clarify what my dream job is.

This summer I held an internship at the NFL in the information technology department. The buisness application I worked on will help coaches and staff analyze football statistics much more in depth and much faster than ever before. I would love to return to the NFL Information Technology department for research and development in furthering the sport of football. Or perhaps working for a single club such as the Carolina Panthers in the information technology department.

fields.title: Week of 9/7
fields.post:
Honestly, I had not even heard of STARS before one of my friends approached me and suggested to apply for it. What appealed to me most was the opportunity to do some research. In the midst of prepping for interviews, research was the one major category that was missing from my resume.

The process of application seemed fairly simple to me. Write up your application and essay, and submit. If I remember correctly the whole process was automated and therefore easy to complete at one's leisure.

fields.title: Reaching for the STARS Weekend
fields.post:
The Reaching for the STARS Weekend consisted of several sessions where STARS members from different schools were able to get together in a smaller group than the STARS celebration. We wanted students to be able to get together, talk about their projects, and participate in professional development. Students from Georgia Southern University drove up to NCSU and spent the weekend with us. On Friday morning, they took tours of the campus and talked with some of the groups like WICS. In the afternoon, students from NCSU and Georgia Southern got together with some representatives from IBM for professional development. On Saturday, students from both schools watched the NCSU vs ECU football game and enjoyed pizza. (It was a fabulous game...it went into overtime for a big NCSU win!)

I think there are a few ways we could improve if we were to do this event again. We had rather small participation, and I would have liked to see more students attend. While the small group created a setting where everyone was comfortable talking, more students could have benefited from the event. There are a couple ways we could achieve this. First, contacting more schools in the local area would help. Sending the schools full details several weeks in advance would probably help. Additionally, liaisons for the schools should really hype up the event to their students and encourage them to attend. The afternoon schedule probably would have benefited from short 10 minute breaks between sessions, along with drinks and cookies about halfway through. Also, several NCSU students had class on Friday afternoon, and those who didn't have class probably didn't want to come back to campus. I'm not sure what day of the week would be best, but Friday afternoon naps are awfully nice. :)

The students who did attend gave very positive feedback. They enjoyed the intimate setting of the group, and really enjoyed the speakers. Students liked the mock interviews and had fun playing with the robots.

fields.title: Week of Sept 22nd
fields.post:
This week (on Sept 23rd) I am traveling to the Institute for Creative Technologies in Los Angeles, CA. They are hosting a Virtual Human Workshop, which I have been invited to. It should be a great opportunity to learn quite a bit about the different tools they are using at ICT and meet with other grad students from across the country. I haven't been out to LA since I interned at ICT in Summer 2007, so it will be fun to be back for a few days.

Today we had our first meeting with teachers for The Narrative Theater project. The teachers seemed very enthusiastic about the project and are already giving us loads of useful feedback and resources. This semester, Wayne and Roman's STARS projects involve building some of the basic infrastructure for the Narrative Theater. Both have gotten started on learning Javascript and are working on building an interface for us to collect stories and store them locally, or on a remote server. Unfortunately, due to scheduling conflicts and my travel schedule it has been tough for all of us to get together and meet all at once. This week will be no different, because of my trip to California. Hopefully next week we'll be able to get back into "normal" mode and fall into a rhythm of meeting regularly.

Next week will prove a bit chaotic. There's a paper deadline on Friday (AAAI Intelligent Narrative Technologies Symposium), which is the same day as our Crystal Island study. Further, I have two class presentations during the week, one on ICT's Virtual Human's work, and another on Facade. It'll be busy, but everything is fun stuff, fortunately.

For those not familiar with Facade, go download it and play it: http://www.interactivestory.net/

fields.title: Week of Sept 15th
fields.post:
I have spent the last several weeks getting the newest version of Crystal Island set up for a coming study we're conducting with 60 8th grade students from rural North Carolina. Tightening the world, story, dialogue, and everything else has been surprisingly time consuming, but I've made a lot of progress and hope that the newest version of Crystal Island is substantially stronger than prior versions. I'm looking forward to heading up the study next week.

My ideal job would be an some interdisciplinary faculty position at a joint research-teaching college someplace. I enjoy teaching a lot, particularly with smaller classes, and would enjoy teaching at a place like my undergrad (Lafayette College). Of course, I'd also like the opportunity to continue working on educational games, AI, and even start dabbling in computational art. I think games can be an incredibly effective learning and creativity platform, and I'd love to work with groups of students to see what sorts of cool things they can come up with.

So a forward-thinking liberal arts school with a strong science or engineering program sounds ideal. Now I just need to get a PhD so that I can be qualified to go do that. . .

fields.title: Week 4: The Dream Job
fields.post:
Well, yet again, another default. Oh well. Enough with promises. Things will get done when they get done. Reaching for the Stars weekend was really fun the last two days, but you will have to wait till my next blog for that :) Don't you just love the anticipation? Down to the topic at hand!

The dream job. Isn't this supposed to be an easy question? Shouldn't we all have a plan for what we want to do with the rest of our lives? Well, guess what? I really don't know! Yep, thats right, I don't know. But hey, thats what I'm in school for! There is just so much out there that I cant even comprehend. Opportunities in this field especially are limitless. Thats why it is always exciting to go to career fairs, like the one coming up next week, and other such events. Through them, I can learn what I can do. I'm also really excited about what the possibilities are for internships this summer. Getting the opportunity to learn about specific things in the actual career field is priceless!

Well, I am about out of ideas for this week. If I had any more specific idea as to what I wanted in a job, this would be easier. But I don't, so this will have to do. I will write again soon! If nothing else, you can count on it for next Sunday :)

fields.title: first visit to nursing home!
fields.post:
Our nursing home team all gathered up and made a visit to the Raleigh Rehabilitation and Healthcare Center close to campus this past Wednesday. This location is in the middle of all the schools involved, so that's a plus. We met with Tangela Herring (Activities Director) and discussed the fundamentals of the service project. Tangela already has a list of residents interested and will contact their families to collect e-mail addresses. The activities room already has a computer connected to the internet, which is another plus. We are planning on setting up a wireless network so we can work with more than one resident at a time. Each student in the team will type up a certain set of instructions so the residents can refer to them if they forget something.

On a side note...the people are really nice there and the facilities look great!

Our next visit will be on Wednesday, October 1st at 3:30pm.

fields.title: My Dream Job
fields.post:
When I came into Computer Science freshman year, I really had no idea what to expect...in fact, I didn't even really know what it meant to program. So I don't really remember what my dream job was at that time.

My dream job for immediately after school has several characteristics:

  • Challenging development position
  • Software company (I don't want to be part of the IT Department of a company in a different industry)
  • A product I care about that interests me--ideally, a collaborative software tool like Team Concert
  • Room to grow, learn, and advance my career
  • An agile, collaborative team
  • Located near a job my fiance gets
  • And of course, it pays well!

While the above characteristics describe my ideal job for the next few years, my ideal job for later in life is a lot different. Once I've learned a lot about the software business and have refined my programming skills, I think it would be really fun to have a bridal website business. In order to do this, I would have to take some classes and get better at graphic design, but it would be so fun! I would work with local Bridal Consultants to help create personalized websites for brides. I think it would be fun to be part of this exciting time in people's lives!

fields.title: My Dream Job
fields.post:
My dream job is to be a computer science professor (ideally at NCSU) and work on research in the area of intelligent tutoring systems. I'm not sure I would really consider this a change thats happened while being in school, but I would count it as a solidification. Most of the components of this line of work have always been of interest to me and I spent a long time looking for a good way to integrate them. It just so happened that in the past year, I learned exactly how.

My primary interests are computer science, teaching, psychology and cognition. These combine in a lot of interesting ways. Cognition and computer science lead to AI. Psychology and teaching combine into educational psychology. AI and ed psych are the main compenents of Intelligent Tutoring Systems research. Also, I can combine teaching and CS interests by, well, teaching computer science. And I can teach and do research as a professor. It amazes me sometimes how well it works out. I just hope that it does :)

fields.title: Dream Job
fields.post: My dream job consists of my owning my own business. The business may be something along the lines of a software company. After getting into research recently, I realized getting a PHD may be the best move for me. I hope to continue research under professors until I gain their thinking ability. I hope to turn one of my own research ideas into a business venture, which is common amongst the research community these days.

fields.title: WCPSS registration
fields.post: We have taken care of the WCPSS registration last week 9-11-08 at CCMS around 11:00 until 11:45.

fields.title: Dream Job
fields.post:
Five years ago, if someone asked me what I would be doing in five years, I would have given a completely different answer than what I am doing now. There was NO WAY that I would've been back in school working on a second degree. Due to this, it's a personal philosophy of mine not to have too detailed of a five year game plan because it's probably just a huge waste of precious mental effort. However, I can with confidence say what I will NOT be doing in five years. By process of elimination then, my path will be more clear to me.
1) I will not be doing a job that is not fulfilling to me
2) I will not be working a third shift
3) I will be mentally challenged by my job
4) I will make enough money to support a predominantly sushi dinner diet.

Of course, I would love to invent the next Facebook or Flickr and not have to work for the man, but I would settle for moderately successful blog that pays the mortgage.

fields.title: Dream Job
fields.post:
My dream job is a complicated matter, probably because of my ambiguous definition. My dream job is anything I'm paid to do, that I am happy to do for the rest of my life (i.e. never retire). One of my teachers once told me, "Salary can only decrease your dissatisfaction with your job," so there is no requirement for my job to make me wealthy, as long as money isn't a concern. A few other aspects of my dream job are as follows:
-Help people
-Create a lasting product, or entity
-Meet new people
-Travel (worldwide)

All of these can be easily satisfied in a job in the computing/IT field. Ideally, my dream job will involve contributing on an open source project, such as KDE or FreeBSD, but those are pipe dreams right now.
Unfortunately, my Air Force career will not satisfy all these requirements, because there is a mandatory retirement date set for every member of the Armed Forces (30 years, if I remember correctly), so I will not be able to keep that job indefinitely. Additionally, the higher-up ranks are more concerned on organizational and vision matters than individual tasks. I seriously doubt anyone Colonel or higher does any coding for their job.

fields.title: Why I joined STARS
fields.post:
I had never heard of STARS before my CSC216 teacher (Mrs. Miller) recommended me for it. After that, I spent a lot of time weighing the time commitment against the opportunity to network with professionals and faculty alike, and in the end, the opportunities won out. Already, I've learned far more through STARS than I would have, had I not joined, and that in itself is a good enough reason to join. The stipend, as well as the Summer Celebration are great incentives that make people seriously consider STARS as an extra-curricular activity. Simply put, the opportunity to help others, while benefiting myself, was something I couldn't pass up.
The recruitment process could be improved by simply advertising more. Progress has been made last year, specifically with the website, but I still doubt many students have heard about it. Part of the problem is some students aren't looking for these opportunities, which makes it harder to attract their attention. Another downside is the multiple lengthy surveys, which are a necessary evil. Overall, the recruitment process is improving, and is headed in the right direction.

fields.title: Wifi project -- Raleigh IT contact
fields.post:
So I managed to establish contact with some people over in the Raleigh IT Department. I spoke with a Jack Morne in the Customer Service and Support section, who informed me that Raleigh's government had two current separate initiatives. The first was a contract out to a company called Airband (www.airband.com) for WiMax (slightly different from WiFi) access on Fayetteville Street. The second is down at the Convention Center, which is directly administrated by the IT dept of Raleigh, and not the Airband company.
I also spoke with Chris, a student here at NC State currently working for the city of Raleigh in its IT dept, and he is working on looking at where STARS could possibly integrate itself (through me) into such a free wireless project for the city of Raleigh.

fields.title: Stars Celebration 2008
fields.post:
I was personally highly anticipating the STARS celebration being that my summer was not as enjoyable as I would've liked. It definitely was a completely different experience than I was anticipating. Although much of it was very enjoyable I felt this years conference was definitely lacking in some areas.
My favorite part of the celebration was definitely the mentoring training because that's what I wanted to get involved in. Helping people in a mostly one on a one basis and making sure they don't make the same mistakes that I have made or I have seen other people close to me make that made school/life unneccesarily difficult/complicated. I think that mentor training will be very beneficial to me effectively running the CSC 116 Mentoring program this year.
My least favorite part was the lack of night activities after dinner. You have a large group of college students mostly between the ages of 19-25 coming from all over the southeast. I think interaction between the colleges should be highly promoted. I know they keep us busy all day but none of us are just going to go up into our room and go to bed at 9:30. I heard rumors of a movie night and then a pool party but nothing actually formulated. Whether its something as simple as that or maybe a mixer where they clear out a room, play music, and just let everybody have a good time. I know its a conference but it is also suppose to be a celebration and I just didn't see much of the celebration side.

fields.title: Summer Activity
fields.post:
My Summer can be summed up into two words: Field Training. As part of my Air Force ROTC obligation, I was required to go to Maxwell Air Force Base, Alabama, for 27 days (late June to late July). This was the culmination of my past two years of AFROTC training, designed to test my nerves and leadership skills while under pressure, and believe me, there was plenty of pressure and stress. Obviously, it was nothing like the Full Metal Jacket style of training, but I was still pushed to the limits of my physical and mental endurance. Once I completed Field Training, I spent the rest of my time catching up with friends, and of course, attending the annual STARS celebration.
This year's STARS celebration was a big improvement on last year's (in Charlotte), and that's saying a lot. Our hotel was amazing, the town of Auburn was great, and the food was outstanding. The only downside had to do with the schedule. This year, it seemed the "work hours" were extremely long, 10-7 if I remember correctly. Last year seemed to be much shorter.
Overall, this Summer was great. I learned a lot, met many new people, and had fun at the same time. Now bring on the school year.

fields.title: Blog 3: Joining STARS, the start of a journey
fields.post:
Well, I guess I kinda faulted on my goal of getting back earlier this week. SORRY :( Life is crazy. Plus, I went to the NC State, Clemson football game. Needless to say I am sunburnt. OUCH. Anyway, enough of my life. Noone really wants to hear about that. Its boring. We care about what I am doing for STARS, right? Here we go...

So this week we could write about how we heard about STARS and stuff like that. Honestly, the first time I heard about STARS, I completely dismissed it. I got an email from Dr. Adams (thank you so much!!!) saying that there was this program, STARS, and it was a really good opportunity. Kinda read through stuff, and was like, meh, thats a lot of work. So, I put it off. About a month or so later (I dont remember exactly how long) I got another email from Dr. Adams really encouraging me to look into it. Since she had taken the time to send me a second email, I read through the information a second time, except a lot closer. Wow. What had I almost missed! What I had initially blown off as a lot of work (which it still is :) ) was actually a whole lot of fun too! The rewards were much greater than the $500 a semester stipend (which definately helps). Being able to reach out and shape the minds of middle school students to accept and consider computer science is one of the most amazing things ever! I personally got interested in computer science around that age when I took a webmastering summer course. I immediately filled the application out and sent it back. Days later I got my acceptance into this organization. Now look at what I get to do! So amazing. I would have completely missed this opportunity had Dr. Adams not sent a second suggestion to me.

As for how to improve the process... that is a little tougher. I feel like the best way to recruit people is to actually talk to people. Only through voice can you truly convey the true possibilities of a project. Ya, sure, an email is much easier, but it is so easy to just blow by it. I mean, there is a very good possibility that I will miss something this year cause of the large quantity of emails I recieve on a daily basis. It is so impersonal. I feel like if we could go and talk to csc groups around campus, we could really bring in more people. Specifically, I think we could talk to ACM and WICS. I am sure there are others, but those would be great places to start. WICS, especially would be a great place. It is exactly what we are promoting through STARS. If need be, I will gladly go to some of the meetings and talk to them, spreading what we do. There is so much untapped potential. Oh, another thing we could do. We have the outreach to 116 students this semester with tutoring and help on projects. Why not be able to get someone in each class towards the end of the year to talk about what we do, and they will know exactly who we are, cause we have already helped them! I cant believe I didn't think of that right off the bat!

Anyway, enough of my random rambling (was that repetitive?). I shall return soon with my next blog. It will actually happen this week :) I will also get a chance to talk about what went down with SPARCS. Untill then, stay well. Please keep the people in Houston in your prayers. My family is down there. They made it through fine and with minimal damage, but there is so much to do still. Thanks.

fields.title: why i applied to stars
fields.post:
I applied to STARS because I was interested in the outreach, service, research, and all the other projects it provided that related to Computer Science/IT. Another reason I applied to STARS was because so many of my parents' friends kept telling me that Computer Science was a dying major. If they tell me this, then they probably tell their children this also. I want to gain enough info so that I can go back to Charlotte and inform their children about what Computer Science has instore for them. Even though I am not doing an outreach project this year, simply informing people is "outreach".

I think an interview and a group meeting with all future applicants would be a good idea for next year. I think it would be good for them to get a detailed understanding of STARS, instead of just going to the STARS conference not knowing what to expect.

fields.title: STARS Celebration
fields.post:
The STARS celebration was a very inspirational conference to attend. I very much enjoyed talking to professors outside of a scholastic setting and getting to know them as individuals instead of as just teachers. The atmosphere made it less intimidating to talk to those who have "made it" in the field. I feel being able to attend this event will help me make more informed decisions about my future plans and goals.
If I were to improve on some aspects of the stars event, I would have additional breakout sessions with professors where the professors can discuss their research and what inspired them to focus on that aspect of computer science.
Also, I would want a more substantial breakfast.

fields.title: Week of Sept 8th
fields.post:
This week I had meetings with two of my STARS students, Wayne and Karl. I was able to give Wayne (who goes to St. Aug's) a tour of our building and the IntelliMedia lab, as well as a demo of Crystal Island. Wayne is interested in going to grad school after finishing at St. Aug's, so hopefully seeing a 'real' graduate research lab and research project helps offer some perspective on what grad school and grad life is like. He was able to get a nice book on Javascript from one of his professors, and he plans on spending some time working in Javascript in the next week or so. Our plan is for Wayne to try and develop a small application showing off some of his newly developed Javascript knowledge by the end of the month, before he begins working in earnest on the tools for our Narrative Theater project.

This week Karl showed me a nearly complete version of the Face Tagging Tool that he developed as part of his STARS project last year. It is looking really outstanding. Our plan is for Karl to finish up some final touches / revisions to the program this week, and hand off a 'release' version of the tool to me at our next weekly meeting. Our lab is really excited to have this tool and even start using it this semester. Karl really did a nice job on it. Next, we're working on getting Crystal Island installed on Karl's computer (which can be a process in and of itself) and getting Karl acquainted with the development environment and tools that he would need to contribute to the CI codebase. My hope is to have Karl actually working in Crystal Island's source code to implement some of the features that we have been hoping for over the last several years (e.g. a one-item knapsack / inventory for the player). Over the next several weeks Karl will probably be spending his time familiarizing himself with the development tools, modding Half Life 2, and exploring some of the massive CI codebase.

To address one of the blog topics, this summer I worked as a research assistant under Dr. James Lester in the IntelliMedia lab. Last spring we received an NSF CreativeIT grant to create The Narrative Theater, which I have described in an earlier post. Over the summer, I began design work on this project, did some miscellaneous work on Crystal Island, and researched information on various technologies that will be a part of the Crystal Island and Narrative Theater projects. Much of the work on NT was only very formative, but it was a productive summer and I think we have a leg up on the project work this semester because of it.

fields.title: Why I Joined STARS
fields.post:
I actually became interested in STARS in the spring of 2007. I had decided to go to graduate school, but I wasn't quite sure what I wanted to study. I browsed through current research projects of several professors, including Dr. Laurie Williams. There was a short description of STARS on her website, and I was very interested in it. I talked with Dr. Williams about it to see if there was a way for me to do my thesis on a project that would improve the recruitment and/or retention of women in computing. She encouraged me to pursue something technical that could have the implications of improving the recruitment and retention of women or pursue it as a side project. We later decided I would work on distributed pair programming, which is something I am very interested in...and pair programming has been shown to improve the recruitment of women and minorities in computing. :) Last fall, Dr. Williams told me about the STARS Assistant Academic Liaison position, which sounded so perfect for me. I'm really enjoying working with the STARS members this year as they are all really motivated and a fun group.

I helped with the STARS recruitment process last year, and I think there are a few things we could do to improve the recruitment process. Mostly, we need to make STARS more well-known throughout the department. We're hoping to move the application to an online form, which may be easier for people to fill out. We also hope to move the poster sessions to times more convenient for students to attend so that possible recruits will be able to easily chat with current STARS members.

fields.title: Third Entry - Project Status
fields.post:
This week I'd like to give a status update of the SPARCS outreach project.

Yesterday, Mei, Daniel and I went to CCMS to hold an information session for potential SPARCS students. About a dozen students came to the session including all grades (6th - 8th). Unfortunately only one of the students was female.

After the session the students all seemed really excited. They had lots of questions about the types of projects they would be working on. There were also a lot of logicistical questions (date, travel, etc) which surprised me to be coming from middle school students. I hope this is indicative of well-disciplined mature group of students who are really interested in learning.

Since we didn't quite get the demographic of students we were looking for at the session, Elwood Peters plans to supplement the group by doing targeted recruitment of female and minority students for the program. We hope to have a complete list of students within a week or two.

This week I plan to go over the CCMS, NCSU and St Aug calendars for the next year and plan our SPARCS session dates. Our first session is tentatively scheduled for Oct 18th. It's much later than I had hoped for, but the CCMS modified year round calendar ruled out any earlier dates.

fields.title: Wifi project -- goals
fields.post:
If I can connect to a government-sponsored group, my goals would consist of integrating myself with them and working where their needs are--which could be anything from actual implementation of various designs to a public relation-type project like that one school for learning disabled students did (they did a website-type deal; they presented this year at the conference in Auburn).
If I can connect to a public nonprofit group, the ideas would be much the same.
If I can connect with industry, say, Cisco or someone, then my goals might align more with research and looking at improving the wifi network design or even hardware configuration.

Given the lack of structure in Raleigh, as of today, it is hard to get any response...as of roughly three years ago, this sort of project seemed ideal, but it appears as of now that this idea has fallen a bit by the wayside in the local government's mind. Now, my plan is to upfront call the pertinent offices in Raleigh, and see what more specific information I can garner, as the polite email/website approach has so far failed.

fields.title: First Week
fields.post: Meet up with NC State student. We talked about what will be doing for the outreach program this year.

fields.title: First Week
My Summer
fields.post: The entirety of July, I partook in a research project with Dr Xie. The project dealt with the verification and testing of access control policies. A new language (XACML) is used to implement different access control policies. These policies are very effective but in order to ensure their correctness, rigorous tests have to be run. My job was to incorporate combinatorial testing into the project, compile results, and compare them to those of other testing methods.

fields.title: Goals
fields.post:
First, I want to give Lauren credit for helping me come up with this idea when she was teaching me how to blog. Thank you!

I would like to expose high school students to IT/computing internships. I'm a sophomore, and I haven't had too many courses in computer science, but I successfully gained employment this semester working in IT. Unfortunately, many students procrastinate obtaining an internship because they are afraid that they do not know enough about technology to make them useful to a company. Then, by the time they do apply for an internship, it turns out to be too late and it is time for them to graduate without obtaining that valuable experience.

fields.title: Week of 8/30
fields.post:
This summer I held an internship at the National Football League headquarters in New York, NY. I was in the Information Technology department and assisted in the development of an application that coaches use to study film of games.

Aside from my individual work, I got to learn all about the business of the NFL through presentations that each department gave specifically for the interns (officiation, human resources, marketing, player development). I had a number of fantastic opportunities such as sitting down with Commissioner Roger Goodell for a question and answer session (this happened to be during the time of the Brett Farve indecision).

More Concrete Project Goals (cont. from last blog):

Level 1: Making the application(Wolf Poker) ready to be used in industry
Level 2: Finding a team in industry to willing test the application during their development process, getting feedback of application's effectiveness
Level 3: Adding additional features based on industry feedback, Wolf Poker 2.0

fields.title: Week of Sept 1st
fields.post:
This week I actually took a 1-week hiatus from STARS because of travel to Tokyo, Japan for the International Conference on Intelligent Virtual Agents (IVA-08). It was a very nice conference (http://research.nii.ac.jp/~iva2008/) where I gave a talk about some work on character dialogue generation in Crystal Island. There were a lot of very interesting talks and people at the conference, and I look forward to submitting again to IVA 2009. Tokyo was also a very fun city, and I regret not having even more time to explore. Fortunately, I did have time to eat lots of sushi and take some pictures.

In response to the weekly blog topic, I'd like to compliment Auburn and particularly Cheryl Seals for hosting a great STARS Celebration this August. It was my second STARS Celebration and it's fun to see the projects and event mature and improve year by year. I felt that this year's celebration fostered a lot of nice discussions, connections, and project ideas. Some of the conference sessions were particularly nice; the cyber security speaker comes to mind, as do Tiffany Barnes's sessions on intelligent tutoring and game development. I thought having Nate run a full mentoring workshop was also very helpful, and I look forward to seeing how the various components of that workshop evolve over the coming years.

The Celebration seemed like an effective and fun opportunity for our Raleigh STARS group to meet and come together as a group, which seems like one of the aims of the yearly Celebration. I'm really enthusiastic about this result, and I think it's going to pay dividends as we move forward, work on our projects, and hold events throughout the year.

In response to the other weekly blog topic, I applied to join STARS near the end of Spring 2007 (the end my first year at NCSU). There was an e-mail notice about STARS, it sounded interesting, and I decided to apply on a whim. Having been in computer science departments at two very different colleges, I had noticed that one common theme was the lack of gender and ethnic diversity in my CS classes. In particular, I noticed how different the demographics of my CS classes were compared to some of my non-CS classes. I felt that this was a real loss for Computer Science, and thought that STARS might be a good avenue to address it. The promise of a stipend for participating was also a nice carrot, of course.

My graduating class at my undergrad was the first to partner with the Posse Foundation (http://www.possefoundation.org/), a group that gave scholarships to promising, underprivileged youth from urban areas to go to top liberal arts schools throughout the country. This first group of students quickly became leaders and role models at my undergrad institution, and almost everyone at the school benefited from their presence, made possible by Posse. I felt that for Computer Science as a field to miss out on students like those from Posse would be a big loss, and that STARS was a perfect way to try and fix that. So here I am, and I look forward to continuing work to make that difference!

fields.title: CSC 116 Outreach Set-up and Goals
fields.post:
The reason for CSC 116 Outreach is to help students in CSC 116 with their programming, their GER classes, and adjusting to college life and helping them succeed not only in the Computer Science major but here at NC State. This will be accomplished by giving students who desire it a mentor and they would meet with their mentor weekly. The mentor would provide the student with guidance give them help in their classes (or direct them to someone/somewhere that they could receive help in those classes). In order to not infring on the NCSU Honor Code the mentors would follow a strict "hands off" policy where they are not able to actually type in code for the student only guide them to write their own code and help them understand why it does/doesn't work. Among help in their classes the mentor would also help the mentee get involved on campus (through organizations such as STARS, ACM, Campus Crusade etc.) and get them connected. Social functions will be provided and/or suggested to not only let the students connect with each other but also with other people at NC State. Also the mentor would just provide support for the student. If the student is having trouble academically or personally the mentor will be able to give/find the neccesary support to help the student. The mentors will be myself (JD), Bellanov, and Karl. The mentees will be however many students apply to have a mentor. Students willl have the oppurtunity to sign up for a mentor when we go into each section of CSC 116 and give a short presentation about the program. The application will be online and be relatively short (5-7 questions). The main criteria for matching up mentors and mentees will be available times for both parties. If the program has a large response (20 or more) or the mentor become overwhelmed then we will reach out within the CSC department to find more upperclassmen who wish to be a mentor. Hopefully, that turns out to be the case.

My standard goals
-Get a few students from each section (9-12 students total)
-Have every student in the program receive at least a C- in CSC 116
-Positively impact each student's life in general (have them feel we made a difference)

My over the top goals
-Every single person in every section signs up for the program
-Every person in the program receives an A and has AT LEAST a 3.5 GPA overall
-Every person absolutely loves the program and raves about it
-Program becomes a requirement for all incoming CSC freshmen.

fields.title: Week 2: The STARS Convention/Celebration
fields.post:
Well, I guess I have to start off again with an appology. Life is crazy busy, but thats what makes it interesting, right? Lets get right on with it, cause noone wants to read a long winded thing like last week again.

The Celebration. Wow, try and sum that four and a half day trip in a few paragraphs. Lets keep it simple. It was a ton of fun! It was really neat to get together with my fellow STARS members and figure out exactly what STARS is all about. Probably the coolest speaker at any of the sessions was Linda Criddle, president of Look Both Ways, a company she founded to try and improve internet safety. To say the least, the topics were disturbing, but they were intensely interesting! You simply had to be there to experience it. If anyone reads this and is in charge of next years celebration, BRING HER BACK!!!

The only complaint I have with the event was, and still is, the process for getting money back on plane tickets/any other expenses. Right now, I am sitting here out of 150 bucks for the plane ticket alone! Luckily, I can afford to be without that sum of money at this moment in time, but I am sure there are plenty of others that can't. I almost feel like we should get interest or something. Anyway, just food for thought.

As for my projects, here is a little look into them. For SPARCS, we have set up an introductory meeting after school on Wednesday to try and get a list of possible students. For the Wii-mote project, meetings are being set up right now. Things have been kind of thrown out of wack with the hurricane. Should be much more to report on that in the near future.

My next post will probably be tomorrow, or sometime in the very near future, so untill then, have a great week!

fields.title: STARS conference
fields.post: I didn't really know what to expect going into Auburn, AL for the STARS conference since I am new to STARS. I thought the conference was very informational. There was a mentoring workshop where I took a personality test, which I thought was interesting. The workshops of students talking about their outreach, service, and other projects were also intriguing. The poster session helped me the most because it helped me gather up ideas of how to make my project successful. I loved Auburn's campus as well.

fields.title: Wifi project - reasons and research
fields.post:
"Around the country, some cities say providing cheap wireless Internet access is as essential as water. Why not here?"
http://www.indyweek.com/gyrobase/Content?oid=oid%3A23924
An article written a little over 3 years ago, it describes in great detail similar projects being undertaken all over NC, and talks about the Triangle following suit. However, still no push or concentrated effort for free public wifi has been instigated in Raleigh.

The People's Emergency Center
http://www.pec-cares.org/index.php?page=technology
This organization is based in Philadelphia, the city everyone else is watching to see how its city-wide wifi project works out.
The PEC offers many services to the homeless and poorer sections of the city, including free wifi and cheap refurbished laptops as well as the Teen Technology Network (TTN) which "helps local high school students stay on track for graduation while preparing for job opportunities in the computer technology field. TTN introduces students to basic computer skills and teaches them to refurbish computers, navigate the internet, and design websites for local businesses and organizations."

"Austin's Wireless Mesh Provides Free Access and Test Environment"
http://www.cisco.com/en/US/prod/collateral/wireless/ps5679/ps6548/prod_c...
An example of successful implementation for a section of Austin with help of Cisco's products and workers; notably, they used the new mesh theory of wireless networking.

Downtown Wireless Pilot Project
http://townhall.townofchapelhill.org/news/current_issues/wifi/
Nearby Chapel Hill is managing to start something.

See, an organized and integrated wireless solution city-wide is totally different from merely looking up a few nearby hotspots. It's like the difference between being on a cell phone uninterrupted during an hour car drive, and having to walk down the street and go into every neighbor's house to use one of their phones to continue on a conversation.
It's beneficial to most every aspect of a city's vitality and good growth (with the exception perhaps of large telecom companies who hate the idea), and can be used in many different fashions to benefit the community, as seen in the PEC in Philadelphia.

...to be continued.

fields.title: STARS Week 3
fields.post: This past week I continued to use the Java Script Tutorial and began making sample interactive web pages. I also spoke with Saint Augustine's College Academic Liason Dr. Austin and he instructed us to get well aquainted with the RoboLab that we have here on campus. He aslo asked us to schedule a time for SAC to have there own STARS meetings weekly. This week I spent a total of 6 hours on Java Script Research and Tutorials.

fields.title: STARS Week 2
fields.post: For the week of August 31, I met with my Stars Grad student. He basically introduced me to the research that we would be conducting on the Crystal Island project. He also gave me my first assignment of getting to know Java Script. This past Monday I began to google "Java Script" and use tutorials to help me become more aquainted with the programming language.

fields.title: How I Spent My Summer
fields.post:
I spent my summer working at IBM as part of the Extreme Blue program. Extreme Blue is a fabulous program that I would recommend to anyone who wants a challenging internship. I worked on a team with 2 other technical interns and a business intern. My team was extremely motivated, and it was a lot of fun to take a look at things from a business perspective. The program is also amazing because we don't only do technical things--we also have lots of networking opportunities. Every week we presented our project to IBM executives, and it was cool to be able to learn from some of their experiences.

So, what did I actually do this summer? Our team was tasked with figuring out how to educate customers on IBM products in Second Life (a 3-D online, interactive environment). So we began by deciding which product we wanted to create the education for and then figuring out how to teach adults in a 3-D world. It was challenging since none of us have formal training in education. Once we figured out our plan, we had to implement it using Linden scripting, a state-based programing language (oh, how I missed Java). After being trained to always create unit tests, it was hard for me to feel confident my code was complete without any automated testing. But I survived. Overall, it was a great way to spend my summer.

fields.title: Second Entry - Computing this summer
fields.post:
Describe your favorite and least favorite parts about the STARS celebration. Or describe something related to computing that you did this summer (maybe you had a cool internship!).

This summer I worked at SAS Institute in Cary. I've actually been there for the past three years and this summer wrapped up my long internship with them. The strange thing about finishing up such a position is it gives you a chance to look back at old projects. I worked mainly on internal tools to help support the functioning of my group and over the years I accummulated a large number of such projects. In leaving, I had to figure out how to hand over all of my projects. For most, this was a matter of adding a lot of documentation (lesson learned: do this during the project not after).

However for one project, my manager decided with less than 2 weeks left of my employment that he wanted an exorbitant amount of new features added. He wanted me to get as many done as possible. I suggested to him that I could do 1 and do it well - but the rest may be neglected and not fit into the overall architecture well. My solution was to set up a framework which would support all of the new features and allow them to be added easily.

This was a really interesting project because I had to look at everything from a different perspective. It was no longer just "how can I implement this functionality?", but "how can I assist someone else implementing it?". It was a really fun task and a great way to end my internship. Hopefully if I go back next summer, I can see how well all the new functionality got added in.

fields.title: Introduction
fields.post:
This semester I am continuing my work with Jonathan Rowe on Crystal Island, a narrative-centered learning environment (which actually recently earned a substantial amount of grant money). Where last year I was working on tools surrounding Crystal Island, this year I will be working on the program itself. Here are my goals for the coming semester.

Minimum Goals:
-Get a better understanding of the Source Engine
-Gain experience working as a team on a large codebase
-Wrap up last year's work on the video tagging utility (final bugs, deployment, and maintenance)

Realistic Goals:
-Complete individual features/tasks in time to be used for studies (these have yet to be defined)
-Add a backpack feature to Crystal Island

Pipe Dreams:
-Contribute to a graduate paper on the Crystal Island project (get my name in a research publication)

Unfortunately, Jon and I had to reschedule our meeting, so the exact goals, deadlines, and tasks haven't been finalized yet, but it looks like it will be a great semester.

fields.title: Project Discussion
fields.post:
So far I've met with Dr. Williams twice in order to discuss the Planning Poker research project and the progress I should be able to make from week to week. There is a software application already in existance called "Wolf Poker" (developed by another student) which I will be contributing to along with my group members.

The purpose of the Planning Poker research project is to create an operation profile where Wideband Delphi estimation is used to bring software reliability and security engineering practices into an Agile Software Development method.

Long term goals consist of completing the Wolf Poker application to the point where it can be used in industry. Hopefully it will evolve to actually working with a team in industry to conduct research on the effects of using the Wolf Poker application.

fields.title: Week 1 Blog over goals and the start of the year
fields.post:
Well this certainly is fun. Personally I have never blogged before, so this is something new for me. Lets see, what do I need to talk about for this/last week.
