I dont know where one starts and the other stops, so this is for the week starting 8/24. If I happen to be a day late, oh well. Nothing can be done about it now :)

Starting with SPARCS! What can I say, this is going to be so much fun! Personally, there is nothing more fun than seeing someone's face light up when they discover something new and exciting. Being able to bring that to someone is the best feeling in the world. As for goals of the project, I do believe that Jen will have covered those, but I can run through them real quick. At a basic level, we want to retain at least 50% of the students throughout the year. Of course, having these events on Saturday does make it so some will miss it everyonce in a while, but from what I hear, last year people just stopped coming all together. That is something that we plan to take action against. As a secondary goal, we would like to recieve overall positive feeback on our surveys. We really want to make sure that the students are having a good time and having a positive experience in Computer Science. Can anyone tell that I am super psyched about this :)

Last thing for this post is the Wii Smartboard project. As of right now, I don't really know where we are at. I haven't heard from Dave lately, so I am still a little vague on the details. For the sake of saying a little more on the topic, I will outline a few of my personal goals with this project. At the very least, I would like to be able to get the set-up to work and be deployed in one school. To the next level, I would like to have all the teachers trained on how to use the set-up to the greatest potential, probably with a meeting showing its possiblities. Other than that, I am not quite sure what to expect out of this project. In theory it sounds really cool, but I am rather hesitant on its posibilities now. I am planning on focusing myself on something for SPARCS, but also make myself avalaible for help on this project once it gets a more firm outline.

Enough for one week. If you made it through all of my long winded commentary, CONGRATULATIONS!!! This is gonna be quite a ride, and I look forward to having you along. Untill next time!

fields.title: Goals
fields.post:
Success: the tutoring plugin works correctly for simple programs

Greater Success: the tutoring program is able to handle more complex programs

For our project to be considered successful, an eclipse tutoring plugin implementation that works correctly for simple programs should be achieved. For now, I am reading papers about regression testing and how tests are generated. This will be one of the prime features of the eclipse plugin. Thsi tool component will synthesize a test driver to handle the test generation, where the comparison between the instructor and student programs will take place.

fields.title: first blog
fields.post:
I had my first meeting with my group this past Thursday. Leslie(Meredith), Eric(St. Augustine), Mikhail(Shaw) and I discussed the initial steps we should take for this nursing home service project to be a success. We discussed the questions listed in the blog topics at D.H. Hill Library. We decided that the NC State Library was a good location for our meetings because it is a central location for all of the campuses involved. If we need to contact each other we will do it through e-mail.

We found a few possible nursing homes that we could volunteer at, so once we visit these communities we will decide what supplies we need.
We hope to achieve all of the goals in level one by the end of September.

Level 1 Goals:
-Find a nursing home that will be best to work with from the list of possible locations.
-Make sure the nursing home has enough computers, laptops, webcams, and possibly a projector for the visually impaired.
-Set up a network in the nursing home if they do not have one.

Level 2 Goals:
-Teach the residents how to use e-mail and other communication services a computer can provide.
-Collect e-mail addresses and contact info from resident's loved ones so they can communicate with each other.

Level 3 Goals:
-Try to get more volunteers so get more residents involved in this project.
-If loved ones come visit the residents, we can maybe do an "outreach" activity with the little kids that come visit.

fields.title: STARS Celebration 08
fields.post:
As a newbie to STARS and college life this year, my first experience with anything was the STARS conference held at Auburn University. Despite the long travel time, people in general where engaging and welcoming, as we headed out to grab a bite to eat before the evening start to the mentoring workshop. This workshop lasted for a few days, off and on, and consisted primarily of tools to meet, get to know, and mentor/council others that we may encounter while spreading the STARS message of broadening participation in computing.
At other points during the conference we (the group from NC State) were able to discuss what outreach/projects we wanted to do this coming semester/year. This gave me some idea of where I wanted to plug in, and what I wanted to do, as well as see how effective STARS has been already over the past few years.

fields.title: First Blog Entry - STARS Goals
fields.post:
This semester I am the coordinator for the SPARCS middle school outreach program. We had our first meeting this Wednesday and have come up with some plans and goals for getting the program started and ensuring it's success. We have come up with the following year-long goals:

Level 1
Retain 50% of students through the entire program. Last year, we only retained about 1/3 so hopefully we can do better this time

Level 2
Get an overall positive rating on surveys.
Have an increased interest in computer science careers between pre and post surveys

Level 3
90% interest in computer science careers on post survey

In addition to these long-term goals we have to following goals for the end of September:

  • Get all students registered for volunteer work through WCPSS
  • Organize an info session for prospective students - Tentatively Sept 10
  • Finalize list of middle school students
  • Hold first SPARCS session

fields.title: Semester Goals
fields.post:
This week I met with Rob and Christa. I'll be working with Rob on the STARS website, which I'm very excited about. I also had a planning meeting for the Reaching for the STARS weekend where STARS students from several different STARS groups will get together with IBM representatives for some professional development.

This week was also the Computer Science/Computer Engineering Welcome Back Bash. Several student organizations had booths representing their organizations. Several of our students manned our booth, and I got to know them a little better. Unfortunately, we really only recruit in the spring, so our presence was more just a way for us to get our name out in the department. One of my overall goals this year is to get STARS to be more well-known within the department. During the event, we met one high-school female who is currently taking Computer Science classes at NCSU and she was interested in the middle school outreach. We are very excited about having her become part of our group this year!

So, on to the goals:

Level 1 Goals

  • Update members page on the website with new members
  • Update projects page on the website with new 2008 projects
  • Create an archive page for previous years' projects
  • Create a clear description of what STARS is and what STARS students do.
  • Check on current sponsorship with Ken Tate and Kristy and update website to reflect this
  • Plan and execute the end-of-semester poster session

Level 2 Goals

  • Get the STARS website posted on the CSC website
  • Create a page for Alumni STARS members to detail life after graduating
  • Make the STARS application an online application
  • Create links to other Raleigh STARS groups
  • Include a Google Calender to the Events page
  • Plan an event with the other Raleigh STARS groups

Level 3 Goals

  • Verify that the entire website is 508 compliant
  • Develop a log in process for Alumni to enter their information
  • Plan a "fun" STARS outing
  • Plan a STARS road-show for local high-schools
  • Expand and customize the Drupal site to better fit our needs. For example, get the feed aggregator working correctly, customize the template to better match the STARS website, and create some sort of auto-backup system.
  • Partner with other CSC student organizations to plan a training workshop for high school Computer Science teachers.

When and where will you meet with the others working on your project?
I'll be meeting with Rob on Tuesdays at 10:45 in the computer lab, and Christa on Wednesdays at 12:45.

How will you arrange transportation to these meetings?
Not an issue.

If you need to contact the others working on your project, how will you typically contact them (e.g., by phone, e-mail, in person)?
E-mail

What software and/or supplies will you need for your project? Does everyone on your team have access to that software and/or supplies?
Dreamweaver. We need to make sure the lab still has Dreamweaver loaded.

Which of the goals you wrote above do plan to complete by the end of September?

  • Update members page on the website with new members
  • Update projects page on the website with new 2008 projects
  • Create an archive page for previous years' projects
  • Create a clear description of what STARS is and what STARS students do.

fields.title: Week of Aug 25th
fields.post:
This week I had my first STARS meeting of the new semester with Roman and Wayne, the St. Augustine's students that I am mentoring in research. We had a very productive discussion about the different projects that we could work on this semester and how it fits into the bigger picture of research at the IntelliMedia Lab at NCSU.

Roman and Wayne will be helping out by building some of the core infrastructure for the Narrative Theater project, a new project in the IntelliMedia lab funded by the NSF CreativeIT program. The idea behind the project is to build a creativity support tool, where students sit down at a terminal and write short creative stories that are situated in the game world of Crystal Island. Students will be able to press a button after completing their stories and watch their story "come to life" through an animated, graphical representation of the story displayed using game engine technologies. The expectation is that the use of multiple representations of the story (textual and graphical) will encourage student revisions and the creative process. Roman and Wayne will be using Javascript to help build web-based tools that students will use to interact with the Narrative Theater.

Later today I have my first meeting of the semester with Karl, who will be finishing up his work on the facial expression tagging tool that he worked on last year. We're looking forward to using his tool this semester in the lab. For his next project, we may have Karl working on some additional web tools for the Narrative Theater project, or actually working in the Crystal Island source code to help implement extended features for the game.

This Friday (tomorrow) I will be leaving for Japan to present at the IVA Conference in Tokyo. I won't be returning until Sept 5th, so my next STARS mentoring meetings will not be until the following week.

My goals for this semester are:

1. Write and schedule my written prelim exam.

2. Successfully implement a new version of Crystal Island (using some of Karl's help!) that includes a student modeling and tutoring component for a November study at CCMS.

3. Start developing infrastructure and a plan for the Narrative Theater project (using Wayne and Roman's work!) so that we can begin making significant developmental progress on it in the Spring.
